10147-8{_}1572{_}By September 13th the Americans had taken forty-seven towns and villages, reduced the German front from forty miles to twenty, captured the railway that connects Verdun with Commercy, opened the cities of Nancy and Toul to the allies, and with the French and British on the east, created a new battle front on a line running from Hattonville on the west to Pagny on the east--Pagny being a town on the Moselle river, at the German border.
10147-8{_}1573{_}The importance of this victory could hardly be overestimated.
10147-8{_}1574{_}It opened the way to and was followed up by the demolition of the whole German line from the Swiss border to the North Sea, and hastened the great German retreat.
10147-8{_}1575{_}In the action itself, September 11 to 13, about 15, Germans were taken prisoner by the Americans.
10147-8{_}1576{_}STORIES TO THE FOLKS BACK HOME  Sidelight stories of what happened in the St. Mihiel fight, mostly in letters written home by men who were in it, go far toward showing how completely the Germans were taken off their guard.
10147-8{_}1577{_}Corp. Ray Fick of the 103d Infantry wrote home in this wise:  "We got into the woods and then kept on going until we reached a big city where there was a brewery, but they had set fire to the whole city before they left.
10147-8{_}1578{_}We got some beer and wine just the same.
10147-8{_}1579{_}It was a little stale, but it was fine.
10147-8{_}1580{_}The Huns' warehouses were all fixed for the winter and the boys got cigars and cigarettes, but I was a little too late to get in on it.
10147-8{_}1581{_}"The whole thing was very interesting all the way through.
10147-8{_}1582{_}The Huns sure did make themselves scarce in a hurry, but they kept many prisoners, a troop train and an ammunition train.
10147-8{_}1583{_}"Cigarettes are scarce and we look for smokes all the time.
10147-8{_}1584{_}The Red Cross and the Salvation Army are the ones who look to our comforts.
10147-8{_}1585{_}If any one wants to give, tell them the Red Cross and the Salvation Army are the ones to get it."
10147-8{_}1586{_}HUNS CARRY OFF CAPTIVE WOMEN  But Corporal Fick uncovers another Hun procedure that has no fun in it.
10147-8{_}1587{_}While the Huns lost no time in getting away from there, they took care to carry off their captured women slaves.
10147-8{_}1588{_}"The women they have held captives for the last four years," he writes, "were driven ahead of them, but they were brought back by the Americans.
10147-8{_}1589{_}Truckload after truckload passed us on the way, and they sure were happy to be free again."
10147-8{_}1590{_}"HELL HAS CUT LOOSE"  Another soldier wrote to his father telling about the first day of attack as he saw it:  "Hell has let loose.
10147-8{_}1591{_}The woods are a mass of whistling shell and shrapnel.
10147-8{_}1592{_}Every time the big twelves go off the flash lights up the entire camp like a flashlight picture, then the ground heaves and tumbles like old Lake Michigan does on a stormy day.
10147-8{_}1593{_}"The infantry have cleared the top and have gone on far in advance, almost outside of the range of fire.
10147-8{_}1594{_}Our big objective has been wiped off the map and our men are preparing to keep right on going after them and backing up the doughboys who are doing such great work.
10147-8{_}1595{_}"I went up to the front last night on an ammunition caisson (which is the only way to get up there) and saw the thing commence.
10147-8{_}1596{_}It started with one solitary gun of ours (a big one, too).
10147-8{_}1597{_}Then the others joined in on the chorus, and it has been steady ever since.
10147-8{_}1598{_}"When the doughboys were told that they were going over the top at the zero hour, you never heard shouting to equal it; the Board of Trade on a Monday morning was just a whisper in comparison.
10147-8{_}1599{_}"Dad, that is the general feeling of our boys over here--always waiting to move up.
10147-8{_}1600{_}I told a lad in one of the outfits that the artillery was right back of them and would blow them through to the objective if they did not make it, and he laughed and said, 'Hoboken by Christmas.'
10147-8{_}1601{_}They were all in the best of mood and roaring to go."
10147-8{_}1602{_}These letters are good specimens of the thousands that have come over the sea.
10147-8{_}1603{_}They not only give good sidelights on an event that will loom large in history, but they show the indomitable cheer and high spirit of our soldiers.
10147-8{_}1604{_}MAJOR TELLS HIS STORY  Concurrently with the action that originated at St. Mihiel on September 11, 1918, another great battle developed northwest of Verdun.
10147-8{_}1605{_}It lasted about three weeks, and is graphically described by Lt. Col. B.M.
10147-8{_}1606{_}Chipperfield (then a major) of the 23d Division.
10147-8{_}1607{_}Lt. Col. Chipperfield was a participant in as well as an eyewitness of the whole engagement.
10147-8{_}1608{_}Under date of September 29, 1918, the described it substantially as follows, in a letter to a friend at home:  "For several days preparations had been in progress for the action that began on Thursday, September 26th.
10147-8{_}1609{_}The American troops were moved up by night, jamming the roads with their advancing columns and transport trains.
10147-8{_}1610{_}"Thousands and thousands of them," wrote Major Chipperfield, "trudged along without a light and in almost quiet.
10147-8{_}1611{_}ENORMOUS NUMBERS OF GUNS  "Tanks and cannon and guns of all sorts, every kind of vehicle, ambulance wagon, and transport passed in this continuous procession.
10147-8{_}1612{_}It seemed that there was no end to it, and one could not help but admire the wonderful resources that had been gathered together by the United States to help perform its part in this great struggle for freedom.
10147-8{_}1613{_}"I think the greatest collection of guns that has ever been gathered together for participation in any conflict of the world was taken to the front where the attack was about to be made.
10147-8{_}1614{_}It is estimated there were 6,000 of these guns, and the soldiers that were gathered together numbered hundreds of thousands.
10147-8{_}1615{_}"These guns and soldiers were conducted to their places so secretly and quietly that, although they marched many miles, the enemy did not even know a small part of the strength and could only speculate what it all meant.
10147-8{_}1616{_}UNDER ENFILADING FIRE  "In the arrangement of the plan of battle our division was on the extreme right.
10147-8{_}1617{_}Across the river was a German stronghold.
10147-8{_}1618{_}Here there were located a large quantity of artillery and many machine guns.
10147-8{_}1619{_}Our officers understood that it was going to be a difficult advance, for a bridge had to be built across a creek, but everything in our division went like clockwork.
10147-8{_}1620{_}It had all been planned in advance, and the plan was carried out exactly as made.
10147-8{_}1621{_}"It was arranged that at 11:30 o'clock on Thursday night the battle was to begin.
10147-8{_}1622{_}Before that time I had reached my destination at the headquarters of the other division, and together with the rest of the headquarters staff we were in a favorable place to watch the commencement.
10147-8{_}1623{_}"At 11:25 it was silent as the grave, and the night was beautiful.
10147-8{_}1624{_}Precisely at 11:30 from every conceivable direction the great bombardment commenced.
10147-8{_}1625{_}In an instant the whole night was filled with a roar and thunder and reverberation of the cannon from, every quarter.
10147-8{_}1626{_}The shriek and whistle and whine and clamor of the shells made a fearful chorus as they were hurled in the direction of the field occupied by our adversaries.
10147-8{_}1627{_}"From every quarter came the flash of the explosions, until the night was lighted as bright as day.
10147-8{_}1628{_}Signal rockets rose from every portion and part of our lines and also from the enemy lines.
10147-8{_}1629{_}It looked as though the heavens were ablaze and raining fire.
10147-8{_}1630{_}It was a scene which has probably never been seen before upon any battlefield and may never be witnessed again.
10147-8{_}1631{_}"Apparently this fierce bombardment took the enemy entirely by surprise because our fire was so deadly and the extent so great that they could only make uncertain reply.
10147-8{_}1632{_}They seemed to be stupefied.
10147-8{_}1633{_}"For six hours this terrific bombardment continued.
10147-8{_}1634{_}It is estimated that each of the guns fired an average of three shots a minute and that 1,000,000 projectiles and charges of ammunition were used.
10147-8{_}1635{_}OVER THE TOP AT 5:30 A.M.  "As 5:30 approached the bombardment increased.
10147-8{_}1636{_}The machine guns joined in the chorus and a curtain of steel and fire was placed in front of our troops and rained upon the guns and cannon of the enemy.
10147-8{_}1637{_}"After a brief period of this fire our men started over the top, and as they did so they swept the enemy before them in their irresistible rush.
10147-8{_}1638{_}They advanced kilometer after kilometer.
10147-8{_}1639{_}They could not be resisted or stayed at any stage of the attack.
10147-8{_}1640{_}"Soon the prisoners commenced to come in, and they told of the terrific effect that the great bombardment had upon the Germans.
10147-8{_}1641{_}They said the bombardment was so terrible that it disrupted their plans so that they could not be carried out and that they could not resist the attack.
10147-8{_}1642{_}"Several times during the night I went out to witness the scene and as long as life lasts it will be remembered.
10147-8{_}1643{_}ON DEAD MAN'S HILL    "Once when two of our regiments came over a hill and saw the   valley that lay before them being terrifically shelled by the cannon   and assailed by hail from the machine guns, the whole column was   seen to pause and a look of worry came over the faces of these men   that for just an instant was pitiful.
10147-8{_}1644{_}They knew that ahead of them lay   death for many and it is not strange that for several seconds the   lines were held up, but then a look of fierce determination and of   courage took the place of the former expression and with a great   resolve and courage, dash, and daring, the lines shot forward at a   redoubled step and the determination to do or die was manifested in   every action.
10147-8{_}1645{_}"These machine guns were speedily put out of business, and   then the attack would go on.
10147-8{_}1646{_}That portion of the lines that the   division of which I am a member was given for the purpose of the   attack, it was thought would take the entire day, but our division   was on its objective by early afternoon and had commenced to dig   in, from which position they could defy the Germans with impunity.
10147-8{_}1647{_}"While the attack was going on I went up to Dead Man's Hill.
10147-8{_}1648{_}This hill is the last word in the destructiveness of war.
10147-8{_}1649{_}"It is literally rent to atoms.
10147-8{_}1650{_}Dugouts have been blown to   pieces.
10147-8{_}1651{_}Hundreds of thousands of men had been killed in the earlier   battles before Verdun, and many of the bodies could not be reached   for burial, the place was so torn up."
10147-8{_}1652{_}OTHER PERSONAL GLIMPSES  Many other personal glimpses of the fighting come from officers and men.
10147-8{_}1653{_}One division was made up largely of Illinois regiments, among others the 3d Illinois Infantry, commanded by Col. John V. Clinnin.
10147-8{_}1654{_}The position held by these troops was vital to the entire advance, and it required rapid action on the first day to reach the objective at the same time as the other units.
10147-8{_}1655{_}Menomme creek is a little stream which is not shown on maps.
10147-8{_}1656{_}It runs eastward from the village of Septsarges to the Meuse.
10147-8{_}1657{_}The stream holds vivid memories for the Illinois infantry.
10147-8{_}1658{_}It was there that it met the most severe resistance, the Germans catching our men just as they were relieving other young soldiers.
10147-8{_}1659{_}The men fought their way down to the creek.
10147-8{_}1660{_}On the other side along the highway between Septsarge and Dannevoux the Germans had entrenched themselves and were shelling the road which the Americans had crossed.
10147-8{_}1661{_}They were also using intrenched machine guns at the edge of the woods.
10147-8{_}1662{_}"I heard bullets whistling overhead," said a wounded soldier in   a hospital.
10147-8{_}1663{_}"We were lying near the edge of the creek at the time and knew that a machine gun was shooting at us, so I just started out and got it."
10147-8{_}1664{_}"Our colonel was right up there with us getting into line."
10147-8{_}1665{_}said Private Hiram E. Burnett.
10147-8{_}1666{_}"One night when the shells were bursting all around and several men were wounded the colonel went over the top just like any of us."
10147-8{_}1667{_}The Bois des Forges has been a battle ground since the war began, with trenches in front and miles of barbed wire, machine gun nests and concrete pillboxes inside.
10147-8{_}1668{_}A frontal attack on such a stronghold apparently meant suicide, but the Illinois men, led by Col. Sanborn and Col. Abel Davis, took it so neatly and quickly that they bagged nearly 1,000 soldiers, fifteen officers, twenty-six guns ranging from 105s down, 126 machine guns, twenty-one flatcars, two rolling kitchens, an ambulance and thousands of rounds of ammunition.
10147-8{_}1669{_}"We were looking for you in front," said a captured German officer.
10147-8{_}1670{_}"We did not expect that you would come through the swamp and outflank us.
10147-8{_}1671{_}We did not think that any Yankee outfit was so foxy."
10147-8{_}1672{_}"A GREAT SHOW"  "It was a great show when we crossed that river and rushed on through the woods, cleaning up machine gun nests," said Private Gray McKindy of Woodstock, "The machine guns in the woods started throwing bullets as soon as we reached the river.
10147-8{_}1673{_}They thought they could stop us from going up the opposite hill, but we did it and got every gun there."
10147-8{_}1674{_}Private Kenneth W. Steiger was one of those who went in on the second night when his captain called for volunteers to make up a patrol.
10147-8{_}1675{_}Steiger became separated from the others in the darkness and ran into a party of three Germans.
10147-8{_}1676{_}Quickly covering them with his rifle he brought all three back.
10147-8{_}1677{_}Private Bernard Snyder returned with prisoners before dark on the first day.
10147-8{_}1678{_}Making use of his ability to speak German, he induced a dozen Germans to lay down their arms, pick up stretchers and carry American wounded back five kilometers (three miles) to where ambulances were waiting.
10147-8{_}1679{_}A FIGHTING CHAPLAIN  Lieut.
10147-8{_}1680{_}Jorgen R. Enger, the chaplain of a Kansas-Missouri outfit, carried the wounded for three days from the Montfaucon woods two miles to the ambulance.
10147-8{_}1681{_}Searching in the woods in the darkness one night with shells bursting and bullets whistling he found a husky sergeant wounded in the foot and growing weaker and weaker from loss of blood.
10147-8{_}1682{_}The chaplain shouldered the man and carried him back to a dressing station, saving his life.
10147-8{_}1683{_}"I didn't think a chaplain would do a thing like that," said the sergeant.
10147-8{_}1684{_}"I would rather save you than save a general," replied the chaplain.
10147-8{_}1685{_}When not searching for wounded hidden in the tangle of under-brush the chaplain was busy helping the surgeons at a first aid dressing station.
10147-8{_}1686{_}"I never thought any clergyman would have the opportunities for doing good such as I am haying," he said when I saw him.
10147-8{_}1687{_}Col. Eugene Houghton, Wisconsin, who was a British major until America entered the war, distinguished himself by personally leading a unit of New York men.
10147-8{_}1688{_}According to them he escaped death repeatedly as by a miracle.
10147-8{_}1689{_}"DESERT?
10147-8{_}1690{_}NO, WANTED TO FIGHT"  Capt.
10147-8{_}1691{_}Carl F. Laurer while assisting in the examination of German prisoners, was surprised when an American prisoner was brought before him.
10147-8{_}1692{_}"Where do you belong?"
10147-8{_}1693{_}asked the captain.
10147-8{_}1694{_}"I am with an aerial squadron in the south of France" replied the prisoner.
10147-8{_}1695{_}"I walked fourteen days to get here."
10147-8{_}1696{_}"Did you desert?"
10147-8{_}1697{_}asked Captain Lauer.
10147-8{_}1698{_}"No," the man replied, "I want to fight.
10147-8{_}1699{_}That is what I came to France for.
10147-8{_}1700{_}When I get home the folks will ask what I did in the war and when I answer 'worked' they will say 'Why the devil didn't you fight?'"
10147-8{_}1701{_}The boy's wish was gratified and he was sent forward.
10147-8{_}1702{_}"We have everything good and plenty--rations, ammunition and other things.
10147-8{_}1703{_}It looks like a regular Sunday."
10147-8{_}1704{_}TEXAS AND OKLAHOMA TROOPS SHOW GREAT FIGHTING FORM  In this district, the 36th Division, made up of troops from Texas and Oklahoma, veterans and raw recruits together, showed splendid fighting form.
10147-8{_}1705{_}They were under terrific shell fire day after day, but they met several murderous attacks firmly, and drove the boches back in brilliant counter attack, chasing them in true Ranger style.
10147-8{_}1706{_}All these men showed the same spirit that animated Roosevelt's renowned Rough Riders in the war with Spain, so many of whom were Texas and Oklahoma men.
10147-8{_}1707{_}Reporting this fight, General Naulin, commanding the Corps of which the 2d and 36th Divisions were parts, said "the 36th Division, a recent formation not yet completely organized, was ordered into line on the night of October 6-7 to relieve, under conditions particularly delicate, the 2d Division, and to dislodge the enemy from the crest north of St. Etienne and throw him back to the Aisne.
10147-8{_}1708{_}Although being under fire for the first time, the young soldiers of Maj. Gen. W. R. Smith, rivaling in combative spirit and tenacity the old and valiant regiment of General LeJeune, accomplished all the tasks set for them."
10147-8{_}1709{_}Every American knows full well the bright record of the 2d Division of Infantry, the regulars of which were composed of the 5th and 6th Marines and the 9th and 23rd Infantry.
10147-8{_}1710{_}These are the boys who stopped the Germans up in Belleau Wood when the boches were headed for Paris and cocksure of getting there, blandly unaware that they were goose-stepping toward an American knock-out.
10147-8{_}1711{_}OUR COLORED TROOPS WIN CREDIT  American negro troops had a considerable share in the last few months of fighting, and acquitted themselves in a highly creditable manner.
10147-8{_}1712{_}They were great trench diggers and trench fighters, and their endurance on the march was a marvel to the allied armies.
10147-8{_}1713{_}They were very popular with the French people, who were delighted with their good nature and their never-ceasing songs.
10147-8{_}1714{_}Regular negro melodies these songs were, nearly all of them of the camp-meeting variety--and sung with that choral beauty which especially distinguishes all of their musical performances.
10147-8{_}1715{_}The negro notion of war and indifference to death was instanced in the case where a white officer overheard one of them at the zero hour call out, "Good night ol' world!
10147-8{_}1716{_}Good mawin,' Mistah Jesus!"
10147-8{_}1717{_}as he went over the top.
10147-8{_}1718{_}"The colored boys," said Charles N. Wheeler, a distinguished   correspondent with the American armies, "are great fighters, and   are no better and no worse than any other group of American soldiers   in France, whatever the blood strain.
10147-8{_}1719{_}They do take pardonable pride   in the fact that 'Mistah' Johnson, a colored boy, was the first American   soldier in France to be decorated for extraordinary bravery under   fire.
10147-8{_}1720{_}THEY CAN FIGHT AND SING    "The color line has about died out in the American army--in   France.
10147-8{_}1721{_}They play together, sing their songs together--the blacks   and the white--and they go over the top together.
10147-8{_}1722{_}They come back   together, too, the wounded, and there is no thought of the color of a   man's skin.
10147-8{_}1723{_}They mix together on the convoy trains going up to the   front, and all sing together, sharing each other's dangers and their   joys.
10147-8{_}1724{_}It is not an uncommon sight to see a crowd of white doughboys   around a piano in some 'Y' or Red Cross hut, singing to beat the band,   with a colored jass expert pounding the stuffing out of the piano.
10147-8{_}1725{_}The   white boys enjoy immensely the wit of the colored comrades, and   many a bleak and drab day of privation and suffering is made a bit   brighter by the humor that comes spontaneously to the lips of the   'bronze boys.'
10147-8{_}1726{_}"The children of France love them.
10147-8{_}1727{_}I suppose that is because   they wear American soldiers' uniforms.
10147-8{_}1728{_}I have seen scores of white   children holding the hands of colored boys and trudging along on   the march with them or romping into their tents and sitting on their   knees and just exuding the affection that all the children of France   have for anything and everybody from the United States."
10147-8{_}1729{_}CHAPTER V.   THE WAR IN THE AIR  The Hughes report on air craft, submitted in October, 1918, contained a full account of the difficulties, drawbacks and questionable management that had held back the manufacture and shipment of airplanes to Europe.
10147-8{_}1730{_}In September there were on the French-Belgian front between 300 and machines, all of which were in the scout and observation classes, with no regulation combat planes of American build; but American airmen had conducted many successful actions against German battle planes, and a good many Americans were operating French and British battle planes in action back of the German lines.
10147-8{_}1731{_}The combined American, British, French and Canadian planes had before that time cleared the air of German observation and other machines in front of the allied lines, thereby preventing hostile observation of allied camps and artillery positions and movements of troops preparatory to attack.
10147-8{_}1732{_}The efficiency of this combined air service is credited with having contributed in an important degree, first to retarding the movement of supplies from the enemy rear to the enemy fighting line, and next to disturbance of the enemy in retreat.
10147-8{_}1733{_}The Americans especially distinguished themselves by flying at high speed along the last of the enemy trenches and clearing up the German troops therein by continuous streams of machine gun fire.
10147-8{_}1734{_}American flyers also made successful raids across the German border, blowing up munitions works, railway centers, and German troops at concentration points.
10147-8{_}1735{_}Between early September and late October, 1918, they dropped thousands of tons of high explosives inside of Germany.
10147-8{_}1736{_}At the same time, in association with British and Canadian aviators, they put a definite end to German air raids upon the British Isles and interior France.
10147-8{_}1737{_}The Canadian air service during the summer and early autumn of 1918 increased at the rate of 300 planes per month, all manufactured in Canada.
10147-8{_}1738{_}LIBERTY MOTORS AND AIR SERVICE  After July, 1918, the output of Liberty motors for the Government caught up with the immediate demand.
10147-8{_}1739{_}It increased until in October it reached a rate of about 5,000 a month.
10147-8{_}1740{_}The Ford factory at Detroit alone reported at the end of October an established monthly rate of increase of over 1,500.
10147-8{_}1741{_}AMERICAN FLYERS DOWN 473 PLANES IN TWO MONTHS  American flyers made a great record in the closing days of war.
10147-8{_}1742{_}In the period from September 12 to 11:00 o'clock on the morning of November 11, American aviators claim they brought down 473 German machines.
10147-8{_}1743{_}Of this number, 353 have been confirmed officially.
10147-8{_}1744{_}Day bombing groups from the time they began operations dropped a total of 116,818 kilograms of bombs within the German lines.
10147-8{_}1745{_}THE WAR IN THE AIR  Aviation is the most perilous of all services, calling for young bodies, high spirit, quick wit, personal initiative, and unshakable nerve.
10147-8{_}1746{_}Thus it has drawn in the best and brightest of America's sons--brilliant, clear-eyed, steady youths, who take the air and its perils with joyous ardor.
10147-8{_}1747{_}The danger, the romance, the thrill of air fighting, are things that never were known in war until this one called into being vast aerial navies that grappled in the sky and rained upon the earth below "a ghastly dew" of blood.
10147-8{_}1748{_}There are no tales of this war more fascinating than those that have been told by these men.
10147-8{_}1749{_}Courage and modesty being inseparable, our aviators avoid print and cannot be interviewed with any satisfaction.
10147-8{_}1750{_}But sometimes they write home to a mother, a sweetheart or a pal, and these letters now and then come to light.
10147-8{_}1751{_}CHANCE OF LIVING NOW  "I cannot describe my feelings, right off the bat," said Eddie Rickenbacker, the ace of American aces, the day following the signing of the armistice.
10147-8{_}1752{_}"But I can say I feel ninety-nine per cent better.
10147-8{_}1753{_}There is a chance of living now and the gang is glad."
10147-8{_}1754{_}Rickenbacker became a captain during the last phase of the war and has twenty-four victories over enemy airmen to his credit.
10147-8{_}1755{_}To Rickenbacker, whose home is in Columbus, Ohio, the allied command gave the honor of making the last flight over the German front and firing the last shot from the air on the morning of November 11, 1918.
10147-8{_}1756{_}AIR PLANE'S TAIL SHOT OFF  In reporting this most remarkable occurrence Edward Price Bell, an American correspondent, wrote as follows from the front:  A British observer, flying a powerful machine at 16,000 feet over Ostend, had the machine's tail shot off by the direct hit of a shell--a very unusual occurrence.
10147-8{_}1757{_}The machine turned upside down, out of control, and the pilot was thrown out of his seat.
10147-8{_}1758{_}By some inexplicable maneuver he managed to clamber on to the bottom of the fuselage of the machine, astride of which he sat as if he was riding a horse.
10147-8{_}1759{_}Though the machine was out of control, owing to the loss of its tail planes, yet by moving forward and backward he so managed to balance it that it glided fairly steadily downward, although upside down.
10147-8{_}1760{_}He successfully brought it across the German lines, and came safely to within a few hundred feet of the ground.
10147-8{_}1761{_}Then he crashed and was injured, but is now recovering in a hospital.
10147-8{_}1762{_}When it is considered that this incident occurred at a height of 16, feet, over hostile territory, and that during the airman's terribly precarious ride he was subject to antiaircraft fire, and liable to the attack of hostile scouts, it is not too much to say that his was a record achievement.
10147-8{_}1763{_}Recently, another airman was shot down, out of control, from 13, feet, and fell fluttering like a leaf, toward the ground.
10147-8{_}1764{_}At a height of 9,000 feet he fainted.
10147-8{_}1765{_}Shortly afterward he came to and found himself in the machine upside down, in a marsh, absolutely unhurt.
10147-8{_}1766{_}Many airmen, of course, have been through several "crashes" without sustaining so much as a broken collar bone.
10147-8{_}1767{_}JOINS THE SKY FIGHTERS  This story of Lieut.
10147-8{_}1768{_}Manderson Lehr, who refused a transfer home and shortly after died in combat, is taken (by permission) from his personal letters written to a friend in this country.
10147-8{_}1769{_}It is typical of many that might be told by or about brilliant young Americans who would not wait for America's participation in the war, but went voluntarily, with high hearts and eager hands, to help those other boys of France and the British Empire to whom had fallen so large and so momentous a part in the world's salvation.
10147-8{_}1770{_}Nearly all of these American lads, the choicest spirits of our nation, took up whatever work they could find--anything, so long as it was useful, or contributed in any way to winning out against the German hordes, or stem the flood of German crime that was sweeping over Europe, that would later, if it were not stopped, cover our continent with an inundation of blood and desolation.
10147-8{_}1771{_}Most of them, like Lieutenant Lehr, went into ambulance service; and afterward when the air planes were ready and needed men to fly them, took to the air.
10147-8{_}1772{_}These were the men who "put out the eyes" of the German armies and piloted the allies to many a victory.
10147-8{_}1773{_}And alas!
10147-8{_}1774{_}Many of them, like Lehr, gave up their lives--though not in vain, nor without having sent down to crashing death, each one, his share of the flyers of the foe.
10147-8{_}1775{_}LEHR'S STORY  Lieutenant Lehr's story begins with a letter from France just after his arrival in Paris on May 15, 1917, when he joined the Ambulance Corps--later entering the air service.
10147-8{_}1776{_}It covered a period of more than a year's experiences at the front.
10147-8{_}1777{_}The last letter from Lieut.
10147-8{_}1778{_}Lehr was dated June 14th, 1918, when the big German drive was about at its climax.
10147-8{_}1779{_}According to news reports from the front Lehr had a period of intense activity up to July 15th, when he was reported missing.
10147-8{_}1780{_}"Bud" was regarded as one of the most adept of American fliers.
10147-8{_}1781{_}One of the last news reports from the front told of him still flying under French colors and having twice returned from raids with his passenger killed by enemy attacks and of his being awarded the war cross.
10147-8{_}1782{_}The same report told of a 150 mile raid into Germany with eight other French Machines--when a patrol of twelve German planes were attacked and three of them sent down in flames, while all the nine French machines returned safely.
10147-8{_}1783{_}The following are a few of Lehr's later letters from the front:  FLYING AT THE FRONT  Sector----at the Front, Oct. 12, 1917.--It's blowing terrifically, wind and rain.
10147-8{_}1784{_}You can't imagine how I picture you people at home, warm, happy and safe.
10147-8{_}1785{_}I've been out here a week now.
10147-8{_}1786{_}Three days of it has been flying weather.
10147-8{_}1787{_}Up 25,000 feet and ten miles into Germany is my record so far and I've actually had one combat with a boche.
10147-8{_}1788{_}He was below me, at first, far in the distance.
10147-8{_}1789{_}I was supposed to be protecting a bombing expedition of ten machines.
10147-8{_}1790{_}I saw this spot, started away from the rest and through excitement, anticipation and the goodness knows what, I climbed, went faster and faster until I had the sun between us and the German below me.
10147-8{_}1791{_}Then I dived; he heard me and "banked"; we both looped and then came head on, firing incessantly.
10147-8{_}1792{_}My machine gun was empty and the boche had more, for he got in behind me and "Putt!
10147-8{_}1793{_}Putt!
10147-8{_}1794{_}Putt!"
10147-8{_}1795{_}past my ear he came, so I dove, went into a "vrille" with him on top, came out and squared off, and he let me have it again.
10147-8{_}1796{_}All I could do was to maneuver, for I had no shells left and I did not want to beat it, so I stuck.
10147-8{_}1797{_}We both came head on again and I said a little prayer, but the next time I looked Mr. Boche was going home.
10147-8{_}1798{_}I "peaked" straight down, made my escadrille, accompanied them home and when I got out of my furs I was wringing wet in spite of the fact it was cold as ice where I had done my fighting.
10147-8{_}1799{_}CONSIDERS HIS OWN TACTICS  I looked my machine over and found five holes in it, but nothing serious.
10147-8{_}1800{_}Tomorrow is going to be bad and no one will fly unless they call for volunteers, and then I think most of us will go.
10147-8{_}1801{_}I'd like to figure out what I did wrong.
10147-8{_}1802{_}First of all, I was so excited that I fired all my shots at the German and he maneuvered out of my way and then came at me as I was helpless.
10147-8{_}1803{_}My captain gave me "harkey" for staying when out of bullets, so I guess the rest was O.K., but I'd hate to run from any boche.
10147-8{_}1804{_}MEN DIE IN FAULTY PLANES  The machine I've been flying has been condemned, so I expect to be sent back to get another one, a brand new one that has never been on the front.
10147-8{_}1805{_}Twenty-five pilots in the last month have been killed by wings dropping off.
10147-8{_}1806{_}I've seen twelve go and it surely takes the old pep out of you.
10147-8{_}1807{_}I was above one and saw his wing crumple, then fall.
10147-8{_}1808{_}A man is so utterly helpless he must merely sit there and wait to be killed, and when you're flying the same type of machine it doesn't help your confidence any.
10147-8{_}1809{_}I was glad they condemned mine, for I've put my old "cuckoo" through some awful tests and it's about ready to fall apart.
10147-8{_}1810{_}We expect to change soon and go up to a new offensive in F----.
10147-8{_}1811{_}If I get through that I'm going to change over to the American army.
10147-8{_}1812{_}They have offered me a commission and I think I'll take it.
10147-8{_}1813{_}My fingers are cramped and my feet have long since been numb.
10147-8{_}1814{_}Now I'm going to wrap up in my fur leathers and go to bed.
10147-8{_}1815{_}This is war.
10147-8{_}1816{_}FIGHTS WITH FLYING CIRCUS  Feb. 1, 1918.--Had a great time this last week, and made six long bombardments.
10147-8{_}1817{_}For the first three times we had no trouble getting across whatsoever.
10147-8{_}1818{_}Coming out the last three times we got some real competition.
10147-8{_}1819{_}It was in the form of the flying circus or "tangoes," which consists of fifteen of the best pilots in Germany, commanded by Baron von Richthofen, who seems a good sort, for when you fight him and you both miss he waves and we wave back.
10147-8{_}1820{_}We had been at it consistently for four days, and so they sent these birds down opposite us to stop us.
10147-8{_}1821{_}We had been in Germany for some distance and had reached our objective and bombed it.
10147-8{_}1822{_}There was a heavy fog below us, so I took a couple of turns to make sure we could see our objective.
10147-8{_}1823{_}We dropped our bombs and then I turned to the right to see the damage.
10147-8{_}1824{_}I had to take a large turn, for the "archies" were shooting pretty close.
10147-8{_}1825{_}I looked for my escadrille, and saw these machines way off in the distance.
10147-8{_}1826{_}I started for them and soon caught up with them.
10147-8{_}1827{_}Then I swerved and dipped up to them, for I thought them a little strange.
10147-8{_}1828{_}I got up closer, and, wow!
10147-8{_}1829{_}all three dived at me like a rock and bullets flew by me, cutting my plane, so I pulled up at them, fired, swerved so my gunner could let them have it also and then saw the iron cross flash by, so I knew it was the Huns.
10147-8{_}1830{_}I started getting altitude and went up high and then the boches got the sun between them and my plane and came again, but I thought this would happen and "peaked."
10147-8{_}1831{_}They went under me and that left me on top, so I gave them about 120 bullets, and one went for home.
10147-8{_}1832{_}The other two came by again and I went into a tight spiral so my gunner could pump at them--but nothing doing.
10147-8{_}1833{_}They beat it home and so did I, for it had been three to one.
10147-8{_}1834{_}When I landed I had five holes in my machine.
10147-8{_}1835{_}One of the wires had been shot away and gave me some trouble in landing.
10147-8{_}1836{_}Feb. 10, 1918.--We have been pretty busy and had some exciting times.
10147-8{_}1837{_}I almost got mine day before yesterday and feel pretty lucky to be here.
10147-8{_}1838{_}We started out on a long trip into Germany and all the way over we had no trouble at all.
10147-8{_}1839{_}After we bombed, my observer and I dived down on some villages and used our own guns on them.
10147-8{_}1840{_}We got so low that the anti-aircraft guns were popping too close, so we beat it.
10147-8{_}1841{_}We soon saw a bunch of hangars below us and we dived down on them and shot at them.
10147-8{_}1842{_}In a few minutes a bunch of Huns came up from the hangars after us and we beat it to catch up with the others.
10147-8{_}1843{_}We got up with them and looked behind us and there were a number of Germans sneaking down on us.
10147-8{_}1844{_}Then the battle commenced and for forty minutes we had a hot fight.
10147-8{_}1845{_}We picked off (censored) of them and they went plunging down in flames.
10147-8{_}1846{_}Then the others went back and we all returned safely, but I noticed that my machine worked queerly, and when I landed I had a hard time, and barely got to the ground without smashing to pieces.
10147-8{_}1847{_}I looked the machine over, and you should have seen it.
10147-8{_}1848{_}From top to bottom it was one mass of holes.
10147-8{_}1849{_}One bullet passed through my combination and hit a can of tobacco.
10147-8{_}1850{_}Another cut a main spar on one of my wings, and another hit my stabilizer, tearing it half in two.
10147-8{_}1851{_}One other hit my gas tank and put a hole clear through it.
10147-8{_}1852{_}Luckily my gas was low and it did not explode, but, believe me, I was lucky.
10147-8{_}1853{_}IN THE BIG GERMAN DRIVE  April 20, 1918.--The orderly has just tapped on my window to put down my shade, which means the Gothas are on their way.
10147-8{_}1854{_}The guns are starting.
10147-8{_}1855{_}This attack has been frightful--day after day long lines of ambulances roll by our camp carrying large numbers of wounded.
10147-8{_}1856{_}Tomorrow we shall continue our work of knocking down their batteries and bombing their railroads.
10147-8{_}1857{_}To-night, now, they are trying to get us.
10147-8{_}1858{_}I started on a "permission" about three weeks ago and had beautiful visions of peace and content for a week, but was called back immediately at the beginning of this horrible attack.
10147-8{_}1859{_}Things look bad, and in a few days we are moving farther up.
10147-8{_}1860{_}Our work here has been hard and exciting and always working in any kind of weather.
10147-8{_}1861{_}While our loss has been heavy we have accomplished wonders.
10147-8{_}1862{_}Going over on cloudy days when the heavy black clouds hang down to within fifty meters of the ground, spotting a group of trucks, a line of cars, or a battery of troops, then bombing them, shooting them up with your machine guns and shooting back up into the clouds midst a rain of luminous machine gun bullets from the ground is interesting work.
10147-8{_}1863{_}But the terror of those on the ground, poor devils!
10147-8{_}1864{_}Yet it's got to be brought home.
10147-8{_}1865{_}Out of twenty-four trips we lost eight machines.
10147-8{_}1866{_}Poor Chuck Kerwood was among them.
10147-8{_}1867{_}Chuck is an American boy from Philadelphia, and he has been with us for five months.
10147-8{_}1868{_}I had a chance to go back to the states as an instructor, and almost took it, but when the time came around to leave this band of men who have been in it for almost four years, I couldn't do it.
10147-8{_}1869{_}They are men, and have pulled me out of tight holes when I was green at this game, and they did it at the risk of their lives.
10147-8{_}1870{_}Now I've seen them drop off one at a time, fine young Frenchmen, and I guess the least I can do is to stay right by them and I feel my work is here.
10147-8{_}1871{_}In Hospital, May 3, 1918.--Well, here I am at last, but I fooled them for six months.
10147-8{_}1872{_}Finally one slipped up behind me.
10147-8{_}1873{_}I never saw him, but felt him.
10147-8{_}1874{_}Only got it in the leg, so it isn't very serious, except that the bullet was incendiary.
10147-8{_}1875{_}They have oodles of sulphur on them and I'm afraid of complications.
10147-8{_}1876{_}This is a nice hospital in a nice location; only thing that I hate about it is that I may not be able to get back to my escradrille for fifteen or twenty days.
10147-8{_}1877{_}SEVERE BOMBING BY GERMANS  May 16, 1918--Going to have another operation tomorrow and then I think I'll be well.
10147-8{_}1878{_}And, believe me, if I am I am going back and get somebody for this.
10147-8{_}1879{_}We are now on the Somme, near Rouen.
10147-8{_}1880{_}I suppose you know Baron von Richthofen has been brought down.
10147-8{_}1881{_}I'm sorry, for he was a game, clean scrapper, and I know, for I've had several brushes with him.
10147-8{_}1882{_}The Huns came over here last night and dropped sixty bombs, killing people and wounding I don't know how many.
10147-8{_}1883{_}Several of the bombs hit about 300 meters from here and our beds shook like the dickens.
10147-8{_}1884{_}COMMENTS ON HIS WAR CROSS  At the Front, June 14, 1918.--I've been back here from the hospital for several days and we are having beautiful weather, doing lots of work and losing lots of men, but getting results.
10147-8{_}1885{_}I think by now you have all my letters explaining the change into the American army and the croix de guerre, which doesn't signify a great deal.
10147-8{_}1886{_}Things look pretty bad now, but the French are holding strong with the constant arrival of Americans and I think the Hun advance is stopped.
10147-8{_}1887{_}We have been working at very low altitudes and while we have lost men heavily the work was extremely effective.
10147-8{_}1888{_}We have been shifted from one part of the front to another so that one hardly has time to unpack before we go to a new attack.
10147-8{_}1889{_}Our car has a broken piston, so we have had to walk more than usual and my leg gets so worn out in a short time that it is slow going.
10147-8{_}1890{_}GREAT FRENCH FLYER BRINGS DOWN  At the beginning of the year, Lieut.
10147-8{_}1891{_}Rene Fonck, the great French flyer and ace of aces of all the belligerent forces, had only nineteen successes to his credit, but during the last days of fighting the wily Lieutenant scored many victories bringing his totals up to seventy five enemy airplanes officially destroyed, with forty more probable successes awaiting official verification.
10147-8{_}1892{_}The final list of Lieut Fonck is all the more astonishing when it is considered that he made flights only when he thought himself in the fittest condition, and every time he flew he triumphed over the German Aviators.
10147-8{_}1893{_}His wonderful success is accredited to his incomparable tactics, keen eyesight and most remarkable skill.
10147-8{_}1894{_}OTHER CHAMPIONS OF THE AIR  Among other champion flyers of the allied forces Major Bishop of the British is credited with seventy-two victories; Lieutenant Coppens of Belgium, wounded during the late fighting, and with a leg amputated, holds the record of thirty-six victories; Lieutenant Baracchini the Italian flyer has thirty victories to his credit; Eddie Rickenbacker the American ace is responsible for twenty-four enemy victims, and Edward Parsons, another American flyer is credited with eight official victories and seven more unconfirmed.
10147-8{_}1895{_}Captain Kosakoff the Russian ace held seventeen successes to his credit at the close of Russias fighting.
10147-8{_}1896{_}ENEMY ACES ALSO SCORE  Lieutenant Udet of Germany is the ace of enemy aces and holds the record of sixty victories; Captain Brunmwsky of the Austrian forces is next with thirty-four to his credit; Sergeant Fiselier the German flyer serving for Bulgaria is credited with seven victims, and Captain Schults also a German serving for Turkey had eleven victories.
10147-8{_}1897{_}QUENTIN ROOSEVELT LOSES HIS LIFE  On Sunday July 14th, 1918, a violent encounter took place between German battleplanes and American Air forces trying to break through the German defense over the Marne.
10147-8{_}1898{_}In this engagement Lieut, Quentin Roosevelt was brought down and killed near Chambry, then behind the German lines.
10147-8{_}1899{_}He was buried with military honors by German airmen, at the spot where he fell.
10147-8{_}1900{_}His grave was located later by one of his fellow air scouts.
10147-8{_}1901{_}AMERICAN AVIATOR GETS IRON CROSS  One of the remarkable feats performed by Yankee air men, was that of Lieut.
10147-8{_}1902{_}Wm.
10147-8{_}1903{_}T. Webb Jr. of Buffalo, a member of an American squadron which encountered a German battleplane while flying over the German lines.
10147-8{_}1904{_}The American flyers surrounded the German Fokker like a flock of birds, and instead of shooting it down, which would have been easy, they maneuvered their planes so the boche machine was forced toward the American lines.
10147-8{_}1905{_}The German airmen fought desperately, but in vain, to break through, and was forced lower and lower to the ground.
10147-8{_}1906{_}Upon reaching the ground he refused to stop his motor until, after bumping over two fields, a bullet was fired through his gas tank setting it afire.
10147-8{_}1907{_}The two Germans jumped from the machine to the ground uninjured.
10147-8{_}1908{_}Both wore iron crosses.
10147-8{_}1909{_}Lieut.
10147-8{_}1910{_}Webb landed his machine, jumped out, grabbed an iron cross from one of the terrified Germans, and rose again to join his companions.
10147-8{_}1911{_}EYES OF THE ARMY ALWAYS OPEN  Few civilians have any idea of the intense, close watch that was kept upon the enemy throughout the struggle.
10147-8{_}1912{_}Soldiers on "listening post" would crawl out every night to and sometimes into the enemy lines and on their return report what they had heard.
10147-8{_}1913{_}By day, aviators came back from flights over enemy positions and gave details of what they had seen.
10147-8{_}1914{_}Every hill, tree-top, church spire, tall building and captive balloon watched every move of the enemy and reported it.
10147-8{_}1915{_}These reports by the ears and eyes of the armies enabled American and allied commanders to plan their infantry and artillery attacks.
10147-8{_}1916{_}AMERICAN INFORMATION SERVICE CHART  Knowledge of conditions in Germany during the war was so accurate that the American general staff had computed many weeks in advance almost the exact date on which the breaking point would be reached.
10147-8{_}1917{_}A chart in Secretary Baker's office shows the fluctuations in the "morale of the German nation" from August, 1914, to the month of November, 1918.
10147-8{_}1918{_}The chart shows how German morale fell and rose under the influence of the military situation, the results of the submarine campaign, the unanimity of purpose evidenced by the different groups in the reichstag, and the economic condition of the country.
10147-8{_}1919{_}So accurate was the information that the "morale line" reached the zero point between Nov. 10 and 15.
10147-8{_}1920{_}The chart indicates clearly that practically every major operation of the German military forces was inaugurated when the morale line showed dangerous slumps.
10147-8{_}1921{_}A big map in the war office locates not only every allied unit but the composition of the opposition forces, their commanders, and, in most cases, their headquarters.
10147-8{_}1922{_}Opposite each German army unit the map shows a list of the "used" and reserve organizations.
10147-8{_}1923{_}On Nov. 11, when the armistice was signed, long lists of divisions which had been entirely used up were noted, but the reserves had disappeared entirely, with the single exception of two fresh German divisions in Belgium.
10147-8{_}1924{_}CHAPTER VI.
10147-8{_}1925{_}CAUSES OF THE WAR  _National and Race Prejudices--The Triple Alliance--The Triple Entente--Teuton vs. Slav--Influence of Russian Diplomacy--Russia vs. Austria--Control of Balkan Seaports--England's Commercial Supremacy Challenged by Germany--Assassination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand of Austria by a Serb_.
10147-8{_}1926{_}Within the space of less than a week from August 1, 1914, five of the six "great powers" of Europe became involved in a war that quickly developed into the greatest and most sanguinary struggle of all time.
10147-8{_}1927{_}The European conflagration, long foreseen by statesmen and diplomats, and dreaded of all alike, had broken out.
10147-8{_}1928{_}Beginning with the thunder of Austrian guns at Belgrade, the reverberations of war were heard in every capital of the Old World.
10147-8{_}1929{_}Austria's declaration of war against Servia was followed by the alignment of Germany with its Teuton neighbor against the forces of Russia, France and England.
10147-8{_}1930{_}Italy alone, of the six great powers, declined to align itself with its formal allies and made a determined effort at the outset to maintain its neutrality.
10147-8{_}1931{_}Soon the highways of Europe resounded with the hoof-beats and the tramp of marching hosts, with the rattle of arms and the rumble of artillery.
10147-8{_}1932{_}Of such a war, once begun, no man could predict the end.
10147-8{_}1933{_}But the world realized that it was a catastrophe of unparalleled proportions, a failure of civilization in its stronghold, a disaster to humanity.
10147-8{_}1934{_}For more than forty years the great powers of Europe had been at peace with one another.
10147-8{_}1935{_}Though war had threatened now and then, diplomacy had avoided the actual outbreak.
10147-8{_}1936{_}But that the dreaded conflict was inevitable had long been recognized.
10147-8{_}1937{_}For its coming immense armaments had been prepared, until the burdens of taxation laid upon the people had become in themselves a source of danger.
10147-8{_}1938{_}But behind it all lay the sinister influence of the "junker" element of Germany--the military party, swollen with pride in the development of the German army by more than forty years of preparation for conflict, and the naval party, eager for "der Tag" which should bring a trial of the new German navy against the battle fleets of an enemy.
10147-8{_}1939{_}Fostering and encouraging these militaristic sentiments was the growing desire of Germany for "a place in the sun," which was translatable only as a desire for world domination.
10147-8{_}1940{_}Greater and wider markets for German commerce were urgently demanded, and visions of Germany as mistress of the seas, with a great colonial empire, and of the Kaiser as the undisputed military overlord of Europe, already filled and fired the Teuton imagination.
10147-8{_}1941{_}The political alignment of the great powers prior to the war was as follows: On the one side was the Triple Alliance, including Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy; while on the other was the Triple Entente, comprising Great Britain, France and Russia.
10147-8{_}1942{_}As the event proved, the uncertain element in this line-up was Italy, which had a real grievance against Austria in the latter's possession of the former Italian territory known as the Trentino, and which was not consulted by Germany and Austria prior to the outbreak of hostilities.
10147-8{_}1943{_}She therefore declined to enter the war as a member of the Triple Alliance, but was later found in the field against Austria, and thenceforth rendered powerful aid to the cause of "the Allies," as the members of the Triple Entente and their supporters soon came to be known.
10147-8{_}1944{_}It was in the Balkans, long regarded as the zone of danger to European peace, that the war-clouds gathered and darkened rapidly.
10147-8{_}1945{_}For generations Austria and Russia had struggled diplomatically for the control of Balkan seaports, with the Balkan states acting as buffers in the diplomatic strife.
10147-8{_}1946{_}Servia acted as a bar to Austria's commercial route to the √Ügean, by way of the Sanjak of Novi Bazar to Saloniki, while Russia was Servia's great ally and stood stoutly behind the little Slav kingdom in its opposition to Austrian aggression.
10147-8{_}1947{_}AMBITIONS OF SERVIA  Then came the recent Balkan Wars, and their outcome was viewed with alarm.
10147-8{_}1948{_}Austria uneasily watched the approach of Servia to the Adriatic and the Aegean.
10147-8{_}1949{_}The formation of the new new autonomous state of Albania, between Servia and the Adriatic, was all that prevented Austria from attacking Servia during that crisis.
10147-8{_}1950{_}The terms of peace left the situation, as it concerned Austria and Russia, practically as it had been.
10147-8{_}1951{_}Austria made no further progress toward the sea, and Russia remained the ally of Servia.
10147-8{_}1952{_}Bulgaria had failed in its efforts to reach Salonica.
10147-8{_}1953{_}At this stage another element exerted its influence.
10147-8{_}1954{_}Servia awoke to the possibility of a Greater Servia.
10147-8{_}1955{_}An Empire of the Slavs had long been dreamed of.
10147-8{_}1956{_}In Austria-Hungary itself millions of Slavs were dreaming of it and awaiting the disruption of Austria-Hungary, held together now, as they argue, only by the indomitable will of the old Emperor, Franz Joseph.
10147-8{_}1957{_}The hatred between the Slavs and the Teutonic Austrians is intense.
10147-8{_}1958{_}The annexation by Austria of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in which Servians predominate, increased the Servian hatred and the indignation of the whole Slav world to the point of violence.
10147-8{_}1959{_}A conflict was avoided with difficulty.
10147-8{_}1960{_}These principalities had hoped to form part of a Greater Servia.
10147-8{_}1961{_}Had not Russia been exhausted by the war with Japan, Servia would have called upon her ally and the crisis would have come then.
10147-8{_}1962{_}As it was, the Balkans teemed with plots and counterplots against the Austrians, culminating in the assassination of the Arch-Duke and heir-apparent to the Austrian throne, Francis Ferdinand, known for his anti-Slav principles, and therefore feared and hated as the king to be.
10147-8{_}1963{_}The assassination occurred at Serajevo in Bosnia, where Servian disaffection was seething.
10147-8{_}1964{_}Austria immediately laid the crime on the Servian government.
10147-8{_}1965{_}AUSTRIA DECLARES WAR  Failing in her peremptory demands for satisfaction, Austria declared war, July 28, 1914, apparently for revenge, but behind her righteous indignation she still held in view her traditional ambition, a port on the Mediterranean, to be secured by the complete control of the Novi Bazar route to Salonica, a route which, besides its commercial importance, is of tremendous strategic value to the nation which commands it.
10147-8{_}1966{_}The treaty of Berlin of 1878, after the Russo-Turkish War, had given Austria the military, political, and commercial control of the route within the Sanjak of Novi Bazar, then a part of Turkey.
10147-8{_}1967{_}But now, in the division of spoils following the Balkan Wars, Servia gained control of Novi Bazar, Pristina, Uskub, and Istip, or practically the entire route to a short distance north of Salonica, where the new boundaries of Greece had been extended.
10147-8{_}1968{_}This meant that Austria saw herself shut out from the Sanjak, and only by the destruction and subsequent occupation of Servia could Austria regain her ascendancy over the route.
10147-8{_}1969{_}Victory would mean a long step by Austria toward the sea.
10147-8{_}1970{_}PLOTS AND COUNTERPLOTS  The "balance of power" among European nations has hitherto been maintained because the formation of a single nation out of the Balkan States has not been possible.
10147-8{_}1971{_}Although the people of these states have similar pursuits, and live much alike in all regions, they have preserved their original racial differences.
10147-8{_}1972{_}A village of Albanians may be within a few miles of a village of Greeks.
10147-8{_}1973{_}Yet through centuries both have remained racially distinct.
10147-8{_}1974{_}Here and there the barriers have given way somewhat, but in general the races persist side by side, sometimes peaceably, more often in mutual distrust or open feud.
10147-8{_}1975{_}Such division has been fostered by the great nations, and new states have been created, as recently Albania, since the formation of a great state in the Balkans by the union of all or the absorbing greatness of one, would overthrow the balance of power, and besides interpose an insurmountable obstacle between Austria and Russia, and the sea.
10147-8{_}1976{_}Thus the states have been played against each other.
10147-8{_}1977{_}Sometimes the game has been one of diplomacy, or one of force, hurling the states at each other's throats.
10147-8{_}1978{_}HOW WAR WAS DECLARED    _Ultimatum, by Austria to Servia--War Declared by Austria--   Russia Mobilizes--Germany Declares War on Russia   August 1--France and England Involved--Germans   Enter Belgium--Scenes in European Capitals_.
10147-8{_}1979{_}On Sunday, June 28, 1914, a Servian student named Prinzep shot and killed the Archduke Francis Ferdinand, heir to the thrones of Austria-Hungary, and his morganatic wife, the Duchess of Hohenberg, in the streets of Serajevo, a town in Bosnia which the royal couple were visiting.
10147-8{_}1980{_}Nearly four weeks later, on July 23, the Austro-Hungarian government, fixing responsibility for the assassination upon Servian intrigues, presented to Servia a number of demands which formed a very drastic ultimatum, requiring compliance within forty-eight hours, with the alternative of war.
10147-8{_}1981{_}Servia was required to condemn "the propaganda directed against Austria" and to take proceedings against all accessories to the plot against the Archduke Francis Ferdinand who were in Servia.
10147-8{_}1982{_}Austrian delegates were to supervise the proceedings, and Servia was also to arrest certain Servian officials whose guilt was alleged.
10147-8{_}1983{_}These exorbitant conditions made it quite obvious that no concessions on Servians part would be accepted.
10147-8{_}1984{_}It was a plain prelude to war.
10147-8{_}1985{_}Nevertheless, a virtual acceptance by Servia followed.
10147-8{_}1986{_}Acting on the advice of Russia, Servia acceded to all that was required of her, making only two reservations of the most reasonable character.
10147-8{_}1987{_}These reservations were found enough to serve as an excuse for war.
10147-8{_}1988{_}Austria at once declared herself dissatisfied and though the actual declaration of war was delayed for a brief period, a state of war practically existed between the two countries from Saturday evening, July 25.
10147-8{_}1989{_}EFFORTS TO LOCALIZE THE WAR  Then began efforts on the part of Great Britain to localize the war.
10147-8{_}1990{_}Sir Edward Grey, the able foreign secretary in Mr. Asquith's cabinet, repeated solemn warnings in every chancellery of Europe.
10147-8{_}1991{_}According to the English "white book," the very day that he was notified of the violent tone of Austria's note to Servia--the day it was presented--he warned the Austrian Ambassador in London that if as many as four of the Great Powers of Europe were to engage in war, it would involve the expenditure of such a vast sum of money and such interference with trade, that a complete collapse of European credit and industry would follow.
10147-8{_}1992{_}The reply of Russia to this warning was quite conciliatory.
10147-8{_}1993{_}The Russian foreign minister, M. Sazonoff, assured the British minister that Russia had no aggressive intentions, and would take no action unless forced.
10147-8{_}1994{_}Austria's action, M. Sazonoff added, in reality aimed at over-throwing Russia's influence in the Balkans.
10147-8{_}1995{_}Thus, on Monday, July 27, Sir Edward Grey was able to state in the House of Commons that his suggestion of a joint conference, composed of the Ambassadors of Germany, France and Italy, and himself, with a view to mediation between Austria and Russia, had been accepted by all except Germany, which power had expressed its concurrence with the plan in principle, but opposed the details on the ground that there was a prospect of direct "conversations" (diplomatic exchanges) between Austria and Russia.
10147-8{_}1996{_}This statement was believed in England to lack sincerity.
10147-8{_}1997{_}On that Monday afternoon the Russian Ambassador at Vienna warned Austria that Russia would not give way and expressed his hope that some arrangement might be arrived at before Servia was invaded.
10147-8{_}1998{_}Austria's reply came next day in the shape of a formal declaration of war against Servia.
10147-8{_}1999{_}GERMANY'S ATTITUDE PRO-AUSTRIAN  On July 30 Sir M. de Bunsen, British Ambassador at Vienna, made the following statement to Sir Edward Grey regarding the attitude of Germany in the crisis: "Although I am not able to verify it, I have private information that the German Ambassador (at Vienna) knew the text of the Austrian ultimatum to Servia before it was dispatched, and telegraphed it to the German Emperor.
10147-8{_}2000{_}I know from the German Ambassador himself that he endorses every line of it."
10147-8{_}2001{_}Naturally enough the Russian foreign minister complained that "conversations" with Austria were useless in the face of such facts.
10147-8{_}2002{_}Russia then declared that her forces would be mobilized the day that Austria crossed the Servian frontier.
10147-8{_}2003{_}The attitude of Germany at once stiffened and it became evident that Germany meant to regard even the partial mobilization of Russia as a ground for war, not only against Russia, but also against the latter's ally, France.
10147-8{_}2004{_}In vain Russia protested that her partial mobilization was merely a precaution.
10147-8{_}2005{_}In vain did the Czar himself offer to give his word that no use would be made of any of his forces.
10147-8{_}2006{_}Germany was aware, as subsequent facts have proved, that her own state of mobilization was very much further advanced than that of Russia.
10147-8{_}2007{_}GERMAN ULTIMATUM TO RUSSIA  By Friday, July 31, Germany was ready for the fray and a final ultimatum to St. Petersburg was launched.
10147-8{_}2008{_}On the same day Russia declared war against Austria.
10147-8{_}2009{_}By six o'clock on Saturday evening, August 1, war between Germany and Russia began, when Germany dismissed the Russian Ambassador, and by Sunday morning Germany was invading France.
10147-8{_}2010{_}The next day, August 3, the German Ambassador left Paris and the French Ambassador at Berlin was ordered to demand his passports.
10147-8{_}2011{_}At this point Great Britain passed from the position of general peacemaker to that of a principal.
10147-8{_}2012{_}In the House of Commons on Monday, August 3, Sir Edward Grey stated that the question whether Austria or Russia should dominate the Southern Slav races was no concern of England, nor was she bound by any secret alliance to France.
10147-8{_}2013{_}She was absolutely free to choose her course with regard to the crisis which had overtaken her.
10147-8{_}2014{_}But there were two cardinal points in the situation which had arisen which ultimately concerned Great Britain.
10147-8{_}2015{_}The first essential feature of British diplomacy, said Sir Edward, was that France should not be brought into such a condition in Europe that she became a species of vassal state to Germany.
10147-8{_}2016{_}On the morning of July 31, therefore, he had informed the German Ambassador that if the efforts to maintain peace failed and France became involved Great Britain would be drawn into the conflict.
10147-8{_}2017{_}In his speech of August 3 the British foreign minister also stated that he had given France on the previous day the written assurance that if the German fleet came into the English Channel or through the North Sea to assail her, the British fleet would protect her to the uttermost.
10147-8{_}2018{_}TO PROTECT BELGIAN AUTONOMY  On the same afternoon, in the same place, Sir Edward Grey reiterated the other dominant principle of British foreign policy--that England can never look with indifference on the seizure by a great continental power of any portion of Belgium and Holland.
10147-8{_}2019{_}More than a hundred years ago it was declared by Napoleon, who was a master of political geography, that Antwerp was "a pistol leveled at the head of London."
10147-8{_}2020{_}When on July 31 the British foreign minister inquired by telegraph both at Paris and Berlin whether the two governments would engage to respect the neutrality of Belgium, France replied with an assurance that she was resolved to do so unless compelled to act otherwise by reason of the violation of Belgium's neutrality at the hands of another power.
10147-8{_}2021{_}The German secretary of state, Herr von Jagow, replied that he could give no such assurance until he had consulted the Emperor and Chancellor, and doubted whether he could give any answer without revealing the German plan of campaign.
10147-8{_}2022{_}He furthermore alleged the commission of hostile acts by Belgium.
10147-8{_}2023{_}Developments quickly followed.
10147-8{_}2024{_}The German government proposed that Belgium should grant its armies free passage through Belgian territory.
10147-8{_}2025{_}The proposal was accompanied by an intimation that Belgium would be crushed out of existence if it refused to comply.
10147-8{_}2026{_}In fact, it was an ultimatum presented at 7 o'clock on Sunday evening, August 2, to expire within twelve hours.
10147-8{_}2027{_}Then came Sir Edward Grey's speech in parliament on August 3, when it was fully realized that Germany and England were on the verge of war.
10147-8{_}2028{_}What followed was related in the House of Commons next day.
10147-8{_}2029{_}SCENES IN PARLIAMENT  Germany's reply to the speech by Sir Edward Grey, the British foreign secretary, indicating the attitude of Great Britain in regard to the contemplated violation of Belgian territory by Germany was a second ultimatum from Berlin to Brussels, saying Germany was prepared to carry through her plans by force of arms if necessary.
10147-8{_}2030{_}The British government was officially informed by Belgium on August that German troops had invaded Belgium and that the violation of that country's neutrality, which the British, foreign secretary had intimated must be followed by action on the part of the British, had become an accomplished fact.
10147-8{_}2031{_}Definite announcement of Great Britain's intentions under these circumstances was expected in the house of commons that afternoon.
10147-8{_}2032{_}TELEGRAM SENT TO BERLIN  On the assembly of the house the premier, Mr. Asquith, said that a telegram had been sent early in the morning to Sir Edward Goschen, British ambassador in Berlin, to the following effect:  "The king of the Belgians has appealed to His Britannic Majesty's government for diplomatic intervention on behalf of Belgium.
10147-8{_}2033{_}The British government is also informed that the German government has delivered to the Belgian government a note proposing friendly neutrality pending a free passage of German troops through Belgium and promising to maintain the independence and integrity of the kingdom and its possessions on the conclusion of peace, threatening in case of refusal to treat Belgium as an enemy."
10147-8{_}2034{_}Sir Edward Grey, the British foreign secretary, had requested an answer within twelve hours.
10147-8{_}2035{_}Premier Asquith then read a telegram from the German foreign minister, which the German ambassador in London had sent to Sir Edward Grey.
10147-8{_}2036{_}It was as follows:    "Please dispel any distrust that may subsist on the part   of the British government with regard to our intentions by   repeating most positively the formal assurance that even in   case of armed conflict with Belgium, Germany will under no   pretensions whatever annex Belgian territory."
10147-8{_}2037{_}The reading of this telegram was greeted with derisive laughter by the members of the house.
10147-8{_}2038{_}Premier Asquith continued:    "We understand that Belgium categorically refused to   assent to a flagrant violation of the law of nations.
10147-8{_}2039{_}"His majesty's government was bound to protest against   this violation of a treaty to which Germany was a party in   common with England and must request an assurance that   the demand made upon Belgium by Germany be not proceeded   with and that Belgium's neutrality be respected by Germany   and we have asked for an immediate reply.
10147-8{_}2040{_}"We received this morning from our minister in Brussels   the following telegram:    "'The German minister has this morning addressed a   note to the Belgian minister for foreign affairs stating that as   the Belgian government has declined a well intentioned proposal   submitted to it by the imperial German government   the latter, deeply to its regret, will be compelled to carry out,   if necessary by force of arms, the measures considered indispensable   in view of the French menace.'"
10147-8{_}2041{_}ENGLAND AND GERMANY AT WAR  By 11 o'clock that evening England and Germany were at war.
10147-8{_}2042{_}Their respective ambassadors were handed their passports and Great Britain braced herself for a conflict that was felt to threaten her very existence as a nation.
10147-8{_}2043{_}CHAPTER VII.
10147-8{_}2044{_}THE INVASION OF BELGIUM    _Belgians Rush to Defense of Their Frontier--Towns Bombarded   and Burned--Defense of Liege--Fall of Liege--  --Fall of Namur--Peasants and Townspeople Flee--   Destruction of Louvain_.
10147-8{_}2045{_}At 10 o'clock on the night of August 2 German troops crossed the Belgian frontier, coming from Aix-la-Chapelle, or Aachen, temporary headquarters of the general staff, and the bloody invasion of Belgium, involving the violation of its neutral treaty rights, began.
10147-8{_}2046{_}Simultaneously the German forces entered the independent duchy of Luxemburg to the south, en route to the French border, and also came in touch with French outposts in the provinces of Alsace and Lorraine.
10147-8{_}2047{_}The events that followed in Belgium furnished a genuine surprise to the world.
10147-8{_}2048{_}Instead of finding the Belgian people indifferent to the violation of their territory and the Belgian army only a slight obstacle in the road to Paris, as was probably expected by the German general staff, a most gallant and determined resistance was offered to the progress of the German hosts.
10147-8{_}2049{_}The army of the little State was quickly mobilized for defense and its operations, while ineffectual in stopping the Kaiser's irresistible force, delayed its advance for three invaluable weeks, giving time for the complete mobilization of the French and for the landing of a British expeditionary force to co-operate with the latter in resisting the German approach to Paris.
10147-8{_}2050{_}Just across the Belgian border lay the little towns of Vis√© and Verviers, and these were the first objects of German attack and Belgian defense.
10147-8{_}2051{_}Both were occupied after desperate resistance by the Belgians and Vis√© was partly demolished by fire in reprisal, it was claimed, for the firing by civilians on the German invaders.
10147-8{_}2052{_}The subsequent bombardment and burning of towns and villages by the Germans were explained in every case as measures of revenge for hostile acts on the part of non-combatants and intended to prevent their occurrence elsewhere by striking terror into the hearts of the Belgian populace.
10147-8{_}2053{_}Whatever the pretext or the excuse, the historical fact remains that the result of the German progress toward the Franco-Belgian frontier constituted a martyrdom for Belgium and gained for the plucky little kingdom the fullest sympathy of the civilized world.
10147-8{_}2054{_}[Illustration:--From the Literary Digest BELGIUM--THE FIRST BATTLEFIELD OF THE WAR  The map shows the more important railroad lines connecting the cities of Brussels, Antwerp and Namur and those of Northern France.
10147-8{_}2055{_}Paris is 200 miles by rail from Brussels and 190 from Namur.]
10147-8{_}2056{_}THE ATTACK ON LIEGE  The ancient city of Li√®ge was attacked by the German artillery on August 4.
10147-8{_}2057{_}The town itself was occupied, five days later, but the modern forts surrounding it continued for some time longer to hold out against the fierce German attack.
10147-8{_}2058{_}It became necessary to bring up the heaviest modern Krupp siege guns in order to reduce them.
10147-8{_}2059{_}Amidst all the plethora of events which crowded themselves into the first few days following the outbreak of the war, none was more remarkable than the Belgian stand at Li√®ge against the German advance.
10147-8{_}2060{_}The struggle round Li√®ge bids fair to become historic, and the garrisons of the Li√®ge forts when they looked out fearlessly from the banks of the Meuse on the vanguard of the German host, and took decision to block its further progress, proved their claim once again to Julius C√¶sar's description of their ancestors, "The Belgians are the bravest of the Gauls."
10147-8{_}2061{_}THE FALL OF LIEGE  News of the fall of Liege and the occupation of the city by German troops was received with great rejoicing in Berlin on August 8th.
10147-8{_}2062{_}Dispatches received at Amsterdam from the German capital said:  The news of the fall of Liege spread with lightning rapidity throughout Berlin and created boundless enthusiasm.
10147-8{_}2063{_}The Emperor sent an aide-de-camp to announce the capture of the city to crowds that assembled outside the palace.
10147-8{_}2064{_}Policemen on bicycles dashed along Unter den Linden proclaiming the joyful tidings.
10147-8{_}2065{_}Imperial Chancellor Bethmann-Hollweg drove to the castle to congratulate the Emperor on the victory and was enthusiastically cheered along the way.
10147-8{_}2066{_}PEASANTS AND TOWNSPEOPLE FLEE  Following the fall of Li√®ge came a number of sanguinary engagements in northern Belgium; the unopposed occupation of Brussels on August 20, and a four days' battle beginning on August 23, in which the Germans forced back the French and British allies to the line of Noyon-LaF√®re across the northern frontier of France.
10147-8{_}2067{_}In the northern engagements the Belgians gave a good account of themselves, but were everywhere forced to give way before the innumerable hosts of the Kaiser, though not without inflicting tremendous losses on the invaders.
10147-8{_}2068{_}The retirement of the civilian population before the advancing masses of the German army was a pathetic spectacle.
10147-8{_}2069{_}It was a flight in terror and distress.
10147-8{_}2070{_}On Tuesday, August 18, the German troops surged down upon Tirlemont, a town twenty miles southeast of Louvain, around which they had been massing for some days, presumably by rail and motor cars.
10147-8{_}2071{_}The stories which had reached the inhabitants of Tirlemont of the happenings at surrounding towns and villages had not added to their peace of mind, and soon the moment for flight arrived.
10147-8{_}2072{_}All kinds of civilians set out towards Brussels and Ghent for refuge.
10147-8{_}2073{_}At times the road was full of carts bearing entire families, with pots and pans swaying and banging against the sides as the vehicles bumped over the roadway.
10147-8{_}2074{_}The younger women, boys and menfolk who had been left in the towns and villages fled on foot.
10147-8{_}2075{_}Priests, officials and Red Cross helpers mingled with the crowd.
10147-8{_}2076{_}This stream of unfortunates uprooted from their homes was thus described by an eyewitness:    "These masses of broken-hearted people moved silently   along, many weeping, few talking.
10147-8{_}2077{_}With them they brought   a few of their possessions, as pathetically miscellaneous as   the effects one might seize in the panic haste of a hotel fire.
10147-8{_}2078{_}Ox wagons, bundles and babies on dog-drawn carts or on men's   backs, bicycles and handcarts laden with kitchen utensils, all   mingled with the human stream.
10147-8{_}2079{_}Here were to be seen sewing   machines, beds, bedding, food, and there a little girl or boy   with some toy clasped uncomprehendingly in a dirty hand;   they also knew that danger threatened and that they must   save what they held most dear.
10147-8{_}2080{_}And even among these unhappy   people there were some more unfortunate than the   others--men and women who had no bundle, children who   had no doll.
10147-8{_}2081{_}All the way to Louvain there flowed this human   stream of misery.
10147-8{_}2082{_}Back along the Tirlemont road rifle firing   could be heard and entrenchments were to be seen in the town   itself."
10147-8{_}2083{_}These scenes between Tirlemont and Louvain were typical of those on every road leading to the larger cities of Belgium as the inhabitants fled before the approach of the dreaded Uhlans.
10147-8{_}2084{_}FALL OF NAMUR  On the afternoon of Sunday, August 23, the fortress of Namur was evacuated by the Belgians, and the town was later occupied by the Germans.
10147-8{_}2085{_}The fortress was said to be as strong as Li√®ge and it owed its importance in the present war to the fact that it was the apex of the two French flanks.
10147-8{_}2086{_}One ran from Namur to Charleroi and the other by Givet to Mezieres.
10147-8{_}2087{_}Warned by their experiences at Li√®ge, the Germans made most determined efforts against Namur.
10147-8{_}2088{_}From the north, south and east they were able to bring up their big guns unhindered, and by assaults at Charleroi and Dinant they endeavored to break the sides of the French triangle.
10147-8{_}2089{_}Namur finally collapsed but clever strategy enabled the French to fall back upon their main lines.
10147-8{_}2090{_}The fall of Namur, nevertheless, was a decided blow to the allies.
10147-8{_}2091{_}This was admitted by the French minister of war, who said at midnight Monday, August 24, of the failure of the "Namur triangle":  "It is, of course, regrettable that owing to difficulties of execution which could not have been foreseen our plan of attack has not achieved its object.
10147-8{_}2092{_}Had it done so it would have shortened the war, but in any case our defense remains intact in the face of an already weakened enemy.
10147-8{_}2093{_}Our losses are severe.
10147-8{_}2094{_}It will be premature to estimate them or to estimate those of the German army, which, however, has suffered so severely as to be compelled to halt in its counterattack and establish itself in new positions."
10147-8{_}2095{_}The object of the French triangle, having its apex at Namur, was to break the German army in two.
10147-8{_}2096{_}The British troops, as related in another chapter, were cooperating with the French at Mons.
10147-8{_}2097{_}When the Belgians evacuated Namur the Germans had knocked to pieces three of the forts to the northeast of the town with howitzer fire.
10147-8{_}2098{_}Between these forts they advanced and bombarded the town, which was defended by the Belgian Fourth Division.
10147-8{_}2099{_}Namur was evacuated when the defenders found themselves unable to support a heavy artillery fire.
