10147-8{_}2100{_}The Germans attacked in a formation three ranks deep, the front rank lying down, the second kneeling, and the third standing.
10147-8{_}2101{_}They afforded a target which was fully used by the men behind the Belgian machine guns.
10147-8{_}2102{_}Some fifty or sixty howitzers were brought into action by the Germans, who concentrated several guns simultaneously on each fort and smothered it with fire.
10147-8{_}2103{_}DESTRUCTION OF LOUVAIN  At this stage of the war in Belgium an event occurred that riveted universal attention upon the German operations.
10147-8{_}2104{_}On Tuesday, August 25, the beautiful, historic, scholastic city of Louvain, containing 42, inhabitants, was bombarded by the Germans and later put to the torch.
10147-8{_}2105{_}The fire, which burned for several days, devastated the city.
10147-8{_}2106{_}Many artistic and historical treasures, including the priceless library of Louvain University and several magnificent churches, centuries old, were totally destroyed.
10147-8{_}2107{_}Only the Hotel de Ville (City Hall), one of the finest examples of Gothic architecture in Europe, was spared and left standing in the midst of ruins.
10147-8{_}2108{_}The Rotterdam Telegraf, a neutral newspaper, declared that in the devastation of Louvain "a wound that can never be healed" was inflicted "on the whole of civilized humanity."
10147-8{_}2109{_}Frank Jewett Mather, the well-known American art critic, bitterly denounced the act as one of wanton destruction, saying that Louvain "contained more beautiful works of art than the Prussian nation has produced in its entire history."
10147-8{_}2110{_}Thus when the first month of war ended, the Germans had made good with their plan of seizing Belgium as a base of operations against France and had arrived in full force at the first line of French defenses, well on the way to the coveted goal, Paris.
10147-8{_}2111{_}But poor little Belgium, the "cockpit of Europe," ran red with blood.
10147-8{_}2112{_}SURRENDER OP BRUSSELS  _Belgian Capital Occupied by the Germans Without Bloodshed--Important Part Played by American Minister Brand Whittock---Belgian Forces Retreat to Antwerp--Dinant and Termonde Fall_.
10147-8{_}2113{_}After the usual reconnaissances by Uhlans and motorcycle scouts, the van of the German army arrived at Brussels, the capital city of Belgium, on August 20.
10147-8{_}2114{_}The seat of government had been removed three days before to Antwerp.
10147-8{_}2115{_}The French and Russian ministers also moved to Antwerp, leaving the affairs of their respective countries in the hands of the Spanish legation.
10147-8{_}2116{_}Brand Whitlock, United States minister to Belgium, remained at Brussels and played an important part in negotiations which led to the unresisted occupation and march through the city by the Germans in force on August 21 and the consequent escape of Brussels from bombardment and probable ruin.
10147-8{_}2117{_}At the approach of the German army the inhabitants of the capital were stricken with fear of the outcome.
10147-8{_}2118{_}When the Belgian civic guards and refugees began pouring into the city from the direction of Louvain, they brought stories of unspeakable German atrocities, maltreatment of old men and children, and the violation of women.
10147-8{_}2119{_}"The Belgian capital reeled with apprehension," said an American resident.
10147-8{_}2120{_}"Within an hour the gaiety, the vivacity, and brilliancy of the city went out like a broken arclight.
10147-8{_}2121{_}The radiance of the cafes was exchanged for darkness; whispering groups of residents broke up hurriedly and locked themselves into their homes, where they put up the shutters and drew in their tricolored Belgian flags.
10147-8{_}2122{_}"The historic Belgian city went through a state of morbid consternation, remarkably like that from which it suffered on June 18,1815, when it trembled with the fear of a French victory at Waterloo.
10147-8{_}2123{_}"In less than twenty-four hours the Belgian citizens were chatting comfortably with the German invaders and the allegations of German brutality and demoniacal torture dissolved into one of the myths which have accompanied all wars.
10147-8{_}2124{_}"Neither in Brussels nor in its environs was a single offensive act, so far as I know, committed by a German soldier.
10147-8{_}2125{_}In a city of over half a million people, invaded by a hostile army of perhaps a quarter of a million soldiers, no act, sufficiently flagrant to demand punishment or to awaken protest came to my attention."
10147-8{_}2126{_}SURRENDER OF CITY DEMANDED  Prior to the occupation the German commander had sent forward a flag of truce demanding the surrender of the city.
10147-8{_}2127{_}This was at midnight of Wednesday, August 19.
10147-8{_}2128{_}The Belgian commandant replied that he was bound in honor to defend the town.
10147-8{_}2129{_}Brand Whitlock, the United States minister, then came to the fore.
10147-8{_}2130{_}He recommended to the commandant and to Burgomaster Max the unconditional surrender of the city, pointing out how resistance might bring increased misfortune on the citizens.
10147-8{_}2131{_}But the military commander remained adamant until orders arrived from King Albert consenting to the surrender of the city.
10147-8{_}2132{_}Mr. Whitlock was later congratulated officially by the king for his action.
10147-8{_}2133{_}Undoubtedly he had a great deal to do with saving Brussels.
10147-8{_}2134{_}HISTORIC TREASURES OF BRUSSELS  The city of Brussels, thus occupied by the Germans, contains art treasures that are priceless.
10147-8{_}2135{_}The museum and public galleries are filled with masterpieces of the Flemish and old Dutch school, while the royal library comprises 600,000 volumes, 100,000 manuscripts and 50,000 rare coins.
10147-8{_}2136{_}Unquestionably the Brussels Museum is one of the most complete on the Continent.
10147-8{_}2137{_}A prominent historic landmark of Brussels is the King's House (also called the Dreadhouse), an ancient structure, recently renovated.
10147-8{_}2138{_}Within its walls both the Counts Egmont and Hoorn spent the last night before their execution, in 1567, by the hirelings of the Duke of Alva, the Spanish Philip II's tyrannical governor of the Netherlands, who, by means of the sword and the Inquisition, sought to establish the Catholic religion in those countries.
10147-8{_}2139{_}Brussels boasts another historic relic known the world over--the equestrian statue of Godfrey of Bouillon, who led the Crusaders to the Holy Land.
10147-8{_}2140{_}It stands upon the Place Royale, and was unveiled in 1848.
10147-8{_}2141{_}The magnificent Town Hall of Brussels would probably have suffered destruction, together with the city's other beautiful buildings, had not the government yielded without a struggle.
10147-8{_}2142{_}HEAVY WAR TAX LEVIED  General von der Goltz, appointed by the Kaiser military governor of Belgium, levied a war tax of $40,000,000 on the capture of the capital.
10147-8{_}2143{_}Other cities occupied by the Germans were also assessed for large sums, which in several instances had to be paid immediately on pain of bombardment.
10147-8{_}2144{_}It was announced September 1 that the four richest men in Belgium had guaranteed the payment to Germany of the war tax.
10147-8{_}2145{_}The four men were Ernest Solvay, the alkali king; Baron Lambert, the Belgian representative of the Rothschilds; Raoul Warocque, the mine owner, and Baron Empain, the railway magnate.
10147-8{_}2146{_}BELGIANS RETREAT TO ANTWERP  After the German occupation almost normal conditions were soon restored in Brussels, so far as civic life was concerned.
10147-8{_}2147{_}It was speedily announced that the Germans intended to regard the whole of Belgium as a German province and to administer it as such, at least during the continuance of the war.
10147-8{_}2148{_}The Belgian army retired to the north within the fortifications of Antwerp, where they were joined by French troops, but desultory fighting against the German invader continued at many points and the Franco-British allies soon came into contact with the advancing German army.
10147-8{_}2149{_}THE CITY AND PORT OF ANTWERP  Antwerp is one of the largest, most modernly equipped and efficient ports in Europe.
10147-8{_}2150{_}It is only a short distance across the English Channel, and is the head of 1,200 miles of canals in Belgium which connect with the canal systems of Holland, France and Germany.
10147-8{_}2151{_}On the harbor alone over $100,000,000 has been spent and extensions are in progress which will cost $15,000,000 more.
10147-8{_}2152{_}For the prosperity of Belgium, Antwerp is many times more important than Brussels, the capital.
10147-8{_}2153{_}While the country has an enormous amount of coal and many factories and other industries, these would be of little value without the imports which enter through Antwerp.
10147-8{_}2154{_}The city has about 360,000 inhabitants.
10147-8{_}2155{_}Although located fifty-three miles inland on the Scheldt River, it has natural advantages for harbor purposes which have been recognized since the seventh century.
10147-8{_}2156{_}Napoleon looked over the spot and started large harbor construction.
10147-8{_}2157{_}[Illustration: ANTWERP AND ITS FORTIFICATIONS]  Ever since that time, according to popular belief, Antwerp has encouraged commerce.
10147-8{_}2158{_}Over eighty different steamboat lines use the docks and quays.
10147-8{_}2159{_}The passenger lines include boats to New York and Boston, New Orleans, London, Liverpool, Manchester, Grimsby, South American ports, Cuba, the Congo, East and South Africa and the far East.
10147-8{_}2160{_}In 1912 a total of 6,973 ocean-going vessels entered the port, and 41,000 other vessels.
10147-8{_}2161{_}Antwerp in 1870 ranked fifth in the ports of the world.
10147-8{_}2162{_}Today it is believed to be second or third.
10147-8{_}2163{_}Ten years ago the freight received from the inland was principally by the canals.
10147-8{_}2164{_}Approximately 2,300,000 tons were received by rail and 5,500,000 tons by canal boats.
10147-8{_}2165{_}This ratio has not been maintained, but the canal traffic now is much larger than the rail tonnage.
10147-8{_}2166{_}This gives an idea of the extensive use to which the European countries put their canals, and the reader may guess the value of the city at the head of the canal system to the Germans.
10147-8{_}2167{_}BLOODLESS CAPITULATION OF GHENT  Historic Ghent, with its quarter of a million inhabitants, was also surrendered peaceably to the Germans, and again the energy and initiative of an American, United States Vice-Consul J.
10147-8{_}2168{_}A.
10147-8{_}2169{_}Van Hee, had much to do with the avoidance of tragedy and destruction.
10147-8{_}2170{_}Learning that the advance guard of the German army was only a few miles outside the city, the burgomaster went out on the morning of September to parley with Gen. von Boehn--in the hope of arranging for the German forces not to enter.
10147-8{_}2171{_}An agreement finally was reached whereby the Germans should go around Ghent on condition that all Belgian troops should evacuate the city, the civic guard be disarmed, their weapons surrendered, and the municipal authorities should supply the Germans with specified quantities of provisions and other supplies.
10147-8{_}2172{_}The burgomaster was not back an hour when a motor car driven by two armed German soldiers appeared in the streets.
10147-8{_}2173{_}At almost the same moment that the German car entered the city from the south a Belgian armored car, armed with a machine gun, with a crew of three men, entered from the east on a scouting expedition.
10147-8{_}2174{_}The two cars, both speeding, encountered each other at the head of the Rue Agneau, directly in front of the American consulate.
10147-8{_}2175{_}Vice-consul Van Hee, standing in the doorway, was an eyewitness to what followed.
10147-8{_}2176{_}The Germans, taken completely by surprise at the sight of the foe's grim war car in its coat of elephant gray, bearing down upon them, attempted to escape, firing with their carbines as they fled.
10147-8{_}2177{_}Notwithstanding the fact that the sidewalks were lined with onlookers, the Belgians opened on the fleeing Germans with their machine guns, which spurted lead as a garden hose spurts water.
10147-8{_}2178{_}The driver, fearing the Germans might escape, swerved his powerful car against the German motor precisely as a polo player "rides off" his opponent.
10147-8{_}2179{_}The machine gun never ceased its angry snarl.
10147-8{_}2180{_}The Germans surrendered, both being wounded.
10147-8{_}2181{_}Appreciating that Ghent stood in imminent danger of meeting the terrible fate of its sister cities, Aerschot and Louvain, sacked and burned for far less cause, Mr. Van Hee hurriedly found the burgomaster and urged him to go along instantly to German headquarters.
10147-8{_}2182{_}They found General von Boehn and his staff at a chateau a few miles outside the city.
10147-8{_}2183{_}The German commander at first was furious with anger and threatened Ghent with the same punishment he had meted out to the other places where Germans were fired on.
10147-8{_}2184{_}Van Hee took a very firm stand, however.
10147-8{_}2185{_}He told the general the burning of Ghent would do more than anything else to lose the Germans all American sympathy.
10147-8{_}2186{_}He reminded him that Americans have a great sentimental interest in Ghent because the treaty of peace between England and the United States was signed there just a century ago.
10147-8{_}2187{_}The general finally said: "If you will give me your word that there will be no further attacks upon Germans in Ghent, and that the wounded soldiers will be taken under American protection and returned to Brussels by the consular authorities when they have recovered, I will agree to spare Ghent and will not even demand a money indemnity."
10147-8{_}2188{_}The news that Mr. Van Hee had succeeded in his mission spread through the city like fire in dry grass and when he returned he was acclaimed by cheering crowds as the saviour of Ghent.
10147-8{_}2189{_}THE BURGOMASTER'S APPEAL  Blazoned on the front of the Town Hall suddenly appeared a great black-lettered document.
10147-8{_}2190{_}It was a manly and inspiring proclamation by the burgomaster, similar to the splendid proclamation issued by M. Adolphe Max, burgomaster of Brussels, just before the German entry.
10147-8{_}2191{_}He assured the inhabitants that he and all the town officials were remaining in their places, and that so long as life and liberty remained to him he would do all in his power to protect their honor and their interests.
10147-8{_}2192{_}He reminded them that under the laws of war they had the right to refuse all information and help to the invaders; and called upon each citizen, or his wife, to refuse such information and help.
10147-8{_}2193{_}Finally, he urged the citizens to remain calm, and stay in their homes.
10147-8{_}2194{_}"Vive la Belgique!
10147-8{_}2195{_}Vive Ghent!"
10147-8{_}2196{_}The proclamation ended in great capitals with this patriotic cry.
10147-8{_}2197{_}DINANT AND TERMONDE FALL  But other cities and towns of Belgium were not as fortunate as Brussels and Ghent in escaping damage and destruction.
10147-8{_}2198{_}Dinant, a town of 8,000 inhabitants, fifteen miles south of Namur, and dating back to the sixth century, was partially destroyed by the Germans in their advance on September 3 and 4.
10147-8{_}2199{_}Early reports stated that a number of the most prominent citizens had been executed, including Mr. Humbert, owner of a large factory, who was slain in the presence of his wife and children.
10147-8{_}2200{_}The Germans alleged that citizens had fired on them from the heights about the city.
10147-8{_}2201{_}They then drove all of the inhabitants out, shot some of the men as examples, took the gold from the branch of the National Bank and burned the business section.
10147-8{_}2202{_}On September 4 the town of Termonde met a similar fate.
10147-8{_}2203{_}This town, 16 miles from Ghent, was fired in several places before the Kaiser's troops passed on.
10147-8{_}2204{_}They also blew up a bridge over the River Escaut to the north, seeming to renounce for the moment their intrusion into the country of the Waes district.
10147-8{_}2205{_}Afterward they directed an attack against the southwest front position of the Antwerp army and were repulsed with great losses.
10147-8{_}2206{_}Describing the burning of Termonde by the Germans, a Ghent correspondent said:  "By midday Sunday the blaze had assumed gigantic proportions and by Sunday evening not a house stood upright.
10147-8{_}2207{_}This was verified at Zele, where there were thousands of refugees from Termonde.
10147-8{_}2208{_}The Germans also pillaged Zele.
10147-8{_}2209{_}The suburb of St. Giles also suffered from bombardment and fire."
10147-8{_}2210{_}A courier who knew Termonde as a flourishing town with fine shops, an ancient town hall of singular beauty and a number of churches of historic interest, found the place on September 11 a smoldering ruin, except for the town hall and one church, on a stone of which he saw the inscription "1311."
10147-8{_}2211{_}These two structures were left intact, without so much as a broken window.
10147-8{_}2212{_}Termonde was burned for much the same reason as Louvain.
10147-8{_}2213{_}On September 4 a German force came back from the field after having been severely handled by the Belgians, and the German commander, it is said, exclaimed:  "It is our duty to burn them down!"
10147-8{_}2214{_}The inhabitants were given two hours' grace, and German soldiers filed through the town, breaking windows with their rifles.
10147-8{_}2215{_}They were followed by other files of troops, who sprayed kerosene into the houses, others applied lighted fuses and the town was systematically destroyed.
10147-8{_}2216{_}BOMBARDMENT OF MALINES  On Thursday night, August 27, the German artillery bombarded the ancient Belgian town of Malines.
10147-8{_}2217{_}During the bombardment many of the monuments in the town were hit by shells and destroyed.
10147-8{_}2218{_}When the artillery had ceased firing the inhabitants of Malines were advised to leave the town.
10147-8{_}2219{_}CHAPTER VIII BRITAIN RAISES AN ARMY  _Earl Kitchener Appointed Secretary for War--A New Volunteer Army--Expeditionary Force Landed in France--Marshal Sir John French in Command--Colonies Rally to Britain's Aid--The Canadian Contingent--Indian Troops Called For--Native Princes Offer Aid_.
10147-8{_}2220{_}After the declaration of war by Great Britain against Germany on August 4, the first important development in England was the appointment of Earl Kitchener of Khartoum as secretary of state for war.
10147-8{_}2221{_}This portfolio had been previously held by the Rt.
10147-8{_}2222{_}Hon.
10147-8{_}2223{_}H.H.
10147-8{_}2224{_}Asquith, premier and first lord of the treasury.
10147-8{_}2225{_}Lord Kitchener being the idol of the British army and most highly esteemed by the nation generally for his powers of organization and administration, as well as for his military fame, the appointment increased the confidence of the British people in the Liberal Government and awakened their enthusiasm for war.
10147-8{_}2226{_}Parliament unanimously passed a vote of credit for $500,000,000 on August 6.
10147-8{_}2227{_}Lord Kitchener immediately realized the serious nature of the task confronting his country as an ally of France against the military power of Germany.
10147-8{_}2228{_}His first step was to increase the regular army.
10147-8{_}2229{_}The first call was for 100,000 additional men.
10147-8{_}2230{_}This was soon increased to 500,000.
10147-8{_}2231{_}Within a month there were 439,000 voluntary enlistments and then a further call was made for 500,000 more, bringing the strength of the British army up to 1,854,000 men, a figure unprecedented for Great Britain.
10147-8{_}2232{_}The war fever grew apace in England.
10147-8{_}2233{_}All classes of society furnished their quota to the colors for service in Belgium and France.
10147-8{_}2234{_}The period of enlistment was "for the war" and a wave of patriotic fervor swept over the British Isles and over all the colonies of Britain beyond the seas.
10147-8{_}2235{_}Political differences were forgotten and the empire presented a united front, as never before.
10147-8{_}2236{_}If Germany had counted on internal dissension keeping England out of the fray, the expectation proved unfounded.
10147-8{_}2237{_}Englishmen, Irishmen and Scotsmen stood shoulder to shoulder.
10147-8{_}2238{_}The Irish Home Rule controversy was dropped by common consent.
10147-8{_}2239{_}The men of Ulster and the Irish Nationalists struck hands and agreed to forget their differences in the presence of national danger.
10147-8{_}2240{_}Trade resumed normal conditions and the Bank of England rate, which earlier in the week had mounted to 10 per cent, was reduced on August to 5 per cent.
10147-8{_}2241{_}There were some panicky conditions and a disquieting collapse on the London Stock Exchange during the last days of feverish diplomacy, and it was due to the financial solidity of the British nation, no less than to its level-headedness and the promptness of government measures, that the declaration of war, instead of precipitating worse conditions, cleared the atmosphere.
10147-8{_}2242{_}BRITISH TROOPS LAND IN FRANCE  While the British army was being mobilized, the utmost secrecy was observed regarding all movements of troops.
10147-8{_}2243{_}The newspapers refrained from publishing even the little they knew and an expeditionary force, composed of the flower of the British army and numbering approximately 94,000 men of all arms of the service, was assembled, transported across the English Channel and landed at Boulogne and other French ports behind a veil of deepest mystery, so far as the British public and the world at large were concerned.
10147-8{_}2244{_}The old town of Plymouth, on the Channel, was the chief port of embarkation for the troops and the main concentration point in England, but troops embarked also at Dublin, Ireland; Liverpool; Eastbourne; Southampton, and other cities.
10147-8{_}2245{_}Not a mention of the midnight sailings of transports carrying troops, horses, automobiles, artillery, hospital and commissary equipment and supplies was allowed to be printed in the newspapers, nor was it known how many troops were being sent across the Channel.
10147-8{_}2246{_}The landing in France was effected between the 10th and the 20th of August without the loss of a single man, and on the 23d, having joined forces with the French army under General Joffre, commander-in-chief, the British found themselves in touch with the German enemy at Mons in Belgium.
10147-8{_}2247{_}FIELD-MARSHAL FRENCH IN COMMAND  The expeditionary force was in supreme command of Field Marshal Sir John D. P. French, a veteran officer of high military repute, with Maj.-Gen. Sir A. Murray as chief of staff.
10147-8{_}2248{_}Other noted officers were Lieut.-Gen. Sir Douglas Haig, commander of the First Corps; Lieut.-Gen. Sir James Grierson, commander of the Second Corps; Maj.-Gen. W. P. Pulteney, commander of the Third Corps, and Maj.-Gen. Edmund Allenby, in command of the Cavalry Division.
10147-8{_}2249{_}The home army was left in command of Gen. Sir Ian Hamilton.
10147-8{_}2250{_}Hardly had the expedition landed in France when the death was reported of the commander of the Second Corps, Sir James Grierson, who succumbed to heart disease while on his way to the front, dropping dead on a train.
10147-8{_}2251{_}He was given a notable military funeral in London.
10147-8{_}2252{_}Gen. Sir H. L. Smith-Dorrien was appointed to succeed him in command of the Second Corps.
10147-8{_}2253{_}The British troops were received in France with loud acclaim and Field Marshal French, on visiting Paris for a conference at the French war office before proceeding to the front, was greeted by a popular demonstration that showed how welcome British aid was to the French in their critical hour.
10147-8{_}2254{_}The British field force was composed of three army corps, each comprising two divisions, and there was also an extra cavalry division.
10147-8{_}2255{_}Each army corps consists of twenty-four infantry battalions of about one thousand men each on a war footing; six cavalry regiments, eight batteries of horse artillery of six guns each, eighteen batteries of field artillery, two howitzer batteries, and troops of engineers, signal corps, army service corps and other details.
10147-8{_}2256{_}Thus the first British field force landed in France aggregated about 94,000 men, including the extra Cavalry division.
10147-8{_}2257{_}These were added to almost daily during the following weeks, until by September 20 the British had probably 200,000 men co-operating with the French army north and east of Paris.
10147-8{_}2258{_}COLONIES RALLY TO BRITAIN  At the prospect of war with Germany the dominions of the British Empire overseas eagerly offered their aid.
10147-8{_}2259{_}Canada, Australia, New Zealand, India, all came forward with offers of men, money, ships and supplies.
10147-8{_}2260{_}The Australian premier issued a statement to the people in which he said: "We owe it to those who have gone before to preserve the great fabric of British freedom and hand it on to our children.
10147-8{_}2261{_}Our duty is quite clear.
10147-8{_}2262{_}Remember we are Britons."
10147-8{_}2263{_}CANADA OFFERS MEN  A formal offer of military contingents was cabled to England by the Canadian government August 1.
10147-8{_}2264{_}A meeting of the cabinet was presided over by Premier Borden.
10147-8{_}2265{_}It was called to deal with the situation in which Canada found herself as the result of the European war.
10147-8{_}2266{_}The government unanimously decided to make England an offer of men.
10147-8{_}2267{_}Infantry, cavalry and artillery would be included in any force sent forward and it would number 20,000 men if transportation could be obtained for that number.
10147-8{_}2268{_}It was estimated that within two weeks it would be possible to dispatch 10,000 efficient soldiers, and within three months this number could be increased to 50,000.
10147-8{_}2269{_}Many offers for foreign service arrived from the commandants of militia corps throughout the dominion.
10147-8{_}2270{_}In all 40,000 Canadian troops were tendered to and accepted by the British Government in the early days of the war; also 20,000 men from Australia and 8,000 from New Zealand, a total of 68,000 men.
10147-8{_}2271{_}By the request of the Dominions in each case, the cost of the equipment, maintenance and pay of the forces was defrayed by the three governments--in itself a generous and patriotic additional offer.
10147-8{_}2272{_}The Dominions at the same time declared their readiness to send additional contingents if required, as well as drafts from time to time to maintain their field forces at full strength.
10147-8{_}2273{_}TROOPSHIPS SAIL UNDER CONVOY  The first intimation that Canadian troops had been dispatched to the front from Valcartier Camp came on September 24, when the Hon.
10147-8{_}2274{_}T. W. Crothers, the Dominion minister of labor, announced in a speech before the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress, assembled in convention at St. John, New Brunswick, that 32,000 Canadian volunteers "left for the front a day or two ago."
10147-8{_}2275{_}It was understood that the troops had sailed from Quebec in twenty armed transports, convoyed by a fleet of British warships, which had been collected at convenient ports for the purpose.
10147-8{_}2276{_}There were two army divisions in the force that sailed, each comprising three brigades of infantry (12,000 men), 27 guns, 500 cavalry, and 2, staff, signallers, medical corps and supermimaries.
10147-8{_}2277{_}THE FINAL REVIEW AT VALCARTIER  Before they sailed away the Canadian army marched past the reviewing stand at the Valcartier Camp, Quebec, under the eyes of 10, civilians.
10147-8{_}2278{_}There were 32,000 soldiers equipped for active service and everyone was impressed with the serious scene.
10147-8{_}2279{_}The Duke and Duchess of Connaught, the Princess Patricia, Col. Sam Hughes, the Canadian minister of militia, and Col. V. H. C. Williams, commandant of the camp, looked on with pride as the great parade, almost a full army corps, passed the royal standard.
10147-8{_}2280{_}They marched in column of half battalions, and took a full hour to go by.
10147-8{_}2281{_}Officers commanding the four infantry brigades: Lieut.-Col. R.E.W.
10147-8{_}2282{_}Turner, V.C., D.S.O., of Quebec, a veteran of the South African war, mentioned in dispatches for especially gallant service; Lieut.-Col. S.M.
10147-8{_}2283{_}Mercer, Toronto, Commanding Officer of the Queen's Own Rifles; Lieut.-Col. A.W.
10147-8{_}2284{_}Currie of Victoria, Commanding Officer of the 50th Fusiliers; Lieut.-Col. J.E.
10147-8{_}2285{_}Cohoe of St. Catharines, Commanding Officer of the 5th Militia Infantry Brigade.
10147-8{_}2286{_}The officer appointed to command the artillery brigade was Lieut.-Col. H.E.
10147-8{_}2287{_}Burstall of Quebec, of the Artillery Headquarters Staff.
10147-8{_}2288{_}Officer in command of the Strathcona Horse, Lieut.-Col. A.C. Macdonnell, D.S.O., of Winnipeg, a South African veteran.
10147-8{_}2289{_}Officer in command of the Royal Canadian Dragoons, Lieut-Col. C.M.
10147-8{_}2290{_}Nelles of Toronto, Inspector of Cavalry for Militia Headquarters.
10147-8{_}2291{_}The commanding officer of the whole army division was an English general selected by the British War Office.
10147-8{_}2292{_}It was understood that the Canadian troops would land in the south of England and march through London to training quarters at Aldershot and Salisbury Plains, the infantry going to Aldershot and the artillery to Salisbury Plains, for several weeks' training under active service conditions before going to the firing line.
10147-8{_}2293{_}CANADA FIGHTS AGAINST AUTOCRACY  "Canada will spend its last dollar and shed its last drop of blood fighting for the principle of democracy, against that of autocracy, as exemplified in the present European conflict."
10147-8{_}2294{_}This was the emphatic statement made by Sir Douglas Cameron, lieutenant-governor--chief executive--of the province of Manitoba, passing through Chicago on September 28.
10147-8{_}2295{_}"Great Britain is not fighting for empire," he said.
10147-8{_}2296{_}"It is not fighting for greater commercial gains.
10147-8{_}2297{_}We are fighting for the annihilation of autocracy and it is the sentiment of the people of Canada that they will fight against Germany's domination to the bitter end.
10147-8{_}2298{_}"England does not want more commerce, except as it can be gained through the paths of peace.
10147-8{_}2299{_}We would not draw the sword to increase it, but we will fight to the last drop of blood to protect it.
10147-8{_}2300{_}"The men of Canada have responded nobly to the call to arms.
10147-8{_}2301{_}We have sent about 31,800 provincial troops, every one a volunteer, and we have that many more already enlisted if they are needed.
10147-8{_}2302{_}Our trouble is to equip them as fast as they enlist.
10147-8{_}2303{_}"In Canada we are turning our attention to agricultural pursuits.
10147-8{_}2304{_}Wheat is at a premium; a farmer can get from $1 to $1.10 per bushel in cash for wheat on his wagon.
10147-8{_}2305{_}All Europe will be in dire need of foodstuffs next year and for some years to come and we in Canada hope to profit by the opportunity.
10147-8{_}2306{_}"Economic conditions in the dominion received a terrible blow when the war came; we were shocked, staggered, and business has received a hard setback; finances are depressed.
10147-8{_}2307{_}The government has offered help to the banks, but they do not need it yet.
10147-8{_}2308{_}"We want immigrants in our country--Germans or any other good, strong, virile nationality.
10147-8{_}2309{_}We have no quarrel with the German people.
10147-8{_}2310{_}We like them; they are used to a high standard of living and are the finest kind of citizens.
10147-8{_}2311{_}"To my mind, this war cannot be of long duration.
10147-8{_}2312{_}Germany, with all its preparedness, could not lay by stores enough to support 65,000, people for any great length of time when there is no raw material coming in.
10147-8{_}2313{_}The country will be starved out, if not beaten in the field, for I do not believe Germany can gain control of the high seas and cover the world with its merchantmen."
10147-8{_}2314{_}INDIAN TROOPS CALLED FOR  The announcement by Lord Kitchener in the House of Commons late in August that native troops from India were to be summoned to the aid of the British army in France "came like a crash of thunder and revealed a grim determination to fight the struggle out to a successful finish."
10147-8{_}2315{_}There was some talk in England of increasing the army by temporary conscription, but Premier Asquith declined to consider any such proposal.
10147-8{_}2316{_}In the House of Commons on September 9 a message was read from the Viceroy of India, which said that the rulers of the Indian native states, nearly 700 in number, had with one accord rallied to the defense of the empire with personal offers of services as well as the resources of their states.
10147-8{_}2317{_}Many of the native rulers of India also sent cables to King George offering him their entire military and financial resources, while the people of India by thousands offered to volunteer.
10147-8{_}2318{_}Conditions in India were indeed so satisfactory, from the British standpoint, that Premier Asquith was able to announce that two divisions (40,000) of British (white) soldiers were to be removed from India.
10147-8{_}2319{_}The aid that India could offer was not lightly to be considered.
10147-8{_}2320{_}The soldiery retained by the British and the rajahs, constituting India's standing army, amount to about 400,000, not taking into consideration the reserves and the volunteers.
10147-8{_}2321{_}The rajahs maintain about 23, soldiers, who are named Imperial Service Troops, expressly for purposes of Imperial defense, and these have served in many wars.
10147-8{_}2322{_}They served with British, German, French, and United States troops in China from September, 1900, to August, 1901, and gained the highest laurels for efficiency and good conduct.
10147-8{_}2323{_}The first Indian troops called for by Lord Kitchener included two divisions of infantry and a brigade of cavalry, adding about 70, combatants to the allied armies in France, with approximately 130 pieces of artillery, both light and heavy, and howitzers.
10147-8{_}2324{_}Twelve Indian potentates were selected to accompany this expeditionary force.
10147-8{_}2325{_}These included the veteran Sir Pertab Singh, regent of Jodhpur; Sir Ganga Bahadur, Maharajah of Bikanir, and Sir Bhupindra Singh, Maharajah of Patiala.
10147-8{_}2326{_}The expeditionary force contained units of the regular army and contingents of the Imperial Service Troops in India, From twelve states the viceroy accepted contingents of cavalry, infantry, sappers and transport, besides a camel corps from Bikanir.
10147-8{_}2327{_}The Maharajah of Mysore placed $1,600,000 at the disposal of the Government in connection with the expenditure for the expeditionary force.
10147-8{_}2328{_}In addition to this gift, the Maharajahs of Gwalior and Bhopal contributed large sums of money and provided thousands of horses as remounts.
10147-8{_}2329{_}Maharajah Repa offered his troops and treasure, even his privately-owned jewelry, for the service of the British King and Emperor of India.
10147-8{_}2330{_}Maharajah Holkar of Indore made a gift of all the horses in the army of his state.
10147-8{_}2331{_}A similar desire to help the British Government was shown by committees representing religious, political, and social associations of all classes and creeds in India.
10147-8{_}2332{_}In the House of Lords on August 28 Earl Kitchener announced that the first division of the troops from India was already on the way to the front in France.
10147-8{_}2333{_}At the same time the Marquis of Crewe, secretary of state for India, said: "It has been deeply impressed upon us by what we have heard from India that the wonderful wave of enthusiasm and loyalty now passing over that country is to a great extent based upon the desire of the Indian people that Indian soldiers should stand side by side with their comrades of the British army in repelling the invasion of our friends' territory and the attack made upon Belgium.
10147-8{_}2334{_}We shall find our army there reinforced by native Indian soldiers--high-souled men of first-rate training and representing an ancient civilization; and we feel certain that if they are called upon they will give the best possible account of themselves side by side with our British troops in encountering the enemy."
10147-8{_}2335{_}KING GEORGE PRAISES COLONIES  On September 9 a message from King George to the British colonies, thanking them for their aid in Britain's emergency, was published as follows:  "During the last few weeks the peoples of my whole empire at home and overseas have moved with one mind and purpose to confront and overthrow an unparalleled assault upon the continuity of civilization and the peace of mankind.
10147-8{_}2336{_}"The calamitous conflict is not of my seeking.
10147-8{_}2337{_}My voice has been cast throughout on the side of peace.
10147-8{_}2338{_}My ministers earnestly strove to allay the causes of the strife and to appease differences with which my empire was not concerned.
10147-8{_}2339{_}Had I stood aside when in defiance of pledges to which my kingdom was a party, the soil of Belgium was violated and her cities made desolate, when the very life of the French nation was threatened with extinction, I should have sacrificed my honor and given to destruction the liberties of my empire and of mankind.
10147-8{_}2340{_}"I rejoice that every part of the empire is with me in this decision.
10147-8{_}2341{_}"Paramount regard for a treaty of faith and the pledged word of rulers and peoples is the common heritage of Great Britain and of the empire.
10147-8{_}2342{_}My peoples in the self-governing dominions have shown beyond all doubt that they whole-heartedly indorse the grave decision it was necessary to take, and I am proud to be able to show to the world that my peoples oversea are as determined as the people of the United Kingdom to prosecute a just cause to a successful end.
10147-8{_}2343{_}"The Dominion of Canada, the Commonwealth of Australia and the Dominion of New Zealand have placed at my disposal their naval forces, which have already rendered good service for the empire.
10147-8{_}2344{_}Strong expeditionary forces are being prepared in Canada, Australia and New Zealand for service at the front, and the Union of South Africa has released all British troops and undertaken other important military responsibilities.
10147-8{_}2345{_}"Newfoundland has doubled the number of its branch of the royal naval reserve, and is sending a body of men to take part in the operations at the front.
10147-8{_}2346{_}From the Dominion and Provincial governments of Canada, large and welcome gifts of supplies are on their way for use both by my naval and military forces.
10147-8{_}2347{_}"All parts of my oversea dominions have thus demonstrated in the most unmistakable manner the fundamental unity of the empire amidst all its diversity of situation and circumstance."
10147-8{_}2348{_}A message similar to the foregoing was addressed by King George to the princes and the people of India.
10147-8{_}2349{_}The King's eldest son, the young Prince of Wales, volunteered for active service at the outset of the war and was gazetted as a second lieutenant in the First Battalion, Grenadier Guards.
10147-8{_}2350{_}He also inaugurated and acted as treasurer of a national fund for the relief of sufferers by the war.
10147-8{_}2351{_}This fund soon grew to $10,000,000 and steadily climbed beyond that amount.
10147-8{_}2352{_}CHAPTER IX  EARLY BATTLES OF THE WAR  _Belgian Resistance to the German Advance_--_The Fighting at Vise, Haelen, Diest, Aerschot and Tirlemont_--_Mons and Charleroi the First Great Battles of the War_--Make a Gallant Stand, but Forced to Retire Across the French Border_.
10147-8{_}2353{_}From the first day of the German entry into Belgium brief and hazy reports of battles between the patriotic Belgians and the invaders came across the Atlantic.
10147-8{_}2354{_}Many absurd and mischievous reports of repeated Belgian "victories" were received throughout the month of August.
10147-8{_}2355{_}These were for the most part rendered ridiculous by the steady advance of the German troops.
10147-8{_}2356{_}The resistance of the Belgians was gallant and persistent, but availed only to hinder and delay the German advance which it was powerless to stop.
10147-8{_}2357{_}Up to August 23, there were no "victories" possible for either side, because never until then were the opposing armies definitely pitted against each other in an engagement in which one or the other must be broken.
10147-8{_}2358{_}All the time these Belgian "victories," which were no more than resistances to German reconnoissances, were being reported, the German line was not touched, and behind that line the Germans were methodically massing.
10147-8{_}2359{_}When they were ready they came on.
10147-8{_}2360{_}The Belgian army retired from the Diest-Tirlemont line, from Aerschot and Louvain, from Brussels, because to have held these positions against the overwhelming force opposed to them would have meant certain destruction.
10147-8{_}2361{_}The rearguards held each of these points with the greatest heroism so long as that was necessary, and then retired in good order on the main force.
10147-8{_}2362{_}VIS√â ATTACKED AND FIRED  The first fighting of any severity in Belgium occurred at Vis√©, near the frontier, early in the German advance.
10147-8{_}2363{_}German troops crossed the frontier in motors, followed by large bodies of cavalry, but the Belgians put up a stubborn resistance.
10147-8{_}2364{_}The chiefs of the Belgian staff had foreseen the invasion and had blown up the bridges of the River Meuse outside the town, as well as the railway tunnels.
10147-8{_}2365{_}Time after time the Belgians foiled with their heavy fire the attempts of the Germans to cross by means of pontoons.
10147-8{_}2366{_}Vis√© itself was stubbornly defended.
10147-8{_}2367{_}Only after a protracted struggle did the Germans master the town, which they fired in several places on entering.
10147-8{_}2368{_}BATTLES OF HAELEN-DIEST  At the end of the first week of the Belgian invasion it was estimated that the Germans had concentrated most of their field troops, probably about 900,000 combatants, along a 75-mile line running from Liege to the entrance into Luxemburg at Treves.
10147-8{_}2369{_}With this immense army it was said there were no less than 5,894 pieces of artillery.
10147-8{_}2370{_}This was only the first-line strength of the Germans, the reserves being massed in the rear.
10147-8{_}2371{_}Part of the right wing was swung northward and westward in the direction of Antwerp, and swept the whole of northern Belgium to the Dutch frontier.
10147-8{_}2372{_}On August 10 the Belgian defenders fought a heavy engagement with the Germans at Haelen, which was described in the dispatches as the first battle of the war.
10147-8{_}2373{_}A Belgian victory was claimed as the result, the German losses, it was said, being very heavy, especially in cavalry, while the Belgian casualties were reported relatively small.
10147-8{_}2374{_}But the German advance was merely checked.
10147-8{_}2375{_}The covering troops were speedily reinforced from the main body of the army and the advance swept on.
10147-8{_}2376{_}The result of the Haelen engagement was thus described in the dispatches of August 13:  "The battle centered around Haelen, in the Belgian province of Limbourg, extending to Diest, in the north of the province of Brabant, after passing round Zeelhem.
10147-8{_}2377{_}"At 7 o'clock last evening all the country between the three towns mentioned had been cleared of German troops, except the dead and wounded, who were thickly strewn about the fire zone.
10147-8{_}2378{_}Upward of 200 dead German soldiers were counted in a space of fifty yards square.
10147-8{_}2379{_}"A church, a brewery and some houses in Haelen.
10147-8{_}2380{_}were set afire, and two bridges over the Denier were destroyed by Belgian engineers.
10147-8{_}2381{_}"Great quantities of booty were collected on the battlefield, and this has been stacked in front of the town hall of Diest.
10147-8{_}2382{_}Many horses also were captured.
10147-8{_}2383{_}"The strength of the German column was about 5,000 men."
10147-8{_}2384{_}Another report said of the encounter:  "A division of Belgian cavalry, supported by a brigade of infantry and by artillery, engaged and defeated, near the fortress of Diest, eighteen miles northeast of Louvain, a division of German cavalry, also supported by infantry and by artillery.
10147-8{_}2385{_}"The fighting was extremely fierce and resulted in the Germans being thrown back toward Hasselt and St.
10147-8{_}2386{_}Trond."
10147-8{_}2387{_}Meanwhile the forts at Liege, to the southeast, still held out, though fiercely bombarded by German siege guns.
10147-8{_}2388{_}The fortress of Namur was also being attacked.
10147-8{_}2389{_}The Germans had bridged the river Meuse and were moving their crack artillery against the Belgian lines.
10147-8{_}2390{_}French troops had joined the Belgian defenders and the main battle line extended from Liege on the north to Metz on the south.
10147-8{_}2391{_}A visit to Haelen and other towns by a Brussels correspondent August 17, "showed the frightful devastation which the Germans perpetrated in Belgian territory.
10147-8{_}2392{_}"For instance, at Haelen itself houses belonging to the townspeople have been completely wrecked.
10147-8{_}2393{_}Windows were broken, furniture destroyed, and the walls demolished by shell fire.
10147-8{_}2394{_}Even the churches have not been respected.
10147-8{_}2395{_}The parish church at Haelen has been damaged considerably from shrapnel fire, "On the battlefield there are many graves of Germans marked by German lances erected in the form of a cross."
10147-8{_}2396{_}ON THE BATTLEFIELD OF DIEST  A correspondent of the New York Tribune said:  "Across the battlefield of Diest there is a brown stretch of harrowed ground half a furlong in length.
10147-8{_}2397{_}It is the grave of twelve hundred Germans who fell in the fight of August 11.
10147-8{_}2398{_}All over the field there are other graves, some of Germans, some of Belgians, some of horses.
10147-8{_}2399{_}When I reached the place peasants with long mattocks and spades were turning in the soil.
10147-8{_}2400{_}For two full days they had been at the work of burial and they were sick at heart.
10147-8{_}2401{_}Their corn is ripe for cutting in the battlefield, but little of it will be harvested.
10147-8{_}2402{_}Dark paths in their turnip fields are sodden with the blood of men and horses."
10147-8{_}2403{_}The Belgians, in contempt of German markmanship, had forced the enemy to the attack, which had been made from three points of the field simultaneously.
10147-8{_}2404{_}The fighting had been fierce, but now that both sides had swept on, no one seemed to know how those in the fight had really fared.
10147-8{_}2405{_}Only by the heaps of dead could one make estimate:  "At least, there were most dead on the side toward the bridge.
10147-8{_}2406{_}A charge of 300 Uhlans, who were held in check for a short time by seventeen Belgians at a corner, seems, however, to have come near success.
10147-8{_}2407{_}The derelict helmets and lances that covered the fields show that the charge pressed well up to the guns and to the trenches in the turnip fields where the Belgian soldiers lay.
10147-8{_}2408{_}On the German left mitrailleuses got in their work behind, and in the houses on the outskirts of the villages.
10147-8{_}2409{_}Five of these houses were burned to the ground, and two others farther out broken all to pieces and burned.
10147-8{_}2410{_}In a shed was a peasant weeping over the dead bodies of his cows.
10147-8{_}2411{_}"It would be easy now at the beginning of this war to write of its tragedy.
10147-8{_}2412{_}The villages have each a tale of loss to tell.
10147-8{_}2413{_}All of the twelve hundred men in the long grave were men with wives, sweethearts, and parents.
10147-8{_}2414{_}All the Belgian soldiers and others who were buried where they fell have mourners.
10147-8{_}2415{_}A LETTER FROM THE GRAVE  "A letter which I picked up on the field and am endeavoring to have identified and sent her for whom it is intended will speak for all.
10147-8{_}2416{_}It is written in ink on half a sheet of thin notepaper.
10147-8{_}2417{_}There is no date and no place.
10147-8{_}2418{_}It probably was written on the eve of battle in the hope that it would reach its destination if the writer died.
10147-8{_}2419{_}This is the translation:  "'Sweetheart: Fate in this present war has treated us more cruelly than many others.
10147-8{_}2420{_}If I have not lived to create for you the happiness of which both our hearts dreamed, remember my sole wish now is that you should be happy.
10147-8{_}2421{_}Forget me and create for yourself some happy home that may restore to you some of the greater pleasures of life.
10147-8{_}2422{_}For myself, I shall have died happy in the thought of your love.
10147-8{_}2423{_}My last thought has been for you and for those I leave at home.
10147-8{_}2424{_}Accept this, the last kiss from him who loved you.'
10147-8{_}2425{_}"Postcards from fathers with blessings to their gallant sons I found, too, on the field, little mementos of people and of places carried by men as mascots.
10147-8{_}2426{_}Everywhere were broken lances of German and Belgian, side by side; scabbards and helmets, saddles and guns.
10147-8{_}2427{_}These the peasants were collecting in a pile, to be removed by the military.
10147-8{_}2428{_}High up over the graves of twelve hundred, as we stood there, a German biplane came and went, hovering like a carrion crow, seeking other victims for death.
10147-8{_}2429{_}"In the village itself death is still busy.
10147-8{_}2430{_}A wounded German died as we stood by his side and a Belgian soldier placed his handkerchief over his face.
10147-8{_}2431{_}Soldiers who filled the little market-place may be fighting for life now as I write.
10147-8{_}2432{_}The enemy is in force not a mile away from them, and in a moment they may be attacked.
10147-8{_}2433{_}It is significant that all German prisoners believed they were in France.
10147-8{_}2434{_}The deception, it appears, was necessary to encourage them in their attack, and twelve hundred dead in the harrowed field died without knowing whom or what they were fighting."
10147-8{_}2435{_}THOUGHT THEY WERE IN FRANCE  A number of German prisoners were taken by the Belgians during the fighting at Haelen-Diest.
10147-8{_}2436{_}From these it was learned that the German soldiers really believed they were fighting in France.
10147-8{_}2437{_}At Diest it is said that 400 surrendered the moment they lost their officers and were surprised to learn that they were in Belgium.
10147-8{_}2438{_}King Albert of Belgium was constantly in the field during the early engagements of the war, moving from point to point inside the Belgian lines by means of a high-powered automobile, in which he was slightly wounded by the explosion of a shell.
10147-8{_}2439{_}He was thus enabled to keep in touch with the field forces, as well as with his general staff, and speedily endeared himself to the Belgian soldiery by his personal disregard of danger.
10147-8{_}2440{_}The Belgians by their gallant fight against the trained legions of Germany quickly won the admiration even of their foes.
10147-8{_}2441{_}The army of Belgium was brought up to its full strength of 300,000 men and everywhere the soldiers of the little country battled to halt the invaders.
10147-8{_}2442{_}Often their efforts proved effective.
10147-8{_}2443{_}The losses on both sides were truly appalling, the Germans suffering most on account of their open methods of attack in close order.
10147-8{_}2444{_}But their forces were like the sands of the sea and every gap in the ranks of the onrushing host was promptly filled by more Germans.
10147-8{_}2445{_}TIRLEMONT AKD LOUVAIN  The fighting at Tirlemont and Louvain was described by a citizen of Ostend, who says he witnessed it from a church tower at Tirlemont first and later proceeded to Louvain.
10147-8{_}2446{_}He says:  "Until luncheon time Tuesday, August 18, Tirlemont was quiet and normal.
10147-8{_}2447{_}Suddenly, about 1 o'clock, came the sound of the first German gun.
10147-8{_}2448{_}The artillery had opened fire.
10147-8{_}2449{_}"From the church tower it was possible to see distinctly the position of the German guns and the bursting of their shells.
10147-8{_}2450{_}The Belgians replied from their positions east of Louvain.
10147-8{_}2451{_}It was a striking sight, to the accompaniment of the ceaseless thud-thud of bursting shells with their puffs of cottonlike smoke, tearing up the peaceful wheat fields not far away.
10147-8{_}2452{_}BELGIANS RETIRE AT LOUVAIN  "Gradually working nearer, the shells began to strike the houses in Tirlemont.
10147-8{_}2453{_}This was a signal for the populace, which had been confident that the Belgian army would protect them, to flee.
10147-8{_}2454{_}All they knew was that the Germans were coming.
10147-8{_}2455{_}From the tower the scene was like the rushing of rats from a disturbed nest.
10147-8{_}2456{_}The people fled in every direction except one.
10147-8{_}2457{_}"I moved down to Louvain, where everything seemed quiet and peaceful.
10147-8{_}2458{_}The people sat in the cafes drinking their evening beer and smoking.
10147-8{_}2459{_}Meanwhile the Belgian troops were retiring in good order toward Louvain.
10147-8{_}2460{_}TOWN IN PANIC WITH REFUGEES  "By midnight the town was in the throes of a panic.
10147-8{_}2461{_}Long before midnight throngs of refugees had begun to arrive, followed later by soldiers.
10147-8{_}2462{_}By 11 o'clock the Belgian rear guard was engaging the enemy at the railroad bridge at the entrance to the town.
10147-8{_}2463{_}"The firing was heavy.
10147-8{_}2464{_}The wounded began to come in.
10147-8{_}2465{_}Riderless horses came along, both German and Belgian.
10147-8{_}2466{_}These were caught and mounted by civilians glad to have so rapid a mode of escape.
10147-8{_}2467{_}TROOPS HINDERED BY CIVILIANS  "I remember watching a black clad Belgian woman running straight down the middle of a road away from the Germans.
10147-8{_}2468{_}Behind her came the retiring Belgian troops, disheartened but valiant.
10147-8{_}2469{_}This woman, clad in mourning, was the symbol of the Belgian populace.
10147-8{_}2470{_}"At some of the barricades along the route the refugees and soldiers arrived simultaneously, making the defense difficult.
10147-8{_}2471{_}All about Tirlemont and Louvain the refugees interfered with the work of the troops.
10147-8{_}2472{_}The road to Brussels always was crowded with refugees and many sorrowful sights were witnessed among them as they fled from the homes that had been peaceful and prosperous a few days before.
10147-8{_}2473{_}BRUSSELS FILLED WITH REFUGEES  "Brussels is filled with refugees from surrounding towns, despite the large numbers who left the city for Ghent and Ostend during the last few days," said a correspondent, writing from Ghent on August 20.
10147-8{_}2474{_}"The plight of most of the refugees is pitiable.
10147-8{_}2475{_}Many are camped in the public square whose homes in the suburbs have been fired by the Prussians.
10147-8{_}2476{_}The roads leading into Brussels have been crowded all day with all kinds of conveyances, many drawn by dogs and others by girls, women and aged peasants.
10147-8{_}2477{_}"Most of these people have lost everything.
10147-8{_}2478{_}Few of them have any money.
10147-8{_}2479{_}The peasant is considered lucky who succeeded in saving a single horse or a cow.
10147-8{_}2480{_}"Military men characterize the German force which is moving across Belgium as overwhelming, saying it consists of at least two or three army corps.
10147-8{_}2481{_}The advance of this huge force is covered over the entire thirty-mile front by a screen of cavalry.
10147-8{_}2482{_}The Germans had no difficulty in taking Louvain, which was virtually undefended.
10147-8{_}2483{_}"In the high wooded country between Louvain and Brussels the Germans found an excellent defensive position.
10147-8{_}2484{_}Having occupied Louvain, the Kaiser's troops pushed forward with great celerity, the cavalry opening out in fan-shaped formation, spreading across country.
10147-8{_}2485{_}"At one point they ran into a strong force of Belgian artillery, which punished them severely.
10147-8{_}2486{_}Later in the day a Belgian scouting force reached Louvain and found it unoccupied, but received imperative orders to fall back, because of the danger of being outflanked and annihilated."
10147-8{_}2487{_}ALLIES MEET THE INVADERS  By August 20 the Germans were in touch with the French army that had advanced into Belgium and occupied the line Dinant-Charleroi-Mons, the right of the French resting on Dinant and the left on Mons, where they were reinforced by the British expeditionary force under Field Marshal French.
10147-8{_}2488{_}There was a heavy engagement at Charleroi, and a four days' battle was begun at Mons August 23.
10147-8{_}2489{_}Slowly but surely the Franco-British army was forced back across the French border, to take up a new position on the line, Noyon-Chant-La Fere, which constituted the second line of the French defense.
10147-8{_}2490{_}The German right, opposing the British, was under command of General von Kluck; General von Buelow and General von Hausen commanded the German center opposing the Franco-Belgian forces between the Sambre and Namur and the Meuse.
10147-8{_}2491{_}The Grand Duke Albrecht of Wuerttemberg operated between Charleroi and the French border fortress of Maubeuge.
10147-8{_}2492{_}The German Crown Prince led an army farther east, advancing toward the Meuse.
10147-8{_}2493{_}The Crown Prince of Bavaria commanded the German forces farther south toward Nancy, and General von Heeringen was engaged in repulsing French attacks on Alsace-Lorraine, in the region of the Vosges mountains, where the French had met with early successes.
10147-8{_}2494{_}Meanwhile on August 18 the town of Aerschot had been the scene of a bloody engagement and was occupied and partly destroyed by the Germans.
10147-8{_}2495{_}The occupation of Brussels followed on August 20-21 and the German line of communications was kept open by a line of occupied towns.
10147-8{_}2496{_}After overwhelming the Belgians the Kaiser's great advance army swept quickly into deadly conflict with the allies.
10147-8{_}2497{_}The first mighty shock came at Charleroi, where the French were forced back, and on August came the first battle with the British at Mons.
10147-8{_}2498{_}THE BATTLE OF MONS----FOUR DAYS OF FIGHTING----RETREAT OF THE ALLIES  All England was thrilled on the morning of September 10 when the British government permitted the newspapers to publish the first report from Field Marshal Sir John D.P.
10147-8{_}2499{_}French, commander-in-chief of the British army allied with the French and Belgians on the continent, telling of the heroic fight made by the British troops, August 23-26, to keep from being annihilated by the Germans.
10147-8{_}2500{_}The withdrawal of the British army before the German advance was compared to the pursuit of a wildcat by hounds, the English force backing stubbornly toward the River Oise, constantly showing its teeth, but realizing that it must reach the river or perish.
10147-8{_}2501{_}The report of Field Marshal French created much surprise in England, as it was not known until his statement was made public just how hard pressed the British army had been.
10147-8{_}2502{_}The communication was addressed to Earl Kitchener, the secretary for war, and its publication indicated that the government was responding to the public demand for fuller information on the progress of operations, so far as the British forces in France were concerned.
10147-8{_}2503{_}The report, as published in the London Gazette, the official organ, was as follows:  FIELD MARSHAL FRENCH'S REPORT  "The transportation of the troops from England by rail and sea was effected in the best order and without a check.
10147-8{_}2504{_}Concentration was practically completed on the evening of Friday, August 21, and I was able to make dispositions to move the force during Saturday to positions I considered most favorable from which to commence the operations which General Joffre requested me to undertake.
10147-8{_}2505{_}The line extended along the line of the canal from Cond√© on the west, through Mons and Binche on the east.
10147-8{_}2506{_}"During August 22 and 23 the advance squadrons did some excellent work, some of them penetrating as far as Soignies (a town of Belgium ten miles northeast of Mons) and several encounters took place in which our troops showed to great advantage.
10147-8{_}2507{_}"On Sunday, the 23d, reports began to come in to the effect that the enemy was commencing an attack on the Mons line, apparently in some strength, but that the right of the position from Mons was being particularly threatened.
10147-8{_}2508{_}"The commander of the First Corps had pushed his flank back to some high ground south of Bray and the Fifth Cavalry evacuated Binche, moving slightly south.
10147-8{_}2509{_}The enemy thereupon occupied Binche.
10147-8{_}2510{_}"The right of the third division under General Hamilton was at Mons, which formed a somewhat dangerous salient and I directed the commander of the Second Corps if threatened seriously to draw back the center behind Mons.
10147-8{_}2511{_}"In the meantime, about five in the afternoon, I received a most unexpected message from General Joffre by telegraph, telling me that at least three German corps were moving on my position in front and that a second corps was engaged in a turning movement from the direction of Tournai.
10147-8{_}2512{_}He also informed me that the two reserve French divisions and the Fifth French Army Corps on my right were retiring.
10147-8{_}2513{_}CHOSE A NEW POSITION  "In view of the possibility of my being driven from the Mons position, I had previously ordered a position in the rear to be reconnoitered.
10147-8{_}2514{_}"This position rested on the fortress of Maubeuge on the right and extended west to Jenlain, southeast of Valenciennes on the left.
10147-8{_}2515{_}The position was reported difficult to hold because standing crops and buildings limited the fire in many important localities.
10147-8{_}2516{_}"When the news of the retirement of the French and the heavy German threatening on my front reached me, I endeavored to confirm it by aeroplane reconnaissance, and as a result of this I determined to effect a retirement to the Maubeuge position at daybreak on the 24th.
10147-8{_}2517{_}"A certain amount of fighting continued along the whole line throughout the night and at daybreak on the 24th the second division from the neighborhood of Harmignies made a powerful demonstration as if to retake Binche.
10147-8{_}2518{_}This was supported by the artillery of both the first and the second divisions while the first division took up a supporting position in the neighborhood of Peissant.
10147-8{_}2519{_}Under cover of this demonstration The Second Corps retired on the line of Dour, Quarouble and Frameries.
10147-8{_}2520{_}The third division on the right of the corps suffered considerable loss in this operation from the enemy, who had retaken Mons.
10147-8{_}2521{_}"The Second Corps halted on this line, where they intrenched themselves, enabling Sir Douglas Haig, with the First Corps, to withdraw to the new position.
10147-8{_}2522{_}NIGHT ATTACK ON THE LEFT  "Toward midnight the enemy appeared to be directing his principal effort against our left.
10147-8{_}2523{_}I had previously ordered General Allenby with the cavalry to act vigorously in advance of my left front and endeavor to take the pressure off.
10147-8{_}2524{_}"About 7:30 in the morning General Allenby received a message from Sir Charles Fergusson, commanding the fifth division, saying he was very hard pressed and in urgent need of support.
10147-8{_}2525{_}On receipt of this message General Allenby drew in his cavalry and endeavored to bring direct support to the fifth division.
10147-8{_}2526{_}"During the course of this operation General DeLisle of the Second Cavalry Brigade thought he saw a good opportunity to paralyze the further advance of the enemy's infantry by making a mounted attack on his flank.
10147-8{_}2527{_}He formed up and advanced for this purpose, but was held up by wire about 500 yards from his objective.
10147-8{_}2528{_}GENERAL SMITH-DORRIEN IN RETREAT  "The Nineteenth Infantry Brigade was brought by rail to Valenciennes on the 22d and 23d.
10147-8{_}2529{_}On the morning of the 24th, they were moved out to a position south of Quarouble to support the left flank of the Second Corps.
10147-8{_}2530{_}With the assistance of cavalry Sir Horace Smith-Dorrien was enabled to effect his retreat to a new position.
10147-8{_}2531{_}"At nightfall a position was occupied by the Second Corps to the west of Bavay, the First Corps to the right.
10147-8{_}2532{_}The right was protected by the fortress of Maubeuge, the left by the Nineteenth Brigade in position between Jenlain and Bavay and cavalry on the outer flank.
10147-8{_}2533{_}The French were still retiring and I had no support except such as was afforded by the fortress of Maubeuge.
10147-8{_}2534{_}ARMY IN GEEAT PERIL  "I felt that not a moment must be lost in retiring to another position.
10147-8{_}2535{_}I had every reason to believe that the enemy's forces were somewhat exhausted and I knew that they had suffered heavy losses.
10147-8{_}2536{_}The operation, however, was full of danger and difficulty, not only owing to the very superior forces in my front, but also to the exhaustion of the troops.
10147-8{_}2537{_}"The retirement was recommenced in the early morning of the 25th to a position in the neighborhood of Le Catean and the rear guard were ordered to be clear of Maubeuge and Bavay by 5:30 a. m.  "The fourth division commenced its detrainment at Le Cateau on Sunday, August 23, and by the morning of the 25th eleven battalions and a brigade of artillery with the divisional staff were available for service.
10147-8{_}2538{_}I ordered General Snow to move out to take up a position with his right south of Solesmes, his left resting on the Cambrai-Le Cateau road south of La Chapriz.
10147-8{_}2539{_}In this position the division rendered great help.
10147-8{_}2540{_}"Although the troops had been ordered to occupy Cam-brai-Le Cateau-Landrecies position and ground had, during the 25th, been partially prepared and entrenched, I had grave doubts as to the wisdom of standing there to fight.
10147-8{_}2541{_}"Having regard to the continued retirement of the French right, my exposed left flank, the tendency of the enemy's western corps to envelop me, and, more than all, the exhausted condition of the troops, I determined to make a great effort to continue the retreat till I could put some substantial obstacle, such as the Somme or the Oise between my troops and the enemy.
10147-8{_}2542{_}RETREAT IS ORDERED  "Orders were therefore sent to the corps commanders to continue their retreat as soon as they possibly could toward the general line of Vermand, St. Quentin and Ribemont, and the cavalry under General Allenby were ordered to cover the retirement.
10147-8{_}2543{_}Throughout the 25th and far into the evening the First Corps continued to march on Landrecies, following the road along the eastern border of the forest of Mormal, and arrived at Landrecies about 10 o'clock.
10147-8{_}2544{_}I had intended that the corps should come further west so as to fill up the gap between Le Cateau and Landrecies, but the men were exhausted and could not get further in without a rest.
10147-8{_}2545{_}"The enemy, however, would not allow them this rest and about 9: that evening the report was received that the Fourth Guards brigade in Landrecies was heavily attacked by troops of the Ninth German army corps, who were coming through the forest to the north of the town.
10147-8{_}2546{_}FRENCH AID IS GIVEN  "At the same time information reached me from Sir Douglas Haig that his first division was also heavily engaged south and east of Marilles.
10147-8{_}2547{_}I sent urgent messages to the commander of two French reserve divisions on my right to come up to the assistance of the First Corps, which they eventually did.
10147-8{_}2548{_}"By about 6 in the afternoon the Second Corps had got Into position, with their right on Le Cateau, their left in the neighborhood of Caudry, and the line of defense was continued thence by the fourth division toward Seranvillers.
10147-8{_}2549{_}"During the fighting on the 24th and 25th the cavalry became a good deal scattered, but by early morning of the 26th General Allenby had succeeded in concentrating two brigades to the south of Cambrai.
10147-8{_}2550{_}"On the 24th the French cavalry corps, consisting of three divisions under General Sordet, had been in billets, north of Avesnes.
10147-8{_}2551{_}On my way back from Vavay, which was my _paste de commandemente_ during the fighting of the 23d and the 24th, I visited General Sordet and earnestly requested his cooperation and support.
10147-8{_}2552{_}He promised to obtain sanction from his army commander to act on my left flank, but said that his horses were too tired to move before the next day.
10147-8{_}2553{_}"Although he rendered me valuable assistance later on in the course of the retirement, he was unable for the reasons given to afford me any support on the most critical day of all--namely, the 26th.
10147-8{_}2554{_}GERMANS USE HEAVY GUNS  "At daybreak it became apparent that the enemy was throwing the bulk of his strength against the left of the position occupied by the Second Corps and the fourth division.
10147-8{_}2555{_}At this time the guns of four German army corps were in position against them, and Sir Horace Smith-Dorrien reported to me that he judged it impossible to continue his retirement at daybreak.
10147-8{_}2556{_}"I sent him orders to use his utmost endeavors to break off the action and retire at the earliest possible moment, as it was impossible for me to send him support.
10147-8{_}2557{_}"The French cavalry corps under General Sordet was coming up on our left rear early in the morning, and I sent him an urgent message to do his utmost to come up and support the retirement of my left flank, but owing to the fatigue of his horses he found himself unable to intervene in any way.
10147-8{_}2558{_}"There had been no time to intrench the position properly, but the troops showed a magnificent front to the terrible fire which confronted them.
10147-8{_}2559{_}ARMY FACED ANNIHILATION  "At length it became apparent that if complete annihilation was to be avoided retirement must be attempted, and the order was given to commence it about 3:30 in the afternoon.
10147-8{_}2560{_}The movement was covered with most devoted intrepidity and determination by the artillery, which had itself suffered heavily, and the fine work done by the cavalry in the further retreat from the position assisted materially the final completion of this most difficult and dangerous operation.
10147-8{_}2561{_}"I cannot close the brief account of this glorious stand of the British troops without putting on record my deep appreciation of the valuable services rendered by Sir Horace Smith-Dorrien.
10147-8{_}2562{_}I say without hesitation that the saving of the left wing of the army under my command on the morning of the 26th could never have been accomplished unless a commander of rare and unusual coolness, intrepidity and determination bad been present to personally conduct the operations.
10147-8{_}2563{_}"The retreat was continued far into the night of the 26th and through the 27th and the 28th, on which date the troops halted on the line from Noyon, Chauny and LeFere.
10147-8{_}2564{_}PRAISES SORDET'S HELP  "On the 27th and 28th I was much indebted to General Sordet and the French cavalry division which he commands for materially assisting my retirement and successfully driving back some of the enemy on Cambrai.
10147-8{_}2565{_}General d'Amade also, with the Sixty-first and Sixty-second Reserve divisions, moved down from the neighborhood of Arras on the enemy's right flank and took much pressure off the rear of the British forces.
10147-8{_}2566{_}"This closed the period covering the heavy fighting which commenced at Mons on Sunday afternoon, August 23, and which really constituted a four days' battle.
10147-8{_}2567{_}"I deeply deplore the very serious losses which the British forces suffered in this great battle, but they were inevitable, in view of the fact that the British army--only a few days after concentration by rail--was called upon to withstand the vigorous attack of five German army corps.
10147-8{_}2568{_}"It is impossible for me to speak too highly of the skill evinced by the two general officers commanding army corps, the self-sacrificing and devoted exertions of their staffs, the direction of troops by the divisional, brigade and regimental leaders, the command of small units by their officers and the magnificent fighting spirit displayed by the noncommissioned officers and men.
10147-8{_}2569{_}[Signed] "J. D. P. FRENCH, "Field Marshal."
10147-8{_}2570{_}TOLD BY A WOUNDED SOLDIER  A British soldier, who was wounded in the fight during the retreat from Mons, told the following story of the battle there:  "It was Sunday, August 23, and the British regiments at Mons were merry-making and enjoying themselves in leisure along the streets.
10147-8{_}2571{_}Belgian ladies, returning from church, handed the soldiers their prayer books as souvenirs, while the Belgian men gave the men cigarettes and tobacco.
10147-8{_}2572{_}"About noon, when the men were beginning to think about dinner, a German aeroplane appeared overhead and began throwing out a cloud of black powder, which is one of their favorite methods of assisting batteries to get the range.
10147-8{_}2573{_}"No sooner had the powder cloud appeared than shrapnel began to burst overhead and in a moment all was confusion and uproar.
10147-8{_}2574{_}But it didn't take the regiments long to get into fighting trim and race through the city to the scene of operations, which was on the other side of the small canal, in the suburbs.
10147-8{_}2575{_}"Here our outposts were engaging the enemy fiercely.
10147-8{_}2576{_}The outposts lost very heavily, most of the damage being done by shells.
10147-8{_}2577{_}The rifle fire was ineffective, although at times the lines of contenders were not more than 300 yards apart.
10147-8{_}2578{_}"The first reinforcements to arrive were posted in a glass factory, the walls of which were loop-holed, and we doggedly held that position until nightfall, when we fixed bayonets and lay in wait in case the enemy made an attempt to rush the position in the darkness.
10147-8{_}2579{_}DESTROY BRIDGES BEHIND THEM  "About midnight orders came to retire over the canal and two companies were left behind to keep the enemy in check temporarily.
10147-8{_}2580{_}After the main body had crossed the bridge was blown up, leaving the two outpost companies to get across as best they could by boats or swimming.
10147-8{_}2581{_}Most of them managed to reach the main body again.
10147-8{_}2582{_}"The main body retired from the town and fell back through open country, being kept moving all night.
10147-8{_}2583{_}When daylight arrived it was apparent from higher ground that Mons had been practically blown away by the German artillery.
10147-8{_}2584{_}"Throughout the morning we continued to fight a rearguard action, but the steady march in retreat did not stop until 6 o'clock in the evening, when the British found themselves well out of range of the German artillery in a quiet valley.
10147-8{_}2585{_}"Here all the troops were ordered to rest and eat.
10147-8{_}2586{_}As they had been without food since the previous morning's breakfast it was rather amusing to see the soldiers going into the turnip fields and eating turnips as though they were apples.
10147-8{_}2587{_}"At 8 o'clock all lights were extinguished, the soldiers were ordered to make no noise and the pickets pushed a long distance backward.
10147-8{_}2588{_}Long before dawn the troops were hastily started again and continued the retirement.
10147-8{_}2589{_}"By noon the enemy was again heard from and a large detachment was assigned the task of fighting to protect our rear.
10147-8{_}2590{_}WATCH DUEL IN AIR  "During the afternoon both the German and British armies watched a duel in the air between French and German aeroplanes.
10147-8{_}2591{_}The Frenchman was wonderfully clever, and succeeded in maneuvering himself to the upper position, which he gained after fifteen minutes of reckless effort.
10147-8{_}2592{_}Then the Frenchman began blazing away at the German with a revolver.
10147-8{_}2593{_}"Finally he hit him, and the wounded German attempted to glide down into his own lines.
10147-8{_}2594{_}The glide, however, ended in the British lines near my detachment, the West Kent Infantry.
10147-8{_}2595{_}We found the aviator dead when we reached the machine.
10147-8{_}2596{_}We buried him and burned the aeroplane.
10147-8{_}2597{_}"At dusk a halt was made for food, and as the Germans had fallen behind the English spent a quiet night.
10147-8{_}2598{_}At dawn, however, we found the Germans close to our heels, and several regiments were ordered to prepare intrenchments.
10147-8{_}2599{_}This is tedious and tiresome work, especially in the heat and without proper food, but we quickly put up fortifications which were sufficient to protect us somewhat from the artillery fire.
10147-8{_}2600{_}"It was not long before the German gunners found the range and began tearing up those rough fortifications, concentrating their fire on the British batteries, one of which was completely demolished.
10147-8{_}2601{_}Another found itself with only six men.
10147-8{_}2602{_}Both these disasters bore testimony to the excellent markmanship of the German gunners.
10147-8{_}2603{_}OFFICER, SPIKES THE GUNS  "As it became evident that we must leave these guns behind and continue the retreat, an officer was seen going around putting the guns out of action, so that they would be of no use to the Germans.
10147-8{_}2604{_}His action required cool bravery, because the Germans, having found the range, continued firing directly at these batteries.
10147-8{_}2605{_}"Things rapidly got hotter, and the commanding officer ordered a double-quick retreat.
10147-8{_}2606{_}We were not long in doing the retiring movement to save our own skins.
10147-8{_}2607{_}"I was wounded at this time by a Maxim bullet.
