10147-8{_}2608{_}For a moment I thought my head had been blown off, but I recovered and kept on running until I reached a trench, where I had an opportunity to bandage the wound.
10147-8{_}2609{_}I rushed off to the ambulances, but found the doctors so busy with men worse off than I that I went back to my place in the line."
10147-8{_}2610{_}THE BATTLE AT CHABLEROI  The loss of life in the Franco-German battle near Charleroi was admittedly the greatest of any engagement up to that time.
10147-8{_}2611{_}It was at Charleroi that the Germans struck their most terrific blow at the allies' lines in their determination to gain the French frontier.
10147-8{_}2612{_}Though the tide of battle ebbed and flowed for awhile the French were finally forced to give way and to retreat behind their own frontier, while the British were being forced back from their position at Mons.
10147-8{_}2613{_}The fighting along the line was of the fiercest kind.
10147-8{_}2614{_}It was a titanic clash of armies in which the allies were compelled to yield ground before the superior numbers of the German host.
10147-8{_}2615{_}One of the wounded, who was taken to hospital at Dieppe, said of the fighting at Charleroi:  "Our army was engaging what we believed to be a section of the German forces commanded by the crown prince when I was wounded.
10147-8{_}2616{_}The Germans at one stage of the battle seemed lost.
10147-8{_}2617{_}They had been defending themselves almost entirely with howitzers from strongly intrenched positions.
10147-8{_}2618{_}The Germans were seemingly surrounded and cut off and were summoned to surrender.
10147-8{_}2619{_}The reply came back that so long as they had ammunition they would continue to fight.
10147-8{_}2620{_}"The howitzer shells of the Germans seemed enormous things and only exploded when they struck the earth.
10147-8{_}2621{_}When one would descend it would dig a hole a yard deep and split into hundreds of pieces.
10147-8{_}2622{_}Peculiarly enough the howitzer shells did much more wounding than killing.
10147-8{_}2623{_}The other shells of the Germans, like cartridges, the supply of which they seemed to be short of, did only little damage.
10147-8{_}2624{_}AEROS CONSTANTLY ABOVE  "The German aeroplane service was perfect.
10147-8{_}2625{_}An aircraft was always hovering over us out of range.
10147-8{_}2626{_}We were certain within an hour after we sighted an aeroplane to get the howitzers among us.
10147-8{_}2627{_}Whenever we fired, however, we did terrific execution with our seventy-five pieces of artillery.
10147-8{_}2628{_}I counted in one trench 185 dead.
10147-8{_}2629{_}Many of them were killed as they were in the act of firing or loading.
10147-8{_}2630{_}"The ground occupied by the Germans was so thick with dead that I believe I saw one soldier to every two yards.
10147-8{_}2631{_}You might have walked for a mile on bodies without ever putting foot to the ground.
10147-8{_}2632{_}They buried their dead when they had time, piling fifteen or twenty in a shallow pit."
10147-8{_}2633{_}THE FRENCH IN ALSACE-LORRAINE  On August 9 the advance guard brigade of the French right wing, under General Pau, a veteran of the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71, invaded Alsace, fought a victorious action with an intrenched German force of equal numbers and occupied Muelhausen and Kolmar.
10147-8{_}2634{_}The news of the French entry into the province lost in 1871 was received all over France with wild enthusiasm.
10147-8{_}2635{_}The mourning emblems on the Strasburg monument in Paris were removed by the excited populace and replaced by the tricolor flag and flowers in token of their joy.
10147-8{_}2636{_}Muelhausen was soon after retaken by the German forces, only to be recaptured later by the French and then evacuated once more.
10147-8{_}2637{_}On the day of the first French occupation of Muelhausen France declared war against Austria in consequence of the arrival of two Austrian army corps on the Rhine to assist the main German army.
10147-8{_}2638{_}After the French occupation of Muelhausen a large German army was sent to the front in Alsace-Lorraine and succeeded in dislodging the French from that city, but not without severe fighting.
10147-8{_}2639{_}Two weeks after the war began the French defeated a Bavarian corps in Alsace and for awhile General Pau more than held his own in that former province of France.
10147-8{_}2640{_}On August 21 the Germans drove back the French who had invaded Lorraine, and occupied Lun√©ville, ten miles inside the French border.
10147-8{_}2641{_}About the same time the French reoccupied Muelhausen, after three days' fighting around the city.
10147-8{_}2642{_}Another French army was reported to be within nineteen miles of Metz, But before the end of the month the French had been compelled to evacuate both their former provinces.
10147-8{_}2643{_}They continued during September, however, to make frequent assaults on the German frontier positions, but without regaining a sure foothold on German soil, the bulk of their efforts being devoted to the defense of their own frontier strongholds.
10147-8{_}2644{_}FIGHTING AROUND NANCY  An official dispatch from the foreign office in Paris, dated August 28, said:    "Yesterday the French troops took the offensive in the   Vosges mountains and in the region between the Vosges and   Nancy, and their offensive has been interrupted, but the German   loss has been considerable.
10147-8{_}2645{_}"Our forces found, near Nancy, on a front of three kilometers,   2,500 dead Germans, and near Vitrimont, on a front   of four kilometers, 4,500 dead.
10147-8{_}2646{_}Longwy, where the garrison   consisted of only one battalion, has capitulated to the Crown   Prince of Germany after a siege of twenty-four days."
10147-8{_}2647{_}FRENCH TRAPPED IN ALSACE  The German view of early operations in Alsace-Lorraine was given in the following dispatch September 2 from the headquarters of the general staff at Aix-la-Chapelle:    "The French forces were trapped in Alsace-Lorraine.
10147-8{_}2648{_}Realizing that the French temperament was more likely to be   swayed by sentiment than by stern adherence to the rules   of actual warfare, the German staff selected its own battle   line and waited.
10147-8{_}2649{_}The French did not disappoint.
10147-8{_}2650{_}They   rushed across the border.
10147-8{_}2651{_}They took Altkirch with little opposition.
10147-8{_}2652{_}Then they rushed on to Muelhausen.
10147-8{_}2653{_}Through the   passes in the Vosges mountains they poured, horse, artillery,   foot--all branches of the service.
10147-8{_}2654{_}Strasburg was to fall and   so swift was the French movement that lines of communication   were not guarded.
10147-8{_}2655{_}"Then the German general staff struck.
10147-8{_}2656{_}Their troops   from Saarburg, from Strasburg and from Metz, under the   command of General von Heeringen, attacked the French all   along the line.
10147-8{_}2657{_}They were utterly crushed.
10147-8{_}2658{_}The Germans   took 10,000 Frenchmen prisoners and more than one hundred   guns of every description.
10147-8{_}2659{_}Alsace-Lorraine is now reported   absolutely cleared of French troops.
10147-8{_}2660{_}"The armies of Crown Prince Frederick Wilhelm and of   Crown Prince Rupprecht of Bavaria are moving in an irresistible   manner into France.
10147-8{_}2661{_}In a 3-day battle below Metz   the French were terribly cut up and forced to retreat in almost   a rout.
10147-8{_}2662{_}It is declared that in this engagement the French   lost 151 guns and were unable to make a stand against the victorious   Germans until they had passed inside of their secondary   line of defense."
10147-8{_}2663{_}THE GERMAN "SPY POSTERS"  Just prior to the declaration of war, cable dispatches from Paris told of a remarkable series of posters dotting the countryside of France.
10147-8{_}2664{_}These posters, innocently advertising "Bouillon Kub," a German soup preparation, were so cleverly printed by the German concern advertising the soup, that they would act as signals to German army officers leading their troops through France.
10147-8{_}2665{_}In one of our photographic illustrations, one of these "spy posters" is seen posted on the left of an archway past which the French soldiers are marching en route to meet the Germans near the Alsace frontier.
10147-8{_}2666{_}The ingenuity of the signs was remarkable.
10147-8{_}2667{_}Thus a square yellow poster would carry the information, "Food in abundance found here," while a round red sign would advertise, "This ground is mined."
10147-8{_}2668{_}Many geometrical figures and most of the colors were utilized, and animal forms, flowers and even the American Stars and Stripes were employed to convey their messages of information.
10147-8{_}2669{_}The French Minister of the Interior got wind of the system, and orders were telegraphed throughout France to destroy these posters.
10147-8{_}2670{_}Bouillon Kub, therefore, is no longer advertised in France.
10147-8{_}2671{_}A SOLDIER'S EXPERIENCE UNDER FIRE  A wounded French soldier described his experiences under fire during the Alsace campaign.
10147-8{_}2672{_}He said in part: "There!
10147-8{_}2673{_}A blow in the breast, a tearing in the body, a fall with a loud cry and a terrible pain; there I lay one of the victims of this terrible day.
10147-8{_}2674{_}My first sensation was anger at the blow, my second an expectation of seeing myself explode, for, judging by the sound of the ball, I believed I had a grenade in my body; then came the pain, and with it helplessness and falling.
10147-8{_}2675{_}"Oh, how frightful are those first moments!
10147-8{_}2676{_}Where I was hit, how I was wounded, I could form no idea; I only felt that I could not stir, saw the battalion disappear from sight and myself alone on the ground, amid the fearful howling and whistling of the balls which were incessantly striking the ground around me.
10147-8{_}2677{_}"With difficulty could I turn my head a little, and saw behind me two soldiers attending on a third, who was lying on the ground.
10147-8{_}2678{_}Of what happened I can give no account except that I cried for help several times as well as I could, for the pain and burning thirst had the upper hand.
10147-8{_}2679{_}At last both of them ran to me, and with joy I recognized the doctor and hospital attendant of my company.
10147-8{_}2680{_}"'Where are you wounded?'
10147-8{_}2681{_}was the first question.
10147-8{_}2682{_}I could only point.
10147-8{_}2683{_}My blouse was quickly opened, and in the middle of the breast a bloody wound was found.
10147-8{_}2684{_}The balls still constantly whizzed around us; one struck the doctor's helmet, and immediately I felt a violent blow on the left arm.
10147-8{_}2685{_}Another wound!
10147-8{_}2686{_}With difficulty I was turned round, to look for the outlet of the bullet; but it was still in my body, near the spine.
10147-8{_}2687{_}At last it was cut out.
10147-8{_}2688{_}They were going away--'The wound in the arm, doctor.'
10147-8{_}2689{_}This, fortunately, was looked for in vain; the ball had merely caused a blue spot and had sunk harmlessly into the ground.
10147-8{_}2690{_}"I extended my hand to the doctor and thanked him, as also the attendant, whom I commissioned to ask the sergeant to send word to my family.
10147-8{_}2691{_}The doctor had carefully placed my cloak over me, with my helmet firmly on my head, in order in some measure to protect me from the leaden hail.
10147-8{_}2692{_}"Thus I lay alone with my own thoughts amid the most terrible fire for perhaps an hour and a half.
10147-8{_}2693{_}All my thoughts, as far as pain and increasing weakness allowed, were fixed on my family.
10147-8{_}2694{_}Gradually I got accustomed to the danger which surrounded me, and only when too much sand from the striking bullets was thrown on my body did I remember my little enviable position.
10147-8{_}2695{_}At last, after long, long waiting, the sanitary detachment came for me."
10147-8{_}2696{_}THE REAL TRAGEDY OF WAR  It is not a pleasant picture--this story of the French soldier.
10147-8{_}2697{_}It has little in it of the grandeur, the beat of drums, the sound of martial music, which is supposed to accompany war.
10147-8{_}2698{_}The tread of marching feet has died away, the excitement is gone, and man the demon is supplanted by man the everyday human creature of suffering and home folks and fear.
10147-8{_}2699{_}It is only a personal account of an individual experience, yet in it may be found the real significance and the real tragedy of war; for, after the fighting is over, after the intoxication of legalized murder has gone, after nations turn their attention from victories to men, it is the aggregate of individual experiences which counts the costs of war.
10147-8{_}2700{_}Thousands of German, French, Belgian, Austrian, Russian, and British men in the prime of life have been miserably slain and lie in obscure graves of which the enemy now is the guardian, while others writhe in the agony of lingering wounds or sullenly brood over their fate in the dull routine of military prisons.
10147-8{_}2701{_}In every part of the warring countries mothers weep over the sons they shall see no more, and wives over the husbands snatched from them forever.
10147-8{_}2702{_}In many a mansion, in many a comfortable home, in many a peasant's cottage, the empty chair is eloquent of the absent father, brother, husband or son who shall be absent forever.
10147-8{_}2703{_}CHAPTER X   GERMAN ADVANCE ON PARIS    _Allies Withdraw for Ten Days, Disputing Every Inch of   Ground With the Kaiser's Troops--Germans Push   Their Way Through France in Three Main Columns--   Reports of the Withdrawing Engagements--   Paris Almost in Sight_.
10147-8{_}2704{_}Flushed with their successes over the Allies at Mons and Charleroi, the Germans pushed their advance toward the French capital with great celerity and vigor.
10147-8{_}2705{_}During the last week of August and the first few days of September, it appeared inevitable that the experience of Paris in 1870-71 was to be repeated and that a siege of the city by the German forces would follow immediately.
10147-8{_}2706{_}It was conceded that the armies of the Allies had been forced back and that Paris was endangered.
10147-8{_}2707{_}The German advance was general, all along the line.
10147-8{_}2708{_}The flower of the Kaiser's army had marched through Belgium and pushed back the lines of the Allies to the formidable rows of fortifications that surround Paris.
10147-8{_}2709{_}The Germans advanced in three main columns, constantly in touch with one another, from the right, passing through Mons, Cambrai and Amiens, to the extreme left in Lorraine.
10147-8{_}2710{_}The center threatened Verdun, and from that point the right advance swept through Northern France like an opening fan, with the fortress of Verdun as the pivot.
10147-8{_}2711{_}Three million men were engaged in the main struggle.
10147-8{_}2712{_}When the Germans first reached the Franco-Belgian frontier near Charleroi they were opposed by 700,000 French and 150,000 British troops.
10147-8{_}2713{_}After being driven back the Allies began assembling 1,000,000 men between the frontier and Paris, The Allies hoped to hold the whole German army in check while the Russians pursued their successes in eastern Germany.
10147-8{_}2714{_}French troops guarded the entire frontier, battling to check the other German invading columns.
10147-8{_}2715{_}The holding of the Germans, once they broke through the fortifications that formed the chief reliance of the French, would be impossible.
10147-8{_}2716{_}The next stand would be around Paris, which was well fortified.
10147-8{_}2717{_}The invaders were, of course, attempting to get through where there were no forts.
10147-8{_}2718{_}ALLIES MAKE STRENUOUS RESISTANCE  Strenuous resistance to the onward movement of the German enemy was made by the Allies from day to day, but for a period of ten days there was an almost continual retirement of the French and British upon Paris.
10147-8{_}2719{_}It was in fact a masterly retreat, but a retreat nevertheless.
10147-8{_}2720{_}From the line of La F√®re and Mezieres, occupied by the Allies after the battles at Mons and Charleroi, they fell back 70 miles in seven days, disputing every step of the way, but withdrawing gradually to the line of defenses around the French capital.
10147-8{_}2721{_}From Cambrai the Germans pushed through Amiens to Beauvais; from Peronne to Roye, Montdidier, Creil, and on to the forest of Chantilly.
10147-8{_}2722{_}From the region of Le Cateau and St. Quentin the German advance was by Noyon to Compiegne (famous for its memories of Joan of Arc's famous sortie), at which point the Allies made a desperate stand and the Germans had to fight for every inch of ground.
10147-8{_}2723{_}They then passed through Senlis, which was first bombarded, down to Meaux, almost within sight of Paris, the head of the German army resting on a line between Beaumont, Meaux and La Ferte, at which point the resistance of the Allies finally forced a change in German plans.
10147-8{_}2724{_}Other German forces passed through Laon, Soissons and Chateau Thierry.
10147-8{_}2725{_}Farther to the east, the road from Mezieres led the Germans to Rheims, Mourmelon, and opposite Chalons on the River Marne.
10147-8{_}2726{_}Another German army from the direction of Longwy, under the command of the Crown Prince, was operating through Suippes and on the wooded Argonne plateau, with its five passes, famous in the action of which preceded the battle of Valmy.
10147-8{_}2727{_}At the entrance to this hilly country stands the little town of Sainte Menehould, where there was severe fighting with the French.
10147-8{_}2728{_}Here the German Crown Prince made his headquarters.
10147-8{_}2729{_}The great plain of the Argonne is full of most wonderful ecclesiastical buildings and many magnificent cathedrals, townhalls and ancient fortresses were passed by the warring armies in their advance and withdrawal, some of these historic structures sustaining irreparable damage.
10147-8{_}2730{_}The German advance continued southward toward Paris until September 4.
10147-8{_}2731{_}RELENTLESS PURSUIT OF THE BRITISH  All reports agree that during the retirement of the Allies, the Germans pursued the British headquarters staff with uncanny precision throughout the ten days from Mons back to Compi√®gne.
10147-8{_}2732{_}After fierce street fighting in Denain and Landrecies Sir John French withdrew his headquarters to Le Cateau, which was at once made the target of a terrific bombardment.
10147-8{_}2733{_}The town caught fire, burning throughout one night, and the British headquarters had to be evacuated, this time in favor of St. Quentin, in the local college.
10147-8{_}2734{_}Here the same thing happened and Field Marshal French was compelled once more to retire, to the neighborhood of Compi√®gne.
10147-8{_}2735{_}In an official report issued on Sunday, September 6, it is stated that, "The 5th French army on August 29 advanced from the line of the Oise River to meet and counter the German forward movement and a considerable battle developed to the south of Guise.
10147-8{_}2736{_}In this the 5th French army gained a marked and solid success, driving back with heavy loss and in disorder three German army corps, the 10th, the Guard, and a reserve corps.
10147-8{_}2737{_}In spite of this success, however, and all the benefits which flowed from it, the general retirement to the south continued and the German armies, seeking persistently after the British troops, remained in practically continuous contact with the rearguards.
10147-8{_}2738{_}"On August 30 and 31 the British covering and delaying troops were frequently engaged, and on September 1 a very vigorous effort was made by the Germans, which brought about a sharp action in the neighborhood of Compi√®gne.
10147-8{_}2739{_}This action was fought principally by the 1st British Cavalry Brigade and the 4th Guards Brigade and was entirely satisfactory to the British.
10147-8{_}2740{_}The German attack, which was most strongly pressed, was not brought to a standstill until much slaughter had been inflicted upon them and until ten German guns had been captured.
10147-8{_}2741{_}The brunt of this affair fell upon the Guards Brigade, which lost in killed and wounded about 300 men."
10147-8{_}2742{_}This affair was typical of the numerous rearguard engagements fought by both the British and the French forces during their retirement.
10147-8{_}2743{_}MASTERLY TACTICS IN RETIRING  Pressing hard upon the rear of the Allies for ten days was the greatest military machine that has ever been assembled in one cohesive force.
10147-8{_}2744{_}Through Belgium had poured nearly 2,000,000 German troops, made up of about 800,000 first-line soldiers and more than 1,000,000 reserves.
10147-8{_}2745{_}The twenty-six-hour march of part of the German army through Brussels was stunning evidence of the might of the "war machine," and despite fierce fighting all the way, the great army had never faltered in its 150-mile advance in Belgium.
10147-8{_}2746{_}But the numerical might of the German advance was matched by the masterly tactics of the Allies in retiring.
10147-8{_}2747{_}By these tactics, in which General Joffre, the French commander-in-chief, co-operated with the British field-marshal, Sir John French, the Allies prevented their lines being overwhelmed by the superior numbers of their foe, but the German right flank and center, strung out over a line more than 150 miles long, northeast of Paris, kept smashing on.
10147-8{_}2748{_}Losses were frightfully heavy, but the Kaiser's order was "Take Paris!"
10147-8{_}2749{_}It was believed certain that the German general staff had staked everything on investing Paris immediately, by completely breaking down the opposition massed between the German lines and the city.
10147-8{_}2750{_}Paris had therefore prepared for the siege, with her great circles of forts strengthened and her food supply replenished.
10147-8{_}2751{_}Many of the residents fled the city in panic, fearing a repetition of the dread days of 1871, with their privation and distress, but the spirit of the French people generally remained unshaken and General Gallieni, military governor of Paris, assumed complete control of the situation in the city.
10147-8{_}2752{_}GOVERNMENT MOVED TO BORDEAUX  On August 26 the French cabinet had resigned in a body and it was reconstructed on broader lines under Premier Viviani to meet the demands of the national emergency.
10147-8{_}2753{_}German troops were reported within 40 miles of Paris on September 3, and at 3 A. M. of that day a proclamation was issued by President Poincar√©, announcing that the seat of government would be temporarily transferred from Paris to Bordeaux.
10147-8{_}2754{_}The minister of the interior stated that this decision had been taken "solely upon the demand of the military authorities because the fortified places of Paris, while not necessarily likely to be attacked, would become the pivot of the field operations of the two armies."
10147-8{_}2755{_}The text of President Poincar√©'s proclamation was as follows:  "ENDURE AND FIGHT!"
10147-8{_}2756{_}"FEENCHMEN: For several weeks our heroic troops have been engaged in the fierce combat with the enemy.
10147-8{_}2757{_}The courage of our soldiers has won for them a number of marked advantages.
10147-8{_}2758{_}But in the north the pressure of the German forces has constrained us to retire.
10147-8{_}2759{_}This situation imposes on the president of the Republic and the government a painful decision.
10147-8{_}2760{_}"To safeguard the national safety the public authorities are obliged to leave for the moment the city of Paris.
10147-8{_}2761{_}Under the command of its eminent chief, the French army, full of courage and spirit, will defend the capital and its patriotic population against the invader.
10147-8{_}2762{_}But the war must be pursued at the same time in the rest of the French territory.
10147-8{_}2763{_}"The sacred struggle for the honor of the nation and the reparation of violated rights will continue without peace or truce and without a stop or a failure.
10147-8{_}2764{_}None of our armies has been broken.
10147-8{_}2765{_}"If some of them have suffered only too evident losses, the gaps in the ranks have been filled up from the waiting reserve forces, while the calling out of a new class of reserves brings us tomorrow new resources in men and energy.
10147-8{_}2766{_}"Endure and fight!
10147-8{_}2767{_}Such should be the motto of the allied army, British, Russians, Belgians and French.
10147-8{_}2768{_}"Endure and fight!
10147-8{_}2769{_}While on the sea our allies aid us to cut the enemy's communications with the world.
10147-8{_}2770{_}"Endure and fight!
10147-8{_}2771{_}While the Russians continue to carry a decisive blow to the heart of the German empire.
10147-8{_}2772{_}"It is for the government of this republic to direct this resistance to the very end and to give to this formidable struggle all its vigor and efficiency.
10147-8{_}2773{_}It is indispensable that the government retain the mastery of its own actions.
10147-8{_}2774{_}On the demand of the military authorities the government therefore transfers its seat momentarily to a point of the territory whence it may remain in constant relations with the rest of the country.
10147-8{_}2775{_}It invites the members of parliament not to remain distant from the government, in order to form, in the face of the enemy, with the government and their colleagues, a group of national unity.
10147-8{_}2776{_}"The government does not leave Paris without having assured a defense of the city and its entrenched camp by all means in its power.
10147-8{_}2777{_}It knows it has not the need to recommend to the admirable Parisian population a calm resolution and sangfroid, for it shows every day it is equal to its greatest duties.
10147-8{_}2778{_}"Frenchmen, let us all be worthy of these tragic circumstances.
10147-8{_}2779{_}We shall gain a final victory and we shall gain it by untiring will, endurance and tenacity.
10147-8{_}2780{_}A nation that will not perish, and which, to live, retreats before neither suffering nor sacrifice, is sure to vanquish."
10147-8{_}2781{_}The removal of the French government departments to Bordeaux was accomplished within twenty-four hours and the southern city became at once a center of remarkable activity.
10147-8{_}2782{_}Ambassador Herrick, representing the United States, remained in Paris to render aid to his fellow-countrymen who were seeking means of returning to America and were more than ever anxious to get away when a state of siege became imminent.
10147-8{_}2783{_}A radical change in the French military operations was put in effect after the Germans had swept in from Belgium, and had taken the cities of Lille, Roubaix, and Longwy.
10147-8{_}2784{_}The French army had attempted to strike and shatter the Germans at their weakest point, and failed.
10147-8{_}2785{_}Paris prepared for the worst when the Kaiser's conquering army reached La F√®re, about seventy miles away.
10147-8{_}2786{_}From Amiens to La F√®re the Germans pressed their attack hardest.
10147-8{_}2787{_}As the Allies were seen to be gradually falling back, reserve troops were assembled in Paris and the forts put in readiness for siege.
10147-8{_}2788{_}THE FORTIFICATIONS OP PARIS  Paris has one of the strongest fortification systems of any city in the world.
10147-8{_}2789{_}The siege of the giant city would be a much greater undertaking than forty-four years ago, as the fortifications have been essentially augmented and strengthened since the Franco-Prussian war.
10147-8{_}2790{_}[Illustration: MAP OF FRENCH CAPITAL WITH STARS INDICATING POSITION OF FORTIFICATIONS]  The fortifications consist of the old city walls, the old belt of forts and the new enceinture of the fortified camps, which have been advanced far outside of the reach of the old forts.
10147-8{_}2791{_}The main wall, ten meters (33 feet) high, consists of ninety-four bastions and is surrounded by a ditch fifteen meters wide.
10147-8{_}2792{_}Behind the wall a ringroad and a belt line run around the city.
10147-8{_}2793{_}The belt of old forts surrounds this main fortification of the city at a little distance and consists of not less than sixteen forts.
10147-8{_}2794{_}Those farthest advanced are hardly half a mile distant from the main wall.
10147-8{_}2795{_}The experiences of the last war, the immense progress of the artillery, and especially the wider reach of the modern siege guns induced the French army authorities to build a belt of still stronger forts, which surrounds the old fortress of 1870 like a protective net.
10147-8{_}2796{_}The forts, redoubts and batteries belonging to this last belt of fortifications are situated at least two miles from the city limits proper, and even Versailles is taken into this belt of fortifications.
10147-8{_}2797{_}The circumference of the circle formed by them is 124 kilometers (nearly 77 miles) and the space included in it amounts to 1,200 square kilometers.
10147-8{_}2798{_}This new belt of fortifications consists of seven forts of the first class, sixteen forts of the second class and fifty redoubts or batteries, which are connected with each other by the "Great Belt Line," of 113 kilometers (71 miles).
10147-8{_}2799{_}FORM LARGE FORTIFIED CAMPS  The strongest of these forts form fortified camps, large enough to give protection to strong armies and also the possibility for a new reconcentration.
10147-8{_}2800{_}There are three of these camps.
10147-8{_}2801{_}The northern camp includes the fortifications from the Fort de Cormeilles on the left to the Fort de Stains on the right wing, with the forts of the first class, Cormeilles and Domont, and the forts of the second class, Montlignon, Montmorency, Ecouen and Stains, and it is protected in the rear by the strong forts in the vicinity of St. Denis.
10147-8{_}2802{_}The eastern camp goes from the Ourcq canal and the forest of Bondy to the Seine, and its main strongholds are the forts of Vaujours and Villeneuve-St. Georges, with the smaller forts of Chelles, Villiers, Champigny and Sully.
10147-8{_}2803{_}On the left bank of the Seine the southwestern camp is situated, including Versailles, whose main forts are those of St. Cyr, Haut-Bue, Villeras and Palaiseau, to which the large redubt of Bois d'Arey and the forts of Chatillon and Hautes-Bruyeres, situated a little to the rear, belong likewise.
10147-8{_}2804{_}To invest this strongest fortress of the world the line of the Germans ought to have a length of 175 kilometers and to its continuous occupation, even if the ring of the investing masses were not very deep, a much greater number of troops would be necessary than were used in 1870 for the siege of Paris.
10147-8{_}2805{_}GERMAN AMMUNITION CAPTURED  A correspondent at Nanteuil, September 12, thus described the capture of a German ammunition column while the Germans were feeling their way toward Paris:  "The seven-kilometer column was winding its way along Crepy-en-Valois when General Pan sent cavalry and artillery to intercept it.
10147-8{_}2806{_}The column was too weakly guarded to cope with the attack, and so was captured and destroyed.
10147-8{_}2807{_}This capture had an important bearing on the subsequent fighting.
10147-8{_}2808{_}"A noticeable feature of the operations has been the splendid marching qualities of the French troops.
10147-8{_}2809{_}This was displayed especially when two divisions, which were sent to intercept the expected attempt of the Germans to invest Paris, covered eighty kilometers (49¬Ω miles) in two stages."
10147-8{_}2810{_}ALLIES PLAN TO PROTECT PARIS  The plan of the Allies on September 1 was to make a determined stand before Paris, in the effort to protect the city from the horrors of a siege.
10147-8{_}2811{_}With their left wing resting on the strongly fortified line of the Paris forts and with their right wing strengthened by the defensive line from Verdun to Belfort, they would occupy a position of enormous military strength.
10147-8{_}2812{_}If the Germans concentrated to move against their front the French reserve armies could assemble west of the Seine, move forward and attack the German invading columns in flank.
10147-8{_}2813{_}If in their effort to continue the great turning movement the Germans pushed forward across the Seine and attempted by encircling Paris to gain the rear of the allied armies, the French could mass their reserve corps behind their center at Reims, push forward against the weakened German center in an attack that if successful would cut off the German invading columns and expose them to annihilation.
10147-8{_}2814{_}Such were the conditions and the possibilities when the German advance reached its climax on September 4.
10147-8{_}2815{_}[Illustration: POSITION OF HOSTILE ARMIES, SEPTEMBER 4, 1914 Heavy dotted line denotes battle front of the Allies; lighter line the position of the German Troops.]
10147-8{_}2816{_}CHAPTER XI  BATTLE OF THE MARNE    _German Plans Suddenly Changed--Direction of Advance   Swings to the Southeast When Close to the French   Capital--Successful Resistance by the Allies--The   Prolonged Encounter at the Marne--Germans Retreat   With Allies in Hot Pursuit for Many Miles_.
10147-8{_}2817{_}Suddenly the German plans were changed.
10147-8{_}2818{_}With Paris almost in sight, almost within the range of their heavy artillery, the German forces on the right of the line on September 4 changed the direction of their advance to a southeasterly course, which would leave Paris to the west.
10147-8{_}2819{_}The people of the gay capital, who for several days had been preparing themselves once more for the thunder of the Prussian guns, began to breathe more freely, while all the world wondered at the sudden and spectacular transformation in the conditions of the conflict.
10147-8{_}2820{_}What had happened?
10147-8{_}2821{_}Why was the advance thus checked and the march on Paris abandoned?
10147-8{_}2822{_}Was it a trick, designed to lead the Allies into a trap?
10147-8{_}2823{_}Or were the German troops too exhausted by forced marches and lack of rest to face the determined resistance of the allied forces before Paris?
10147-8{_}2824{_}These were the questions on every tongue, on both sides of the Atlantic, while the military experts sought strategic reasons for the change in German plans.
10147-8{_}2825{_}When the movement towards the east began the right of the German forces moved through Beaumont and L'Isle towards Meaux, apparently with the intention of avoiding Paris.
10147-8{_}2826{_}Their front some twenty-four hours later was found to be extending across the River Marne as far south as Conlommiers and La Ferte-Gaucher, the two opposing lines at that time stretching between Paris on the left flank and Verdun on the right.
10147-8{_}2827{_}On Monday, September 7, there came news that the southward movement of the German army had been arrested, and that it had been forced back across the Marne to positions where the German right wing curved back from La Fert√©-sous-Jouarre along the bank of the River Ourcq, a tributary of the Marne, to the northward of Chateau Thierry.
10147-8{_}2828{_}All this territory forms part of the district known as the "Bassin de Paris."
10147-8{_}2829{_}Then came a turn in the tide of war and the German plans were temporarily lost sight of when the Allies assumed the offensive along the Marne and the Ourcq and the Germans began to fall back.
10147-8{_}2830{_}For four days their retreat continued.
10147-8{_}2831{_}Ten miles, thirty miles, forty-five miles, back toward the northeast and east the invaders retired and Paris was relieved.
10147-8{_}2832{_}The tide of battle had thrown the Germans away from the French capital and Frenchmen believed their retirement was permanent.
10147-8{_}2833{_}BATTLE OF THE MARNE  Important and interesting details of the battle of the Marne and the movements that preceded it are given in an official report compiled from information sent from the headquarters of Field Marshal Sir John French (commander-in-chief of the British expeditionary forces), under date of September 11.
10147-8{_}2834{_}This account describes the movements both of the British force and of the French armies in immediate touch with it.
10147-8{_}2835{_}It carries the operations from the 4th to the 10th of September, both days inclusive, and says:  "The general position of our troops Sunday, September 6, was south of the River Marne, with the French forces in line on our right and left.
10147-8{_}2836{_}Practically there had been no change since Saturday, September 5, which marked the end of our army's long retirement from the Belgian frontier through Northern France.
10147-8{_}2837{_}"On Friday, September 4, it became apparent that there was an alteration in the advance of almost the whole of the first German army.
10147-8{_}2838{_}That army since the battle near Mons on the 23d of August had been playing its part in a colossal strategic endeavor to create a Sedan for the Allies by out-flanking and enveloping the left of their whole line so as to encircle and drive both the British and French to the south.
10147-8{_}2839{_}THE CHANGE IN GERMAN STRATEGY  "There was now a change in its objective and it was observed that the German forces opposite the British were beginning to move in a southeasterly direction instead of continuing southwest on to the capital, leaving a strong rear guard along the line of the River Ourcq (which flows south of and joins the Marne at Lizy-sur-Ourcq) to keep off the French Sixth Army, which by then had been formed and was to the northwest of Paris.
10147-8{_}2840{_}They were evidently executing what amounted to a flank march diagonally across our front.
10147-8{_}2841{_}"Prepared to ignore the British as being driven out of the fight, they were initiating an effort to attack the left flank of the main French army, which stretched in a long curved line from our right toward the east, and so to carry out against it alone an envelopment which so far had failed against the combined forces of the Allies.
10147-8{_}2842{_}"On Saturday, the 5th, this movement on the part of the Germans was continued and large advance parties crossed the Marne southward at Trilport, Sammeron, La Ferte-sous-Jouarre and Chateau Thierry.
10147-8{_}2843{_}There was considerable fighting with the French Fifth Army on the French left, which fell back from its position south of the Marne toward the Seine.
10147-8{_}2844{_}"On Sunday large hostile forces crossed the Marne and pushed on through Coulommiers and past the British right, farther to the east.
10147-8{_}2845{_}They were attacked at night by the French Fifth, which captured three villages at the point of bayonets.
10147-8{_}2846{_}ALLIES TAKE THE OFFENSIVE  "On Monday, September 7, there was a general advance on the part of the Allies.
10147-8{_}2847{_}In this quarter of the field our forces, which had now been reinforced, pushed on in a northeasterly direction in co-operation with the advance of the French Fifth Army to the north and of the French Sixth Army to the eastward against the German rearguard along the River Ourcq.
10147-8{_}2848{_}"Possibly weakened by the detachment of troops to the eastern theater of operations and realizing that the action of the French Sixth Army against the line of Ourcq and the advance of the British placed their own flanking movement in considerable danger of being taken in the rear and on its flank, the Germans on this day commenced to retire toward the northeast.
10147-8{_}2849{_}"This was the first time that these troops had turned back since their attack at Mons a fortnight before and from reports received the order to retreat when so close to Paris was a bitter disappointment.
10147-8{_}2850{_}From letters found on dead soldiers there is no doubt there was a general impression among the enemy's troops that they were about to enter Paris.
10147-8{_}2851{_}GERMAN RETREAT IS HASTENED  "On Tuesday, September 8, the German movement north-eastward was continued.
10147-8{_}2852{_}Their rear guards on the south of the Marne were being pressed back to that river by our troops and by the French on our right, the latter capturing three villages after a hand-to-hand fight and the infliction of severe loss on the enemy.
10147-8{_}2853{_}"The fighting along the Ourcq continued on this day and was of the most sanguinary character, for the Germans had massed a great force of artillery along this line.
10147-8{_}2854{_}Very few of their infantry were seen by the French.
10147-8{_}2855{_}The French Fifth Army also made a fierce attack on the Germans in Montmirail, regaining that place.
10147-8{_}2856{_}"On Wednesday, September 9, the battle between the French Sixth Army and what was now the German flank guard along the Ourcq continued.
10147-8{_}2857{_}"The British corps, overcoming some resistance on the River Petit Morin, crossed the Marne in pursuit of the Germans, who now were hastily retreating northwest.
10147-8{_}2858{_}One of our corps was delayed by an obstinate defense made by a strong rear guard with machine guns at La Ferte-sous-Jouarre, where the bridge had been destroyed.
10147-8{_}2859{_}"On Thursday, September 10, the French Sixth Army continued its pressure on the west while the Fifth Army by forced marches reached the line of Chateau Thierry and Dormans on the Marne.
10147-8{_}2860{_}Our troops also continued the pursuit on the north of the latter river and after a considerable amount of fighting captured some 1,500 prisoners, four guns, six machine guns and fifty transport wagons.
10147-8{_}2861{_}"Many of the enemy were killed or wounded and the numerous thick woods which dot the country north of the Marne are filled with German stragglers.
10147-8{_}2862{_}Most of them appear to have been without food for at least two days.
10147-8{_}2863{_}"Indeed, in this area of the operations, the Germans seem to be demoralized and inclined to surrender in small parties.
10147-8{_}2864{_}The general situation appears to be most favorable to the Allies.
10147-8{_}2865{_}"Much brutal and senseless damage has been done in the villages occupied by the enemy.
10147-8{_}2866{_}Property has been wantonly destroyed.
10147-8{_}2867{_}Pictures in chateaus have been ripped up and houses generally have been pillaged.
10147-8{_}2868{_}"It is stated on unimpeachable authority also that the inhabitants have been much ill-treated.
10147-8{_}2869{_}TRAPPED IN A SUNKEN ROAD  "Interesting incidents have occurred during the fighting.
10147-8{_}2870{_}On the 10th of September part of our Second Army Corps, advancing into the north, found itself marching parallel with another infantry force some little distance away.
10147-8{_}2871{_}At first it was thought this was another British unit.
10147-8{_}2872{_}After some time, however, it was discovered that it was a body of Germans retreating.
10147-8{_}2873{_}"Measures promptly were taken to head off the enemy, who were surrounded and trapped in a sunken road, where over 400 men surrendered.
10147-8{_}2874{_}"On September 10 a small party under a noncommissioned officer was cut off and surrounded.
10147-8{_}2875{_}After a desperate resistance it was decided to go on fighting to the end.
10147-8{_}2876{_}Finally the noncommissioned officer and one man only were left, both of them being wounded.
10147-8{_}2877{_}"The Germans came up and shouted to them: 'Lay down your arms!'
10147-8{_}2878{_}The German commander, however, signed to them to keep their arms and then asked to shake hands with the wounded noncommissioned officer, who was carried off on his stretcher with his rifle by his side.
10147-8{_}2879{_}"Arrival of reinforcements and the continued advance have delighted our troops, who are full of zeal and anxious to press on.
10147-8{_}2880{_}SUCCESS OF THE FLYING CORPS  "One of the features of the campaign on our side has been the success obtained by the Royal Flying Corps.
10147-8{_}2881{_}In regard to the collection of information it is impossible either to award too much praise to our aviators for the way they have carried out their duties or to overestimate the value of the intelligence collected, more especially during the recent advance.
10147-8{_}2882{_}"In due course certain examples of what has been effected may be specified and the far-reaching nature of the results fully explained, but that time has not arrived.
10147-8{_}2883{_}"That the services of our Flying Corps, which, has really been on trial, are fully appreciated by our allies is shown by the following message from the commander-in-chief of the French armies, received September by Field Marshal Lord Kitchener:    "'Please express most particularly to Marshal French   my thanks for the services rendered on every day by the   English flying corps.
10147-8{_}2884{_}The precision, exactitude and regularity   of the news brought in by its members are evidence of   their perfect organization and also of the perfect training   of the pilots and the observers.--JOSEPH JOFFRE, General,'  "To give a rough idea of the amount of work carried out it is sufficient to mention that during a period of twenty days up to the 10th of September a daily average of more than nine reconnaissance flights of over 100 miles each has been maintained.
10147-8{_}2885{_}FIVE GERMAN PILOTS SHOT  "The constant object of our aviators has been to effect an accurate location of the enemy's forces and, incidentally, since the operations cover so large an area, of our own units.
10147-8{_}2886{_}Nevertheless, the tactics adopted for dealing with hostile air craft are to attack them instantly with one or more British machines.
10147-8{_}2887{_}This has been so far successful that in five cases German pilots or observers have been shot while in the air and their machines brought to ground.
10147-8{_}2888{_}"As a consequence the British Flying Corps has succeeded in establishing an individual ascendancy which is as serviceable to us as it is dangerous to the enemy.
10147-8{_}2889{_}"How far it is due to this cause it is not possible at present to ascertain definitely, but the fact remains that the enemy have recently become much less enterprising in their flights.
10147-8{_}2890{_}Something in the direction of the mastery of the air already has been gained in pursuance of the principle that the main object of military aviators is the collection of information.
10147-8{_}2891{_}"Bomb dropping has not been indulged in to any great extent.
10147-8{_}2892{_}On one occasion a petrol bomb was successfully exploded in a German bivouac at night, while from a diary found on a dead German cavalry soldier it has been discovered that a high explosive bomb, thrown at a cavalry column from one of our aeroplanes, struck an ammunition wagon, resulting in an explosion which killed fifteen of the enemy."
10147-8{_}2893{_}LOSSES AT THE MARNE ENORMOUS  Some idea of the terrific character of the fighting at the Marne and of the great losses in the prolonged battle may be gained from the following story, telegraphed on September 14 by a correspondent who followed in the rear of the allied army:  "General von Kluck's host in coming down over the Marne and the Grand Morin rivers to Sezanne, twenty-five miles southwest of Epernay, met little opposition, and I believe little opposition was intended.
10147-8{_}2894{_}The Allies, in fact, led their opponents straight into a trap.
10147-8{_}2895{_}The English cavalry led the tired Germans mile after mile, and the Germans believed the Englishmen were running away.
10147-8{_}2896{_}When the tremendous advance reached Provins the Allies' plan was accomplished, and it got no farther.
10147-8{_}2897{_}"Fighting Sunday, September 6, was of a terrible character, and began at dawn in the region of La Ferte-Gaucher.
10147-8{_}2898{_}The Allies' troops, who were drawn up to receive the Germans, understood it would be their duty to hold on their very best that the attacking force at Meaux might achieve its task in security.
10147-8{_}2899{_}The battle lasted all night and until late Monday.
10147-8{_}2900{_}"The Germany artillery fire was very severe, but not accurate.
10147-8{_}2901{_}The French and English fought sternly on and slowly beat the enemy back.
10147-8{_}2902{_}"Attempts of the Germans to cross the Marne at Meaux entailed terrible losses.
10147-8{_}2903{_}Sixteen attempts were foiled by the French artillery fire directed on the river and in one trench 600 dead Germans were counted.
10147-8{_}2904{_}COUNTRY STREWN WITH DEAD  "The whole country was strewn with the dead and dying.
10147-8{_}2905{_}When at last the Germans retired they slackened their rifle fire and in once place retired twelve miles without firing a single shot.
10147-8{_}2906{_}One prisoner declared that they were short of ammunition and had been told to spare it as much as possible.
10147-8{_}2907{_}"Monday saw a tremendous encounter on the Oureq.
10147-8{_}2908{_}In one village, which the Germans hurriedly vacated, the French in a large house found a dinner table beautifully set, with candles still burning on the table, where evidently the German staff had been dining.
10147-8{_}2909{_}A woman occupant said they fled precipitately.
10147-8{_}2910{_}"There was a great deal of hand-to-hand fighting and bayonet work on the Ourcq, which resulted in the terrible Magdeburg regiment beating a retreat.
10147-8{_}2911{_}"Monday night General von Kluck's army had been thrown back from the Marne and from the Morin and to the region of Sezanne and his position was serious.
10147-8{_}2912{_}Immediate steps were necessary to save his line of communications and retreat.
10147-8{_}2913{_}To this end reinforcements were hurried north to the Meaux district and the Ourcq and tremendous efforts were made to break up the French resistance in this section.
10147-8{_}2914{_}GERMAN GUNS ARE SILENCED  "The second attempt on the Oureq shared the fate of the first.
10147-8{_}2915{_}Though all Monday night and well on into Tuesday the great German guns boomed along this river, the resistance of the allies could not be broken.
10147-8{_}2916{_}'Hold on!'
10147-8{_}2917{_}was the command and every man braced himself to obey.
10147-8{_}2918{_}While the Ourcq was being held the struggle of Sezanne was bearing fruit.
10147-8{_}2919{_}"The German resistance on Thursday morning was broken.
10147-8{_}2920{_}I heard the news in two ways: from the silence of the German guns and from the wounded who poured down to the bases.
10147-8{_}2921{_}"The wounded men no longer were downhearted, but eager to rejoin the fray.
10147-8{_}2922{_}On every French lip was the exclamation that 'They are in full retreat!'
10147-8{_}2923{_}and 'They are rushing back home!'
10147-8{_}2924{_}and in the same breath came generous recognition of the great help given by the British army.
10147-8{_}2925{_}"The number of wounded entailed colossal transportation work.
10147-8{_}2926{_}I counted fifteen trains in eight hours.
10147-8{_}2927{_}A fine, grim set of men, terribly weary but amiable, except for the officers.
10147-8{_}2928{_}GERMANS LEAVE SPOILS BEHIND  "The enemy crossed the Marne on the return journey north under great difficulties and beneath a withering fire from the British troops, who pursued them hotly.
10147-8{_}2929{_}The German artillery operated from a height.
10147-8{_}2930{_}There was again much hand-to-hand fighting and the river was swollen with dead.
10147-8{_}2931{_}"Tuesday night the British were in possession of La Ferte-sous-Jouarre and Chateau Thierry and the Germans had fallen back forty miles, leaving a long train of spoils behind them.
10147-8{_}2932{_}"On the same day, in the neighborhood of Vitry-le-Fran√ßois, the French troops achieved a victory.
10147-8{_}2933{_}Incidentally they drove back the famous Imperial Guard of Germany from Sezanne, toward the swamps of Saint Cond, where, a century ago, Napoleon achieved one of his last successes.
10147-8{_}2934{_}The main body of the guard passed to the north of the swamps, but I heard of men and horses engulfed and destroyed.
10147-8{_}2935{_}"'It is our revenge for 1814,' the French officers said.
10147-8{_}2936{_}'If only the emperor were here to see.'
10147-8{_}2937{_}BRITISH KEEP UP PURSUIT  "Wednesday the English army continued the pursuit toward the north, taking guns and prisoners.
10147-8{_}2938{_}"On that day I found myself in a new France.
10147-8{_}2939{_}The good news had spread.
10147-8{_}2940{_}Girls threw flowers at the passing soldiers and joy was manifested everywhere.
10147-8{_}2941{_}"The incidents of Wednesday will astound the world when made known in full.
10147-8{_}2942{_}I know that two German detachments of 1,000 men each, which were surrounded and cornered but which refused to surrender, were wiped out almost to the last man.
10147-8{_}2943{_}The keynote of these operations was the tremendous attack of the Allies along the Ourcq Tuesday, which showed the German commander that his lines were threatened.
10147-8{_}2944{_}Then came the crowning stroke.
10147-8{_}2945{_}"The army of the Ourcq and of Meaux and the army of Sezanne drew together like the blades of a pair of shears, the pivot of which was in the region of the Grand Morin.
10147-8{_}2946{_}The German retreat was thus forced toward the east and it speedily became a rout."
10147-8{_}2947{_}RETREAT SEEN FROM THE SKY  The best view of the retreating German armies was obtained, according to a Paris report, by a French military airman, who, ascending from a point near Vitry, flew northward across the Marne and then eastward by way of Rheims down to the region of Verdun and back again in a zigzag course to a spot near Soissons.
10147-8{_}2948{_}He saw the German hosts not merely in retreat, but in flight, and in some places in disorderly flight.
10147-8{_}2949{_}"It was a wonderful sight," the airman said, "to look down upon these hundreds and thousands of moving military columns, the long gray lines of the Kaiser's picked troops, some marching in a northerly, others in a northeasterly direction, and all moving with a tremendous rapidity.
10147-8{_}2950{_}"The retreat was not confined to the highways, but many German soldiers were running across fields, jumping over fences, crawling through hedges, and making their way through woods without any semblance of order or discipline.
10147-8{_}2951{_}"These men doubtless belonged to regiments which were badly cut up in the fierce fighting which preceded the general retreat.
10147-8{_}2952{_}Deprived of the majority of their officers, they made a mere rabble of fugitives, Many were without rifles, having abandoned their weapons in their haste to escape their French and British pursuers."
10147-8{_}2953{_}GERMANS ABANDON GUNS  The London Times correspondent describes the German retreat in a hurricane, with rain descending in torrents, the wayside brooks swollen to little torrents.
10147-8{_}2954{_}"The gun wheels sank deep in the mud, and the soldiers,   unable to extricate them, abandoned the guns," he said.
10147-8{_}2955{_}"A wounded soldier, returned from the front, told me   that the Germans fled as animals flee which are cornered and   know it.
10147-8{_}2956{_}"Imagine the roadway littered with guns, knapsacks, cartridge   belts, Maxims and heavy cannon.
10147-8{_}2957{_}There were miles of   roads like this.
10147-8{_}2958{_}"And the dead!
10147-8{_}2959{_}Those piles of horses and those stacks   of men I have seen again and again.
10147-8{_}2960{_}I have seen men shot so   close to one another that they remained standing after death.
10147-8{_}2961{_}"At night time the sight was horrible beyond description.
10147-8{_}2962{_}They cannot bury whole armies.
10147-8{_}2963{_}"In the day time over the fields of dead carrion birds   gathered, led by the gray-throated crow of evil omen with a   host of lesser marauders at his back.
10147-8{_}2964{_}Robbers, too, have   descended upon these fields.
10147-8{_}2965{_}"Trainload after trainload of British and French troops   swept toward the weak points of the retreating host.
10147-8{_}2966{_}"The Allies benefited by this advantage of the battle-ground;   there is a network of railways, like the network of a   spider's web."
10147-8{_}2967{_}FIGHTING DESCRIBED BY U.S. OFFICERS  Two military attaches of the United States embassy at Paris, Lieut.-Col. H. T. Allen and Capt.
10147-8{_}2968{_}Frank Parker, both of the Eleventh cavalry, U.S.A., returned on September 15 from an automobile trip over the battlefield where from September 8 until the night of September 11 the French and Germans were fiercely engaged.
10147-8{_}2969{_}This battle was the one which assured the safety of Paris.
10147-8{_}2970{_}On September 1 the German left and center were separated, but like a letter "V" were approaching each other, with Paris as their objective.
10147-8{_}2971{_}Had the Allies attacked at that time they would have had to divide their forces and, so weakened, give battle to two armies.
10147-8{_}2972{_}By retreating they drew after them the two converging lines of the V and when the Germans were in wedge-shaped formation, attacked them on the flank and center at Meaux and made a direct attack at Sezanne.
10147-8{_}2973{_}The four days' battle at Meaux ended with the Germans crossing the river Aisne and retreating to the hills north and west of Soissons.
10147-8{_}2974{_}Col. Allen and Capt.
10147-8{_}2975{_}Parker saw the end of the battle north of Sezanne, which resulted in the retreat of the Germans to Rheims.
10147-8{_}2976{_}The battles, as Col. Allen and Capt.
10147-8{_}2977{_}Parker describe them, were as follows:  On the 8th the Germans advanced from a line stretching from Epernay and Chalons, a distance of twenty-five kilometers (sixteen miles).
10147-8{_}2978{_}In this front, counting from the German right, were the Tenth, the Guards, the Ninth and Twelfth Army Corps.
10147-8{_}2979{_}The presence of the Guards, the _corps d'elite_ of the German army, suggested that this was intended to be a main attack upon Paris and that the army at Meaux was to occupy the center.
10147-8{_}2980{_}The four combined corps numbered over 200,000.
10147-8{_}2981{_}The French met them, they assert, with 190,000.
10147-8{_}2982{_}The Germans advanced until their left was at Vitry-le-Francois and their right rested at Sezanne, making a column 15 miles long, headed west toward Paris.
10147-8{_}2983{_}The French butted the line six miles east of Sezanne, in the forests of La Fere and Champenoise.
10147-8{_}2984{_}It was here that the greater part of the fight occurred.
10147-8{_}2985{_}It was fighting at long distance with artillery and from trench to trench with the bayonet.
10147-8{_}2986{_}THIRTY THOUSAND MEN KILLED  During the four days in which fortune rested first on one flag and then on another 30,000 men of both armies are said to have been killed and a considerable number of villages were wiped from the map by the artillery of both armies.
10147-8{_}2987{_}Two miles from Sezanne a French regiment was destroyed by an ambush.
10147-8{_}2988{_}The Germans had thrown up conspicuous trenches and with decoys sparsely filled them.
10147-8{_}2989{_}From the forest in the rear the mitrailleuse was trained on the French.
10147-8{_}2990{_}The French infantry charged this trench and the decoys fled, making toward the flanks, and as the French poured over the trenches the hidden guns swept them.
10147-8{_}2991{_}In another trench the American attaches counted the bodies of more than 900 German guards, not one of whom had attempted to retreat.
10147-8{_}2992{_}They had stood fast with their shoulders against the parapet and taken the cold steel.
10147-8{_}2993{_}Everywhere the loss of life was appalling.
10147-8{_}2994{_}In places the dead lay across each other three and four deep.
10147-8{_}2995{_}TURCOS FIERCEST FIGHTERS OF ALL  "The fiercest fighting of all seems to have been done by the Turcos and Senegalese.
10147-8{_}2996{_}In trenches taken by them from the guards and the famous Death's Head Hussars, the Germans showed no bullet wounds.
10147-8{_}2997{_}In nearly every attack the men from the desert had flung themselves upon the enemy, using only the butt or the bayonet.
10147-8{_}2998{_}Man for man no white man drugged for years with meat and alcohol is a physical match for these Turcos, who eat dates and drink water," said Richard Harding Davis, who saw the end of the fighting at Meaux.
10147-8{_}2999{_}"They are as lean as starved wolves.
10147-8{_}3000{_}They move like panthers.
10147-8{_}3001{_}They are muscle and nerves and they have the warrior's disregard of their own personal safety in battle, and a perfect scorn of the foe.
10147-8{_}3002{_}"As Kipling says, 'A man who has a sneaking desire to live has a poor chance against one who is indifferent whether he kills you or you kill him.'"
10147-8{_}3003{_}NIGHT BATTLE DESCRIBED BY SOLDIER  The following narrative of a night engagement during the prolonged battle of the Marne is quoted from a French soldier's letter to a compatriot in London:  "Our strength was about 400 infantrymen.
10147-8{_}3004{_}Toward midnight we broke up our camp and marched off in great silence, of course not in closed files, but in open order.
10147-8{_}3005{_}We were not allowed to speak to each other or to make any unnecessary noise, and as we walked through the forest the only sound to be heard was that of our steps and the rustling of the leaves.
10147-8{_}3006{_}It was a perfectly lovely night; the sky was so clear, the atmosphere so pure, the forest so romantic, everything seemed so charming and peaceful that I could not imagine that we were on the warpath, and that perhaps in a few hours this forest would be aflame, the soil drenched by human blood, and the fragrant herbs covered with broken limbs.
10147-8{_}3007{_}"Yet all those silent, armed men, marching in the same direction as I did, were ever so many proofs that no peace meeting or any delightful romantic adventure was near, and I wondered what thoughts were stirring all those brains.
10147-8{_}3008{_}Suddenly a whisper passed on from man to man.
10147-8{_}3009{_}It was the officer's command.
10147-8{_}3010{_}A halt was made, and in the same whisper we were told that part of us had to change our direction so that the two directions would form a V. A third division proceeded slowly in the original direction.
10147-8{_}3011{_}COMMANDS ARE WHISPERED  "I belonged to what may be called the left leg of the V. After what seemed to be about half an hour, we reached the edge of the forest, and from behind the trees we saw an almost flat country before us, with here and there a tiny little hill, a mere hump four or five feet high.
10147-8{_}3012{_}On the extreme left-hand side the land seemed to be intersected by ditches and trenches.
10147-8{_}3013{_}"Another whispered command was passed from man to man, and we all had to lie down on the soil.
10147-8{_}3014{_}A moment afterward we were thus making our way to the above-mentioned ditches and trenches.
10147-8{_}3015{_}It is neither the easiest nor the quickest way to move, but undoubtedly the safest, for an occasional enemy somewhere on the hills at the farther end of the field would not possibly be able to detect us.
10147-8{_}3016{_}I don't know how long it took us to reach the ditches, which were, for the greater part, dry; nor do I know how long we remained there or what was happening.
10147-8{_}3017{_}We were perfectly hidden from view, lying flat down on our stomachs, but we were also unable to see anything.
10147-8{_}3018{_}Everybody's ears were attentive, every nerve was strained.
10147-8{_}3019{_}The sun was rising.
10147-8{_}3020{_}It promised to be a hot day.
10147-8{_}3021{_}FIRST SHOT IS HEARD  "Suddenly we heard a shot, at a distance of what seemed to be a mile or so, followed by several other shots.
10147-8{_}3022{_}I ventured to lift my body up in order to see what was happening.
10147-8{_}3023{_}But the next moment my sergeant, who was close by me, warned me with a knock on my shoulder not to move, and the whispered order ran, 'Keep quiet!
10147-8{_}3024{_}Hide yourself!'
10147-8{_}3025{_}Still, the short glance had been sufficient to see what was going on.
10147-8{_}3026{_}Our troops, probably those who had been left behind in the forest, were crossing the plain and shooting at the Germans on the crest of the hill, who returned the fire.
10147-8{_}3027{_}"The silence was gone.
10147-8{_}3028{_}We heard the rushing of feet at a short distance; then, suddenly, it ceased when the attacking soldiers dropped to aim and shoot.
10147-8{_}3029{_}Some firing was heard, and then again a swift rush followed.
10147-8{_}3030{_}This seemed to last a long time, but it was broken by distant cries, coming apparently from the enemy.
10147-8{_}3031{_}I was wondering all the time why we kept hidden and did not share in the assault.
10147-8{_}3032{_}"The rifle fire was incessant.
10147-8{_}3033{_}I saw nothing of the battle.
10147-8{_}3034{_}Would, our troops be able to repulse the Germans?
10147-8{_}3035{_}How strong were the enemy!
10147-8{_}3036{_}They seemed to have no guns, but the number of our soldiers in that field was not very large.
10147-8{_}3037{_}ATTACKED WITH BAYONETS  "A piercing yell rose from the enemy.
10147-8{_}3038{_}Was it a cry of triumph?
10147-8{_}3039{_}A short command rang over the field in French, an order to retreat.
10147-8{_}3040{_}A swift rush followed; our troops were being pursued by the enemy.
10147-8{_}3041{_}What on earth were we waiting for in our ditches?
10147-8{_}3042{_}A bugle signal, clear and bright.
10147-8{_}3043{_}We sprang to our feet, and 'At the bayonet!'
10147-8{_}3044{_}the order came.
10147-8{_}3045{_}We threw ourselves on the enemy, who were at the same time attacked on the other side by the division which formed the other 'leg' of the V, while the 'fleeing' French soldiers turned and made a savage attack.
10147-8{_}3046{_}"It is impossible to say or to describe what one feels at such a moment.
10147-8{_}3047{_}I believe one is in a state of temporary madness, of perfect rage.
10147-8{_}3048{_}It is terrible, and if we could see ourselves in such a state I feel sure we would shrink with horror.
10147-8{_}3049{_}"In a few minutes the field was covered with dead and wounded men, almost all of them Germans, and our hands and bayonets were dripping with blood.
10147-8{_}3050{_}I felt hot spurts of blood in my face, of other men's blood, and as I paused to wipe them off, I saw a narrow stream of blood running along the barrel of my rifle.
10147-8{_}3051{_}"Such was the beginning of a summer day."
10147-8{_}3052{_}SCENES ON THE BATTLEFIELD  Writing from Sezanne a few days after the battle of the Marne a visitor to the battlefield described the conditions at that time as follows:  "The territory over which the battle of the Marne was fought is now a picture of devastation, abomination and death almost too awful to describe.
10147-8{_}3053{_}"Many sons of the fatherland are sleeping their last sleep in the open fields and in ditches where they fell or under hedges where they crawled after being caught by a rifle bullet or piece of shell, or where they sought shelter from the mad rush of the franc-tireurs, who have not lost their natural dexterity with the knife and who at close quarters frequently throw away their rifles and fight hand to hand.
10147-8{_}3054{_}"The German prisoners are being used on the battlefield in searching for and burying their dead comrades.
10147-8{_}3055{_}Over the greater part of the huge battlefield there have been buried at least those who died in open trenches on the plateaus or on the high roads.
10147-8{_}3056{_}The extensive forest area, however, has hardly been searched for bodies, although hundreds of both French and Germans must have sought refuge and died there.
10147-8{_}3057{_}The difficulty of finding bodies is considerable on account of the undergrowth.
10147-8{_}3058{_}"Long lines of newly broken brown earth mark the graves of the victims.
10147-8{_}3059{_}Some of these burial trenches are 150 yards long.
10147-8{_}3060{_}The dead are placed shoulder to shoulder and often in layers.
10147-8{_}3061{_}This gives some idea of the slaughter that took place in this battle.
10147-8{_}3062{_}"The peasants, who are rapidly coming back to the scene, are marking the grave trenches with crosses and planting flowers above or placing on them simple bouquets of dahlias, sunflowers and roses.
10147-8{_}3063{_}FOUGHT ON BEAUTIFUL CHATEAU LAWNS  "Some of the hottest fighting of the prolonged battle took place around the beautiful chateau of Mondement, on a hill six miles east of Sezanne.
10147-8{_}3064{_}This relic of the architectural art of Louis XIV occupied a position which both sides regarded as strategically important.
10147-8{_}3065{_}"To the east it looked down into a great declivity in the shape of an immense Greek lamp, with the concealed marshes of St. Sond at the bottom.
10147-8{_}3066{_}Beyond are the downs and heaths of Epernay, Rheims and Champagne, while the heights of Argonne stand out boldly in the distance.
10147-8{_}3067{_}To the west is a rich agricultural country.
10147-8{_}3068{_}"The possession of the ridge of Mondement was vital to either the attackers or the defenders.
10147-8{_}3069{_}The conflict here was of furnace intensity for four days.
10147-8{_}3070{_}The Germans drove the French out in a terrific assault, and then the French guns were brought to bear, followed by hand-to-hand fighting on the gardens and lawns of the chateau and even through the breached walls.
10147-8{_}3071{_}"Frenchmen again held the building for a few hours, only to retire before another determined German attack.
10147-8{_}3072{_}On the fourth day they swept the Germans out again with shell fire, under which the walls of the chateau, although two or three feet thick, crumpled like paper."
10147-8{_}3073{_}The same correspondent described evidences on the battlefields of how abundantly the Germans were equipped with ammunition and other material.
10147-8{_}3074{_}He saw pyramid after pyramid of shrapnel shells abandoned in the rout, also innumerable paniers for carrying such ammunition.
10147-8{_}3075{_}These paniers are carefully constructed of wicker and hold three shells in exactly fitting tubes so that there can be no movement.
10147-8{_}3076{_}The villages of Oyes, Villeneuve, Chatillon and Soizy-aux-Bois were all bombarded and completely destroyed.
10147-8{_}3077{_}Some fantastic capers were played by the shells, such as blowing away half a house and leaving the other half intact; going through a window and out by the back wall without damaging the interior, or going a few inches into the wall and remaining fast without exploding.
10147-8{_}3078{_}Villeneuve, which was retaken three times, was, including its fine old church, in absolute ruins.
10147-8{_}3079{_}A SERIES OF BATTLES  The battle line along the Marne was so extended that the four-days' fighting from Sunday, September 6, to Thursday morning, September 10, when the Germans were in full retreat, comprised a series of bloody engagements, each worthy of being called a battle.
10147-8{_}3080{_}There were hot encounters south of the Marne at Crecy, Montmirail and other points.
10147-8{_}3081{_}At Chalons-sur-Marne the French fought for twenty-four hours and inflicted heavy losses on the enemy.
10147-8{_}3082{_}General Exelmans, one of France's most brilliant cavalry leaders, was dangerously wounded in leading a charge.
10147-8{_}3083{_}There was hard fighting on September 7 between Lagny and Meaux, on the Trilport and Crecy-en-Brie line, the Germans under General von Kluck being compelled to give way and retire on Meaux, at which point their resistance was broken on the 9th.
10147-8{_}3084{_}General French's army advanced to meet the German hosts with forced marches from their temporary base to the southeast of Paris.
10147-8{_}3085{_}The whole British army, except cavalry, passed through Lagny, and the incoming troops were so wearied that many of them at the first opportunity lay down in the dust and slept where they were.
10147-8{_}3086{_}But a few hours' rest worked a great change, and a little later the British troops were following the German retreat up the valley with bulldog tenacity.
10147-8{_}3087{_}The British artillery did notable work in those days, according to the French military surgeons who were stationed at Lagny.
10147-8{_}3088{_}At points near there the bodies of slain Germans who fell before the British gunners still littered the ground on September 10, and the grim crop was still heavier on the soil farther up the valley, where the fighting was more desperate.
10147-8{_}3089{_}As far as possible the bodies were buried at night, each attending to its own fallen.
10147-8{_}3090{_}MANY SANGUINARY INCIDENTS  Sanguinary incidents were plentiful in the week of fighting to the south of the Marne.
10147-8{_}3091{_}In an engagement not far from Lagny the British captured thirty Germans who had given up their arms and were standing under guard when, encouraged by a sudden forward effort of the German front, they made a dash for their rifles.
10147-8{_}3092{_}They were cut down by a volley from their British guards before they could reach their weapons.
10147-8{_}3093{_}"Among dramatic incidents in the fighting," according to an English correspondent, "may be mentioned the grim work at the ancient fishponds near Ermenonville.
10147-8{_}3094{_}These ponds are shut in by high trees.
10147-8{_}3095{_}Driving the enemy through the woods, a Scotch regiment hustled its foes right into the fishponds, the Scotchmen jumping in after the Germans up to the middle to finish them in the water, which was packed with their bodies."
10147-8{_}3096{_}This scene is illustrated on another page.
10147-8{_}3097{_}VAST GRAVEYARD AT MEAUX  Some idea of how the Germans were harassed by artillery fire during their retreat was obtained on a visit to the fields near Meaux, the scene of severe fighting.
10147-8{_}3098{_}The German infantry had taken a position in a sunken road, on either side of which were stretched in extended lines hummocks, some of them natural and some the work of spades in the hands of German soldiers.
10147-8{_}3099{_}The sunken road was littered with bodies.
10147-8{_}3100{_}Sprawling in ghastly fashion, the faces had almost the same greenish-gray hue as the uniforms worn.
10147-8{_}3101{_}The road is lined with poplars, the branches of which, severed by fragments of shells, were strewn among the dead.
10147-8{_}3102{_}In places whole tops of trees had been torn away by the artillery fire.
10147-8{_}3103{_}Beside many bodies were forty or fifty empty cartridge shells, while fragments of clothing, caps and knapsacks were scattered about.
10147-8{_}3104{_}This destruction was wrought by batteries a little more than three miles distant.
10147-8{_}3105{_}Straggling clumps of wood intervened between the batteries and their mark, but the range had been determined by an officer on an elevation a mile from the gunners.
10147-8{_}3106{_}He telephoned directions for the firing and through glasses watched the bursting shells.
10147-8{_}3107{_}THE BATTLE AT CRECY  A graphic picture of the fight in Crecy wood was given by a correspondent who said: The French and English in overwhelming numbers had poured in from Lagny toward the River Marne to reinforce the flanking skirmishers.
10147-8{_}3108{_}One of the smaller woods southeast of Crecy furnished cover for the enemy for a time, but led to their undoing.
10147-8{_}3109{_}The Allies' patrols discovered them in the night as the Germans were moving about with lanterns.
10147-8{_}3110{_}Suddenly the invaders found their twinkling glow-worms the mark for a foe of whom they had been unaware.
10147-8{_}3111{_}Without warning a midnight hail storm from Maxims screamed through the trees.
10147-8{_}3112{_}The next morning scores of lanterns were picked up in the wood, with the glasses shattered.
10147-8{_}3113{_}A dashing cavalry charge by the British finally cleared the tragic wood of the Germans.
10147-8{_}3114{_}BRITISH BLOW UP A BRIDGE  At Lagny one of the sights of the town was a shattered bridge, which was blown up by General French as soon as he got his army across it.
10147-8{_}3115{_}At that time British infantry and artillery had poured through the town and over the bridge for several days.
10147-8{_}3116{_}General French's idea was to keep raiding detachments of German cavalry from incursions into the beautiful villas and gardens of the western suburbs.
10147-8{_}3117{_}Fifteen minutes after the bridge had been reduced to a twisted mass of steel and broken masonry a belated order came to save it, but the British engineers who had received the order to destroy it had done their work well.
10147-8{_}3118{_}The inhabitants were cleared out of all the neighboring houses, which were shaken by the terrific explosion when the charge was set off.
10147-8{_}3119{_}Every window in the nearby houses was shattered.
10147-8{_}3120{_}The people of Lagny took the destruction of their beautiful bridge in good part.
10147-8{_}3121{_}They were too grateful for their deliverance from the Germans to grumble about the wrecked bridge.
10147-8{_}3122{_}GERMAN LOSSES AT THE MARNE  There is no doubt that the German losses in the engagements at the Marne far exceeded those of the Allies and were most severe, in both men and material.
10147-8{_}3123{_}The Germans made incredible efforts to cross the Marne.
10147-8{_}3124{_}The French having destroyed all the bridges, the Germans tried to construct three bridges of boats.
10147-8{_}3125{_}Sixteen times the bridges were on the point of completion, but each time they were reduced to matchwood by the French artillery.
10147-8{_}3126{_}"There is not the slightest doubt," said a reliable correspondent, "that but for the superb handling of the German right by General von Kluck, a large part of Emperor William's forces would have been captured at the Marne.
10147-8{_}3127{_}The allied cavalry did wonders, and three or four additional divisions of cavalry could have contributed towards a complete rout of the Germans."
10147-8{_}3128{_}The general direction of the German retirement was northeast, and it was continued for seventy miles, to a line drawn between Soissons, Rheims and Verdun.
10147-8{_}3129{_}A week after the battle the field around Meaux had been cleared of dead and wounded, and only little mounds with tiny crosses, flowers and tricolored flags recalled the terrible struggle.
10147-8{_}3130{_}The inhabitants of neighboring villages soon returned to their homes and resumed their ordinary occupations.
10147-8{_}3131{_}FALL OF MAUBEUGE  While the fighting at the Marne was in progress, German troops achieved some successes in other parts of the theater of war.
10147-8{_}3132{_}Thus, the fortified French town of Maubeuge, on the Sambre river midway between Namur in Belgium and St. Quentin, France, fell to the Germans on September 7.
10147-8{_}3133{_}The investment began on August 25.
10147-8{_}3134{_}More than a thousand shells fell in one night near the railway station and the Rue de France was partially destroyed.
10147-8{_}3135{_}The loss of life, however, was comparatively slight.
10147-8{_}3136{_}At 11:50 o'clock on the morning of September 7 a white flag was hoisted on the church tower and trumpets sounded "cease firing," but the firing only ceased at 3:08 o'clock that afternoon.
10147-8{_}3137{_}In the meantime the greater part of the garrison succeeded in evacuating the town.
