10147-8{_}3138{_}The German forces marched in at 7:08 o'clock that evening.
10147-8{_}3139{_}The retreat of the German forces from the Marne ended the second stage of the great war.
10147-8{_}3140{_}CHAPTER XII   THE RUSSIAN CAMPAIGN    _Slow Mobilization of Troops--Invasion of German and Austrian   Territory--Cossacks Lead the Van--Early Successes   in East Prussia--"On to Berlin"--Heavy   Losses Inflicted on Austrians--German Troops Rushed   to the Defense of the Eastern Territory_.
10147-8{_}3141{_}When at 7:30 o'clock on the evening of August 1, 1914, the German Ambassador at St. Petersburg handed the declaration of war to the Russian foreign minister, the immediate reason was that Russia had refused to stop mobilizing her army, as requested by Germany on July 30.
10147-8{_}3142{_}The general mobilization of the Russian army and fleet was proclaimed on July 31 and martial law was proclaimed forthwith in Germany.
10147-8{_}3143{_}The government of the Kaiser had given Russia twenty-four hours in which to reply to its ultimatum of the 30th.
10147-8{_}3144{_}Russia paid no attention to the ultimatum, but M. Goremykin, president of the Council of the Russian Empire, issued a manifesto which read:  "Russia is determined not to allow Servia to be crushed and will fulfill its duty in regard to that small kingdom, which has already suffered so much at Austria's hands."
10147-8{_}3145{_}Austria-Hungary declared war against Russia on August 6.
10147-8{_}3146{_}From that time on the Russian army had two main objectives--first, the Austrian province of Galicia, and second the eastern frontier of Germany, across which lay the territory known as East Prussia.
10147-8{_}3147{_}And while the early days of the great conflict saw a German host pouring into Belgium, animated by the battle-cry, "On to Paris!"
10147-8{_}3148{_}the gathering legions of the Czar headed to the west and crossed the Prussian frontier with hoarse, resounding shouts of "On to Berlin!"
10147-8{_}3149{_}MOBILIZATION WAS SLOW  The mobilization of the Russian army was slow compared with that of Germany, France and Austria, and some weeks elapsed after the declaration of war before Russia was prepared to attack Germany with the full force of which it was capable.
10147-8{_}3150{_}The immense distances to be traversed by troops proceeding to the frontier and by the reserves to their respective depots caused delays that were unavoidable but were minimized by the eagerness of the Russian soldiery to get to the front.
10147-8{_}3151{_}In Russia, as in all the other great countries engaged in the conflict, with the probable exception of Austria, the war was popular and a wave of patriotic enthusiasm and martial ardor swept over the land, from the Baltic to the Black Sea, from St. Petersburg to Siberia.
10147-8{_}3152{_}In Russia military service is universal and begins at the age of 20, continuing for twenty-three years.
10147-8{_}3153{_}There are three divisions of the Russian army--the European, Caucasian and Asiatic armies.
10147-8{_}3154{_}Military service of the Russian consists of three years in the first line, fourteen years in the reserve (during which time he has to undergo two periods of training of six weeks each) and five years in the territorial reserve.
10147-8{_}3155{_}The Cossacks, however, hold their land by military tenure and are liable to serve at any time in the army.
10147-8{_}3156{_}They provide their own horses and accouterments.
10147-8{_}3157{_}The total strength of the Russian army is about 5,500,000 men; the field force of the European army consists of 1,000,000 soldiers with about the same number in the second line.
10147-8{_}3158{_}There were besides at the beginning of the war over 5,000,000 men unorganized but available for duty.
10147-8{_}3159{_}ARMY REORGANIZED RECENTLY  Since the disastrous war with Japan the Russian army has been reorganized and it has profited largely by the harsh experience of the Manchurian campaign.
10147-8{_}3160{_}The physique of the Russian infantryman is second to none in Europe.
10147-8{_}3161{_}The Russian "moujik" (peasant) is from childhood accustomed to cover long distances on foot, so that marches of from 30 to 40 miles are covered without fatigue by even the youngest recruits.
10147-8{_}3162{_}They wear long boots, which are made of excellent soft leather, so that sore feet were quite the exception even in Manchuria, where very long marches were undergone by many of the units.
10147-8{_}3163{_}Each regiment of infantry contains four battalions commanded by a major or lieutenant-colonel.
10147-8{_}3164{_}The battalion consists of four companies of men, commanded by a captain, so that each regiment on a war footing numbers upwards of 2,000 men.
10147-8{_}3165{_}The Russian cavalry is divided into two main categories.
10147-8{_}3166{_}There are the heavy regiments of the Guard, which consist mainly of Lancer regiments, and there are also numberless Cossack or irregular cavalry regiments, which are recruited chiefly from the districts of the River Don and the highlands of the Caucasus.
10147-8{_}3167{_}The horses of the Russian horse and field artillery are distinctly poor and very inferior to those of the cavalry.
10147-8{_}3168{_}The artillery is therefore somewhat slow in coming into action.
10147-8{_}3169{_}But the horses, while weedy-looking, are very hardy and pull the guns up steep gradients.
10147-8{_}3170{_}The Russian gunners prefer to take up "indirect" rather than "direct" positions.
10147-8{_}3171{_}Batteries are also rather slow in changing positions and in moving up in support of their infantry units.
10147-8{_}3172{_}THE RUSSIAN COSSACKS  What the Uhlans are to the German army, the Cossacks of the Don and the Caucasus are to the Russians--scouts, advance guards and "covering" cavalry.
10147-8{_}3173{_}They are good all-round fighters, capable of long-continued effort and tireless in the saddle; they are also trained to fight in dismounted action.
10147-8{_}3174{_}As a soldier the Cossack is altogether unique; his ways are his own and his confidence in his officers and himself is perfect.
10147-8{_}3175{_}His passionate love of horses makes his work a pleasure.
10147-8{_}3176{_}The Cossack seat on horseback is on a high pad-saddle, with the knee almost vertical and the heel well drawn back.
10147-8{_}3177{_}Spurs are not worn, and another remarkable thing is that he has absolutely no guard to his sword.
10147-8{_}3178{_}The Russian soldier scorns buttons; he says, "They are a nuisance; they have to be cleaned, they wear away the cloth, they are heavy, and they attract the attention of the enemy."
10147-8{_}3179{_}The Cossack pony is a quaint little beast to look at, but the finest animal living for his work, and very remarkable for his wonderful powers of endurance.
10147-8{_}3180{_}The Cossack and his mount have been likened to a clever nurse and a spoilt child--each understands and loves the other, but neither is completely under control.
10147-8{_}3181{_}The Cossack does not want his horse to be a slave, and recognizes perfectly that horses, like children, have their whims and humors and must be coaxed and reasoned with, but rarely punished.
10147-8{_}3182{_}The famous knout (whip) is carried by the Cossacks at the end of a strap across the left shoulder.
10147-8{_}3183{_}Most of the men are bearded and in full dress, with the high fur cap stuck jauntily on the head of square cut hair, the Cossack presents a picturesque and martial figure.
10147-8{_}3184{_}The appearance of these men is quite different from that of the clean-shaven regular infantryman of the Russian army.
10147-8{_}3185{_}RUSSIAN PLAN OF CAMPAIGN  "While the direct objective of the Russians was Berlin, there were many reasons why a bee-line course could not be followed.
10147-8{_}3186{_}Germany had prepared an elaborate defense system to cover the direct approaches to Berlin, and the fortresses of Danzig, Graudenz, Thorn, and Posen were important points in this scheme.
10147-8{_}3187{_}The nature of the country also adapts itself to these defensive works and would make progress slow for an attacker.
10147-8{_}3188{_}Moreover, as Austria and her forces mobilized before Russia, a diversion was created by the Austrian invasion of south Poland, in which the Germans also took the offensive.
10147-8{_}3189{_}Under these circumstances the Russian plan of campaign resolved itself into three parts:--  (1) A northern movement from Kovno and Grodno on Insterburg and K√∂nigsberg as a counter-attack.
10147-8{_}3190{_}(2) A central movement from Warsaw towards Posen with supporting movements north and south.
10147-8{_}3191{_}(3) A southern movement on Lublin in Poland to repulse the invaders combined with a movement from the east on Lemberg in order to turn the Austrian flank.
10147-8{_}3192{_}The first purpose of Russia was to clear Poland of enemies, as they threatened the Russian left flank.
10147-8{_}3193{_}At the same time Russia took the offensive by an invasion of Prussia in the north.
10147-8{_}3194{_}This latter movement led to a victory at Gumbinnen and the investment of K√∂nigsberg.
10147-8{_}3195{_}Later came victory at Lublin, rolling back the Austrians, and the capture of Lemberg, which signalized the Russian invasion of Austrian territory.
10147-8{_}3196{_}Thus Russia was for awhile clear of the enemy, while she established a strong footing in both Prussia and Austria.
10147-8{_}3197{_}[Illustration: THE RUSSIAN PLAN OF CAMPAIGN In the above view the German lines of defense are shown black, the Austrian lines of defense are indicated by crossed lines, and the Russian advances are shown by arrows.]
10147-8{_}3198{_}We can now understand the main Russian plan a little better.
10147-8{_}3199{_}In the north the army was to advance from K√∂nigsberg and endeavor to cut off Danzig and break the line of defenses between that place and Thorn, thus leaving this fortress in the rear.
10147-8{_}3200{_}In the south the Austrians, already heavily punished, would be driven back on the Carpathian passes to the south, and westward also toward Cracow, which is the key to the situation.
10147-8{_}3201{_}If Cracow fell Russia would have a good route into Germany, and the move would be supported by advances from Warsaw, thus threatening Breslau from two sides.
10147-8{_}3202{_}GERMAN TROOPS HURRIED EAST  Early in September, however, the danger of the Russian advance into Germany, which apparently had given the German general staff but little concern at first, was fully realized and large bodies of German troops were detached from the western theater of war and hurried to the eastern frontier.
10147-8{_}3203{_}Germany had evidently reckoned on Austria being able to hold its ground better, and was badly prepared for a flanking move on Breslau so early in the campaign.
10147-8{_}3204{_}But the Servian and Russian defeats of Austria left Germany to bear the full force of the terrific Russian onslaught, and her forces proved equal to the occasion.
10147-8{_}3205{_}Under General von Hindenberg the German army of the east soon repelled the Russian invaders and forced them to retire from East Prussia across their own border, where they were followed by the Germans.
10147-8{_}3206{_}A series of engagements on Russian soil followed, in which the advantage lay as a rule with the Germans.
10147-8{_}3207{_}The losses on both sides were heavy, but the Germans captured many thousands of Russian prisoners and considerable quantities of arms and munitions of war.
10147-8{_}3208{_}The immense resources of the Russian empire in men and material made the problem of Russian invasion a very serious one for Germany.
10147-8{_}3209{_}This was fully realized by the Kaiser, who about October 1, at the end of the second month of the war, proceeded in person to his eastern frontier to direct the defensive operations against Russia.
10147-8{_}3210{_}CZAR NICHOLAS AT THE FRONT  About the same time the Czar, Nicholas II, also took the field in person, arriving at the front on October 5, accompanied by General Soukhomlinoff, the Russian minister of war.
10147-8{_}3211{_}"I am resolved to go to Berlin itself, even if it causes me to lose my last moujik (peasant)," the Czar is reported as saying in September.
10147-8{_}3212{_}The spirit and temper of the Russian government may be judged by the fact that before the war was many days old the name of the Russian capital was officially changed from "St. Petersburg," which was considered to have a German flavor, to "Petrograd," a purely Russian or Slavic form of nomenclature.
10147-8{_}3213{_}RUSSIA PREPARES TO STRIKE AUSTRIA  By the third week of August, according to an announcement from Petrograd, Russian troops had checked an attempt by the Austrians to enter Poland from the Galician frontier and were preparing to invade Austria on a large scale.
10147-8{_}3214{_}At that time Russia was said to have 2,000, men under arms for the invasion of Germany and Austria, also 500,000 on the Roumanian and Turkish borders, and 3,000,000 men in reserve.
10147-8{_}3215{_}(The latter were called out by imperial ukase before Czar Nicholas started for the front.)
10147-8{_}3216{_}The Poles had been promised self-government and had been called on to support Russia.
10147-8{_}3217{_}The Jews throughout the Russian empire were also promised a greater measure of protection, freedom of action and civil rights.
10147-8{_}3218{_}These measures inaugurated an era of better feeling in Russia and Poland and were strongly approved by the allies of Russia.
10147-8{_}3219{_}Most of the Austrian reserves were mobilized by August 15 and Germany's ally announced that she would soon have her total war strength of 2,000,000 men in the field.
10147-8{_}3220{_}Austria sent some troops to join the German forces in Belgium and an army of several hundred thousand men was gathered along the Austro-Russian frontier under command of the Archduke Frederick.
10147-8{_}3221{_}General Rennenkampf was in command of the Russian forces for the invasion of East Prussia, while General Russky led the Russian army operating against Galicia.
10147-8{_}3222{_}INVASION OF PRUSSIA  Within a week the Russian movement in eastern Germany assumed menacing proportions, the great army of invasion having moved rapidly, considering the natural obstacles.
10147-8{_}3223{_}More than 800,000 men were sent over the border into Prussia.
10147-8{_}3224{_}The Germans evacuated a number of towns, after setting them afire, and a considerable part of the Kaiser's eastern field forces was bottled up in military centers.
10147-8{_}3225{_}Germany's active field force was at this time inferior in numbers to the invading army.
10147-8{_}3226{_}By the capture of Insterberg the Russians paralyzed one of the main German strategic centers and gained control of an important railroad.
10147-8{_}3227{_}The German Twentieth Army Corps was reported to have been routed near Lyck.
10147-8{_}3228{_}At the start the Russian forces extended from Insterberg to Goldapp, a distance of about thirty-two miles.
10147-8{_}3229{_}Seventy-five miles further on was the first of the two strong German lines of fortifications.
10147-8{_}3230{_}Early victories were claimed by the Russians in their advance into Austria, which was made slowly.
10147-8{_}3231{_}Austria then turned to fight the Russian invasion.
10147-8{_}3232{_}It was forced to gather all its forces for this principal struggle and hence retired from offensive operations against the Servians.
10147-8{_}3233{_}Unless she could halt the Russians pouring in from the north, a success against Servia could do her no good.
10147-8{_}3234{_}By the first of September the Russian advance into East Prussia was well under way and the strong fortress of K√∂nigsberg was in danger of a siege, German troops were being rushed to its defense.
10147-8{_}3235{_}In Galicia there were fierce encounters between the Russian invaders and the Austrians.
10147-8{_}3236{_}Several victories were claimed by the Russians all along the line and whole brigades of Austrian troops were reported destroyed, while the Russian losses were also admittedly heavy.
10147-8{_}3237{_}The fiercest fighting occurred in the vicinity of Lemberg, the capital of Galicia, which was soon to fall to General Russky.
10147-8{_}3238{_}The Austrian attack on Russian Poland failed and the Austrians were driven back across their own frontier.
10147-8{_}3239{_}The Russians were seeking to destroy the hope of the Kaiser for help from Austria in Eastern Germany, where the Russian advance, ridiculed or belittled by Germany before it began, became more menacing every day.
10147-8{_}3240{_}The German war plans had contemplated a quick, decisive blow in France and then a rapid turn to the East to meet the Russians with a tremendous force.
10147-8{_}3241{_}But the belligerency of the Belgians and the cooperation of the British balked these plans, while the Russians moved faster than was expected by their foe.
10147-8{_}3242{_}Austria had failed everywhere to stop the Czar's forces, and then came a crushing blow to Austrian hopes in a ruinous defeat near Lemberg and the loss of that fortress.
10147-8{_}3243{_}THE FALL OF LEMBERG  The capture of Lemberg from the Austrians early in September after a four days' battle was one of the striking Russian successes of the war.
10147-8{_}3244{_}Details reached the outer world on September 10th from Petrograd (St. Petersburg) as follows, the story being that of an eyewitness:  "The commencement of the fighting which resulted in the capture of Lemberg began August 29th, when the Russians drove the enemy from Zisczow (forty-five miles east of Lemberg) and moved on to Golaya Gorka--a name which means 'the naked hill.'
10147-8{_}3245{_}"We spent the night on Naked Hill, and the actual storming of the town was begun at 2:30 o'clock in the morning.
10147-8{_}3246{_}Then followed a four days' battle.
10147-8{_}3247{_}A virtually continuous cannonade continued from dawn to darkness without cessation.
10147-8{_}3248{_}"Even in the darkness the weary fighters got little sleep.
10147-8{_}3249{_}Whenever a single shot was heard the men dashed for their places and the battle boiled again with renewed fury.
10147-8{_}3250{_}"The enemy's counter attacks were delivered with great energy and a dense hail of lead and iron was poured over our ranks.
10147-8{_}3251{_}The Russian advance was greatly impeded by the hilly nature of the ground and the great number of extinct craters, which formed splendid natural fortifications for the enemy, which held them doggedly.
10147-8{_}3252{_}Out of these, however, the enemy was driven in succession.
10147-8{_}3253{_}"We suffered much from thirst, for the stony, country was devoid of springs.
10147-8{_}3254{_}The days were oppressively hot and the nights bitterly cold.
10147-8{_}3255{_}RUSSIAN ARTILLERY SUPERIOR  "Both sides fought with great obstinacy, but the nearer we approached Lemberg the harder the struggle became.
10147-8{_}3256{_}However, it soon was evident that we were superior in artillery.
10147-8{_}3257{_}"At length the enemy was driven from all sides beneath the protection of the Lemberg forts.
10147-8{_}3258{_}Our troops were very weary, but in high spirits.
10147-8{_}3259{_}"For two days the fight raged around the forts, but we were always confident of the prowess of our artillery.
10147-8{_}3260{_}The big guns of both sides rained a terrific hail down on the armies, which suffered terrific losses.
10147-8{_}3261{_}"At last we noticed that the resistance of the forts was growing weaker.
10147-8{_}3262{_}A charge at double quick was ordered, and we carried the first line of works.
10147-8{_}3263{_}"It was evident from that point that many of the enemy's guns had been destroyed.
10147-8{_}3264{_}Not enough of them had been left to continue an effective defense, but the enemy was undiscouraged and tried to make up with rifle fire what it lacked in artillery.
10147-8{_}3265{_}LOSSES BECOME HEAVIER  "Between the first and second lines our losses were heavier than before, but under bayonet charges the enemy broke and fled in panic.
10147-8{_}3266{_}"Our troops entered the town at the enemy's heels.
10147-8{_}3267{_}We ran into the town, despite our fatigue, with thunderous cheering.
10147-8{_}3268{_}"An episode which had much to do with ending the enemy's dogged resistance occurred during the fighting between the first and second lines.
10147-8{_}3269{_}The Austrians in the hope of checking the Russian effort to encircle the town had thrown out a heavy screen of Slav troops with a backing of Magyars who had been ordered to shoot down the Slavs from behind if they showed any hesitation.
10147-8{_}3270{_}"This circumstance became known to the Russian commander, who ordered a terrific artillery fire over the heads of the Slavs and into the ranks of the Magyars.
10147-8{_}3271{_}This well-directed fire set the whole line in panic."
10147-8{_}3272{_}More than 35,000 Austrians and Russian wounded were abandoned on the field of battle between Tarnow, Lemberg and Tarnopol owing to lack of means of transportation, according to reliable reports.
10147-8{_}3273{_}Both armies declined to ask for an armistice for the burial of the dead and the collection of the wounded, each fearing to give an advantage to the other.
10147-8{_}3274{_}THE BATTLE BEFORE LEMBERG  The immense superiority of the Austrian forces east of Lemberg enabled the Austrians at first to adopt the offensive.
10147-8{_}3275{_}As soon, however, as the Austrians realized the impossibility of an advance on Warsaw they concentrated their large and overwhelming forces in an attempt to outflank the right wing of the Russian army, which was drawing slowly but surely towards Lemberg, On the other Russian flank the two Russian army corps, after crossing the River Zlota Lipa without much opposition, continued their advance to the River Knila Lipa, where they found the bridges had all been destroyed by the Austrian advance guards.
10147-8{_}3276{_}Two bridges were constructed on the Rogarten-Halicz line, which enabled a crossing to be effected in spite of heavy and incessant artillery fire from the Austrian 24-centimeter guns.
10147-8{_}3277{_}Once across the river, the two Russian corps crossed the upper reaches of the River Boog and so approached the town of Lemberg from the east.
10147-8{_}3278{_}The main Austrian army, however, had by this time moved up to bar the further advance of the Russian forces, and the whole of their armies on the left bank of the River Vistula being in front of the three Russian corps, the latter were compelled to adopt a defensive r√¥le for three or four days, after which, having received large reinforcements, the Russian force moved forward and drove the Austrian troops out of their entrenchments outside Lemberg at the point of the bayonet.
10147-8{_}3279{_}A desperate attempt was made by means of a counter-attack to arrest the advance of the Russian troops, but this only resulted in the capture of 6,000 Austrian prisoners.
10147-8{_}3280{_}[Illustration: WHERE RUSSIA FIGHTS.
10147-8{_}3281{_}Battle grounds of Eastern Prussia and of Galicia, where the Austrians were repeatedly defeated with heavy losses.]
10147-8{_}3282{_}Lemberg was not a fortress but was recently converted into a semi-fortified place, as a series of lunettes, redoubts, etc., had been hastily prepared.
10147-8{_}3283{_}It was the headquarters of the 11th Austrian Corps, which consisted of the famous 43rd Landwehr infantry division, and was further divided into three Landwehr brigades.
10147-8{_}3284{_}There was also a Landwehr Uhlan regiment, together with a howitzer division of field artillery.
10147-8{_}3285{_}These batteries were armed with 10.5-centimeter guns, fitted with the German or Krupp eccentric breech action.
10147-8{_}3286{_}The forts outside the town were said to be armed with the 15-centimeter siege gun made of steel, also with a Krupp action.
10147-8{_}3287{_}The ammunition for these guns is chiefly high explosive shell and shrapnel; one of the forts is also said to have had a battery of three 24-centimeter heavy siege guns of quite a modern pattern.
10147-8{_}3288{_}GERMANY RUSHES REINFORCEMENTS  When Lemberg fell the Russian advance covered a line extending from far up in Eastern Prussia, near Tilsit, across the frontier and on down south into Austrian Galicia.
10147-8{_}3289{_}K√∂nigsberg was hearing the sound of the Russian guns and its besiegers seemed on the verge of victory.
10147-8{_}3290{_}A central column of mighty strength was pushing its way into Germany, despite a stubborn resistance.
10147-8{_}3291{_}Then the tide turned.
10147-8{_}3292{_}German reinforcements were brought up and under General von Hindenberg the Germans administered a severe defeat to General Rennenkampf's army near Allenstein, in which it was claimed that 60,000 prisoners were taken.
10147-8{_}3293{_}Other reverses were suffered by the Russians and soon after the middle of September they had been forced to retire from German territory, the German troops following them into Russia, where a series of minor engagements occurred near the frontier.
10147-8{_}3294{_}GENERAL RENNENKAMPF'S DEFEAT  The operations leading to the defeat of General Rennenkampf's Russian army by the Germans were as follows:  From September 7 to 13 the Russians took a strong position on the line from Angerburg to Gerdauen, Allenburg, and Kehlau, the left wing resting on the Mazurian lakes and the right wing protected in the rear and flank by the forest of Frisching, whose pathless woods and swamps furnished an almost impregnable position.
10147-8{_}3295{_}The Russians devoted great efforts to intrenching their position and brought up besides their heavy artillery.
10147-8{_}3296{_}Russian cavalry scouted far to the west and south, but otherwise the army-undertook no offensive operations in the days following a battle at Tannenberg.
10147-8{_}3297{_}The German forces, according to the German official account, were composed of the Second, Third, Fourth and Twentieth corps, two reserve divisions and five cavalry divisions.
10147-8{_}3298{_}General von Hindenburg, the German commander, meanwhile was assembling every available man, depriving the fortresses of their garrisons and calling in all but a bare remnant of the force protecting the southern frontier in the vicinity of Soldau, adding them to reinforcements received from the west.
10147-8{_}3299{_}General von Hindenburg again resorted to the customary German flanking movement, and since the German right, protected by the forest and marshes, seemed too strong, he adopted the daring strategy of sending the flanking force to the lake region to the south, the same character of movement by which the Russian Narew army had been defeated on August 28, in the vicinity of Ortelsburg, and which in case of failure might have been equally as disastrous for the Germans.
10147-8{_}3300{_}STRATEGY IS SUCCESSFUL  The strategy, however, succeeded, although General Rennenkampf offered a desperate resistance to the frontal attacks.
10147-8{_}3301{_}After three days' fighting the Russians were forced back slightly in the center.
10147-8{_}3302{_}When the flank movement of the Germans was discovered already threatening the flank, a counter-movement was launched with a new army collected at Lyck, including the Twenty-second corps and parts of the Third Siberian corps, just arriving from Irkutsk, and the balance of the defeated army.
10147-8{_}3303{_}The counter-attacks failed and on September 10 the Russians began to fall back on their main position, retreating in good order and well covered.
10147-8{_}3304{_}The Russian artillery on the right wing appears to have made a good retreat owing to a timely start, while the left wing was hard pressed by the enveloping German infantry.
10147-8{_}3305{_}From this wing the Russians retreated across the border in two columns, while the main body went northward and the others in an easterly direction, pursued by the Germans, who advanced far from the border.
10147-8{_}3306{_}The German government appointed Count von Merveldt as governor of the Russian province of Suwalki and other points occupied by them.
10147-8{_}3307{_}The University of Koenigsberg on September 18 conferred upon General von Hindenburg honorary doctors' degrees from all four of the departments of philosophy, theology, law and medicine, in recognition of his success against the Russian invader.
10147-8{_}3308{_}AUSTRIA STRUGGLING FOR EXISTENCE  In Galicia, however, Russian successes continued.
10147-8{_}3309{_}The important fortress of Mikolajoff, 25 miles south of Lemberg, was captured and this cleared away every Austrian stronghold east of Przemysl, which was then invested by the Russians.
10147-8{_}3310{_}Austria was now struggling for her very existence as a monarchy.
10147-8{_}3311{_}Following the crushing defeats administered to the Austrian troops and with the Czar's forces sweeping Galicia, Vienna was hurriedly fortified.
10147-8{_}3312{_}All reports indicated that the large Austrian force, nearly 1,000, men in all, opposing the main Russian invasion had proved ineffective.
10147-8{_}3313{_}Help from Germany did not arrive in time.
10147-8{_}3314{_}Official dispatches reported the main Austrian army retreating, pursued and harassed by the Russians.
10147-8{_}3315{_}The other important Austrian army was surrounded near Lublin.
10147-8{_}3316{_}While the Muscovite host went smashing through Galicia, chasing the Austrian army before it, the Russian staff belittled the retreat from East Prussia, saying that the Russian army was merely falling back on a new defensive position.
10147-8{_}3317{_}The German artillery had been getting in its deadly work and the pressure on Koenigsberg was soon to be relieved.
10147-8{_}3318{_}There were many reports at this time of a popular demand in Austria that an end be made to the struggle.
10147-8{_}3319{_}Peace talk was a marked feature of the sixth week of the war, but there were no definite results in any part of the immense theater of war.
10147-8{_}3320{_}The third week of September found the Germans, greatly reinforced, making a strong resistance to Russian progress, with the aid of the heavy German artillery.
10147-8{_}3321{_}The shattered Austrian armies, under Generals von Auffenberg and Dankl, were making desperate endeavors to concentrate in the vicinity of Rawaruska, but were apparently surrounded by the Russians, who continued to capture Austrian prisoners by the thousand.
10147-8{_}3322{_}Fears were entertained for Cracow, one of the strongest fortresses in Austria, if not in Europe, which seemed likely soon to fall into the hands of Russia.
10147-8{_}3323{_}It was stated in Rome, and said to be admitted in Vienna, that the Archduke Frederick, commanding the Austrian forces in Galicia, had lost 120,000 men, or one-fourth of his entire army.
10147-8{_}3324{_}German troops were reported marching south toward Poland to assist the Austrians.
10147-8{_}3325{_}The Russian successes in Galicia gave them command of the Galician oil-fields, upon which Germany largely depended for her supply of gasoline, which is a prime necessary in modern war.
10147-8{_}3326{_}RUSSIANS AT PRZEMYSL  On September 21 the Russians began the bombardment of Przemysl, having previously occupied Grodek and Mosciska, west of Lemberg.
10147-8{_}3327{_}The shattered second Austrian army was evidently incapable of staying the Russian advance, and took refuge in Przemysl.
10147-8{_}3328{_}A part of this Galician stronghold was soon captured by the Russians, forcing the Austrians to take refuge in the eastern forts, where the entire garrison was concentrated at the end of September, preparing to make a final resistance.
10147-8{_}3329{_}The situation of the garrison was critical, as it was entirely surrounded by the enemy.
10147-8{_}3330{_}On September 21 also the Russian troops took by storm the fortifications of Jaroslav, on the river San, and captured many guns.
10147-8{_}3331{_}The German offensive from East Prussia was apparently halted October by the almost impassable condition of the Russian roads in the north.
10147-8{_}3332{_}Germany was said to have at this time thirty army corps of the line and the first reserve prepared to operate against Russia and to resist the Russian advance upon Cracow.
10147-8{_}3333{_}The German main defenses against Russia extended in a general line from Koenigsberg to Danzig, thence south along the Vistula to the great fortress of Thorn.
10147-8{_}3334{_}From there the fortified line swung to the southwest to Posen, thence south to Breslau, the main fortress along the Oder, and from there to Cracow.
10147-8{_}3335{_}Early in October the Russian invasion of Hungary began.
10147-8{_}3336{_}The Russian armies continued to sweep through Galicia and that province was reported clear of Austrian troops.
10147-8{_}3337{_}The German successes claimed against the Czar farther north included victories at Krasnik and Zamoso, in Russian Poland; Insterburg and Tannenburg, in East Prussia.
10147-8{_}3338{_}ESTIMATE OF AUSTRIAN LOSSES  A Russian estimate places the Austrian losses in Galicia at 300, in killed, wounded and prisoners, or nearly one-third of their total forces.
10147-8{_}3339{_}They also lost, it was claimed at Petrograd, 1,000 guns, more than two-thirds of their available artillery.
10147-8{_}3340{_}The Russian newspaper correspondents described horrible scenes on the battlefields abandoned by the Austro-German forces in Galicia.
10147-8{_}3341{_}"Streams," said one eyewitness, "were choked full with slain men, trodden down in the headlong flight till the waters were dammed and overflowing the banks.
10147-8{_}3342{_}Piles of dead are awaiting burial or burning.
10147-8{_}3343{_}Hundreds of acres are sown with bodies and littered with weapons and battle debris, while wounded and riderless horses are careering madly over the abandoned country.
10147-8{_}3344{_}The trophies captured comprise much German equipment.
10147-8{_}3345{_}An ammunition train captured at Janow (eleven miles northwest of Lemberg) was German, while the guns taken included thirty-six of heavy caliber bearing Emperor William's initials and belonging to the German Sixth army corps.
10147-8{_}3346{_}"The line of retreat of the Austro-German forces was blocked with debris of every kind--valuable military supplies, telephone and telegraph installations, light railway and other stores, bridging material--in fact, everything needed by a modern army was flung away in flight.
10147-8{_}3347{_}Over 1,000 wagons with commissariat supplies alone were captured."
10147-8{_}3348{_}Forty-five thousand Austro-German prisoners were reported to have arrived at Lublin.
10147-8{_}3349{_}Russian correspondents with the armies in Galicia asserted that German troops were interspersed with Austrian troops in the intrenchments in order to raise the morale of the Austrians.
10147-8{_}3350{_}One correspondent declared that while the Austrians often took flight the Germans were ready, to the last man, to perish.
10147-8{_}3351{_}ON THE FIRING LINE IN RUSSIAN POLAND--VIVID DESCRIPTION BY AN AMERICAN EYEWITNESS  The first American permitted to witness actual battles near the eastern frontier of Germany was Karl H. von Wiegand, who wrote as follows from the firing line near East Wirballen, Russian Poland, October 9:   "The German artillery today beat back, in a bloody, ghastly smear of men, the Russian advance.
10147-8{_}3352{_}"Yesterday I saw an infantry engagement.
10147-8{_}3353{_}Today it was mostly an artillery encounter.
10147-8{_}3354{_}The infantry attack is the more ghastly, but the artillery the more awe-inspiring.
10147-8{_}3355{_}This was the fifth day of constant fighting and still the German trenches hold.
10147-8{_}3356{_}"Today's battle opened at dawn.
10147-8{_}3357{_}With two staff officers assigned as my chaperons, I had been attached overnight to the field headquarters.
10147-8{_}3358{_}I slept well, exhausted by the excitement of my first sight of modern war, but when dawn once again revealed the two long lines of the Russian and German positions the Russian guns began to hurl their loads of shrapnel at the German trenches.
10147-8{_}3359{_}"We had breakfast calmly enough despite the din of guns.
10147-8{_}3360{_}Then we went to one of the German batteries on the left center.
10147-8{_}3361{_}They were already in action, though it was only 6 o'clock.
10147-8{_}3362{_}The men got the range from observers a little in advance, cunningly masked, and slowly, methodically, and enthusiastically fed the guns with their loads of death.
10147-8{_}3363{_}"The Russians didn't have our range.
10147-8{_}3364{_}All of their shells flew screaming 1,000 yards to our left.
10147-8{_}3365{_}Through my glasses I watched them strike.
10147-8{_}3366{_}The effect on the hillock was exactly as though a geyser had suddenly spurted up.
10147-8{_}3367{_}A vast cloud of dirt and stones and grass spouted up, and when the debris cleared away a great hole showed.
10147-8{_}3368{_}RUSSIANS TRY NEW RANGE  "While we watched the Russians seemed to tire of shooting holes in an inoffensive hill.
10147-8{_}3369{_}They began to try chance shots to the right and to the left.
10147-8{_}3370{_}It wasn't many minutes before I realized that, standing near a battery, the execution of which must have been noted on the Russian side, I had a fine chance of experiencing shrapnel bursting overhead.
10147-8{_}3371{_}It was a queer sensation to peer through field glasses and see the Russian shells veer a few hundred feet to the right.
10147-8{_}3372{_}I saw one strike a windmill, shattering the long arms and crumpling it over in a slow burning heap.
10147-8{_}3373{_}Then we beat a retreat, further toward the center.
10147-8{_}3374{_}"We had been standing behind a slight declivity.
10147-8{_}3375{_}I hadn't caught a glimpse of the enemy.
10147-8{_}3376{_}Shells were the only things that apprised us of the Russian nearness.
10147-8{_}3377{_}But as we passed out on an open field, considerably out of range of the field guns, I could see occasional flashes that bespoke field pieces, a mile or so away.
10147-8{_}3378{_}RUSSIAN INFANTRY CHARGES  "Back behind us, on the extreme left, I was told the Russians were attacking the German trenches by an infantry charge, the German field telephone service having apprised the commanders along the front.
10147-8{_}3379{_}With glasses we could see a faint line of what must have been the Russian infantry rushing across the open fields.
10147-8{_}3380{_}"We passed on to the center, going slightly to the rear for horses.
10147-8{_}3381{_}As we arrived at the right wing we witnessed the last of a Russian infantry advance at that end.
10147-8{_}3382{_}The wave of Russians had swept nearly to the German trenches, situated between two sections of field artillery, and there had been repulsed.
10147-8{_}3383{_}Russians were smeared across in front of these pits, dead, dying, or wounded--cut down by the terrible spray of German machine guns.
10147-8{_}3384{_}"I got up to the trenches as the German fire slackened because of the lack of targets.
10147-8{_}3385{_}The Russians had gone back.
10147-8{_}3386{_}Strewn in the trenches were countless empty shells, the bullets of which had, as it looked to inexpert eyes, slain thousands.
10147-8{_}3387{_}As a matter of fact, there were hundreds of dead in the field ahead.
10147-8{_}3388{_}GUN BARRELS SIZZLING HOT  "German infantrymen spat on their rapid firers as we reached the trench and delightedly called our attention to the sizzle that told how hot the barrels were from the firing.
10147-8{_}3389{_}"The men stretched their cramped limbs, helped a few wounded to the rear, and waited for breakfast.
10147-8{_}3390{_}It was not long forthcoming.
10147-8{_}3391{_}Small lines of men struggling along tinder steaming buckets came hurrying up to the accompaniment of cheers and shouts.
10147-8{_}3392{_}They bore soup that the men in the trenches gulped down ravenously.
10147-8{_}3393{_}Meanwhile men with the white brassard and the red Geneva cross were busy out in the open, lending succor to the Russian wounded.
10147-8{_}3394{_}The battle seemed to have come to a sudden halt.
10147-8{_}3395{_}"But even as I was getting soup, the artillery fusillade broke forth again.
10147-8{_}3396{_}From 9 o'clock to noon the Russians hurled their heavy shells at the German trenches and the German guns.
10147-8{_}3397{_}The German batteries replied slowly.
10147-8{_}3398{_}"There was mighty little fuss and feathers about this business of dealing death from guns.
10147-8{_}3399{_}The crews at each piece laughed among themselves, but there were none of the picturesque shouts of command, the indiscriminate blowing of bugles, and the flashy waving of battle flags that the word battle usually conjures up.
10147-8{_}3400{_}It was merely a deadly business of killing.
10147-8{_}3401{_}"Over to the right, a scant 300 yards away, the Russians had apparently succeeded in getting the range.
10147-8{_}3402{_}As I watched through the glasses I saw shrapnel burst over the battery there and watched a noncommissioned soldier fall with three of his comrades.
10147-8{_}3403{_}I was told that one had been killed and three wounded.
10147-8{_}3404{_}The Red Cross crew came up and bore away the four--the dead and the live--and before they were gone the gun was speaking away with four fresh men working it.
10147-8{_}3405{_}"But the shrapnel kept bursting away over it and soon an orderly came riding furiously back on his horse, saluted the officers with me, and shouted as he hurried back to the artillery reserve: 'Six inch shells to the front; more ammunition.'
10147-8{_}3406{_}"I went back to see the wounded, but the surgeon wouldn't let me.
10147-8{_}3407{_}I expressed to him my wonder at the few wounded.
10147-8{_}3408{_}I had seen only a few in the trenches, and no German dead until I saw the artilleryman killed.
10147-8{_}3409{_}He explained that the losses on the German side were light because the trenches were well constructed and because there had been no hand-to-hand, bayonet to bayonet fighting.
10147-8{_}3410{_}ATTACKS BY RUSSIAN INFANTRY  "Yesterday, my first day at Wirballen, I saw the third attempt of the Russians to carry the German center by storm.
10147-8{_}3411{_}Twice on Wednesday their infantry had advanced under cover of their artillery, only to be repulsed.
10147-8{_}3412{_}Their third effort proved no more successful.
10147-8{_}3413{_}"The preliminaries were well under way, without my appreciating their significance, until one of my officer escorts explained.
10147-8{_}3414{_}"At a number of points along their line, observable to us, but screened from the observation of the German trenches in the center, the Russian infantry came tumbling out, and, rushing forward, took up advanced positions, awaiting the formation of the new and irregular battle line.
10147-8{_}3415{_}Dozens of light rapid-firers were dragged along by hand.
10147-8{_}3416{_}Other troops--the reserves--took up semi-advanced positions.
10147-8{_}3417{_}All the while the Russian shrapnel was raining over the German trenches.
10147-8{_}3418{_}"Finally came the Russian order to advance.
10147-8{_}3419{_}At the word hundreds of yards of the Russian fighting line leaped, forward, deployed in open order, and came on.
10147-8{_}3420{_}Some of them came into range of the German trench fire almost at once.
10147-8{_}3421{_}These lines began to wilt and thin out.
10147-8{_}3422{_}MEN PAUSE ONLY TO FIRE  "But on they came, all along the line, protected and unprotected alike, rushing forward with a yell, pausing, firing, and advancing again.
10147-8{_}3423{_}"From the outset of the advance the German artillery, ignoring for the moment the Russian artillery action, began shelling the onrushing mass with wonderfully timed shrapnel, which burst low over the advancing lines and tore sickening gaps.
10147-8{_}3424{_}"But the Russian line never stopped.
10147-8{_}3425{_}For the third time in two days they came tearing on, with no indication of having been affected by the terrible consequences of the two previous charges.
10147-8{_}3426{_}As a spectacle the whole thing was maddening.
10147-8{_}3427{_}"On came the Slav swarm, into the range of the German trenches, with wild yells and never a waver.
10147-8{_}3428{_}Russian battle flags--the first I had seen--appeared in the front of the charging ranks.
10147-8{_}3429{_}The advance line thinned and the second line moved up.
10147-8{_}3430{_}"Nearer and nearer they swept toward the German positions.
10147-8{_}3431{_}And then came a new sight.
10147-8{_}3432{_}A few seconds later came a new sound.
10147-8{_}3433{_}First I saw a sudden, almost grotesque melting of the advancing line.
10147-8{_}3434{_}It was different from anything that had taken place before.
10147-8{_}3435{_}The men literally went down like dominoes in a row.
10147-8{_}3436{_}Those who kept their feet were hurled back as though by a terrible gust of wind.
10147-8{_}3437{_}Almost in the second that I pondered, puzzled, the staccato rattle of machine guns reached us.
10147-8{_}3438{_}My ear answered the query of my eye.
10147-8{_}3439{_}MACHINE GUN FIRE TELLS  "For the first time the advancing line hesitated, apparently bewildered.
10147-8{_}3440{_}Mounted officers dashed along the line, urging the men forward.
10147-8{_}3441{_}Horses fell with the men.
10147-8{_}3442{_}I saw a dozen riderless horses dashing madly through the lines, adding a new terror.
10147-8{_}3443{_}Another horse was obviously running away with his officer rider.
10147-8{_}3444{_}The crucial period for the section of the charge on which I had riveted my attention probably lasted less than a minute.
10147-8{_}3445{_}To my throbbing brain it seemed an hour.
10147-8{_}3446{_}Then, with the withering fire raking them even as they faltered, the lines broke.
10147-8{_}3447{_}Panic ensued.
10147-8{_}3448{_}It was every man for himself.
10147-8{_}3449{_}The entire Russian charge turned and went tearing back to cover and the shelter of the Russian trenches.
10147-8{_}3450{_}"I swept the entire line of the Russian advance with my glasses--as far as it was visible from our position.
10147-8{_}3451{_}The whole advance of the enemy was in retreat, making for its intrenched position.
10147-8{_}3452{_}DEAD MEN COVER ACRES  "After the assault had failed and the battle had resumed its normal trend I swept the field with my glasses.
10147-8{_}3453{_}The dead were everywhere.
10147-8{_}3454{_}They were not piled up, but were strewn over acres.
10147-8{_}3455{_}More horrible than the sight of the dead, though, were the other pictures brought up by the glasses.
10147-8{_}3456{_}Squirming, tossing, writhing figures everywhere!
10147-8{_}3457{_}The wounded!
10147-8{_}3458{_}All who could stumble or crawl were working their way back toward their own lines or back to the friendly cover of hills or wooded spots.
10147-8{_}3459{_}"After the charge we moved along back of the German lines at a safe distance and found the hospital corps bringing back the German wounded.
10147-8{_}3460{_}"The artillerymen had resumed their duel and as we came up in the lee of the outbuildings of a deserted farmhouse a shell struck and fired the farmhouse immediately in front of us.
10147-8{_}3461{_}As we paused to see if the shot was a chance one, or if the Russian gunners had actually gotten the range, a regiment of fresh reserves, young men who had just come up from the west, passed us on their way to get their baptism of fire.
10147-8{_}3462{_}"Their demeanor was more suggestive of a group of college students going to a football game than the serious business on which they were bent.
10147-8{_}3463{_}They were singing and laughing, and as they went by a noncommissioned officer inquired rather ruefully whether there were any Russians left for them.
10147-8{_}3464{_}"Throughout the day we watched the fight waged from the opposing trenches and by the artillery.
10147-8{_}3465{_}"Suddenly at sundown the fighting ceased as if by mutual agreement.
10147-8{_}3466{_}As I write this I can see occasional flashes of light like the flare of giant fireflies out over the scene of the Russian charge--the flashes of small electrical lamps in the hands of the Russian hospital corps.
10147-8{_}3467{_}"I'm glad I don't have to look at what the flashes reveal out there in the night."
10147-8{_}3468{_}CHAPTER XIII  THE AUSTRO-SERVIAN CAMPAIGN    _Declaration of War by Austria--Bombardment of Belgrade--   Servian Capital Removed--Seasoned Soldiers of Servia   Give a Good Account of Themselves--Many Indecisive   Engagements--Servians in Austrian Territory_.
10147-8{_}3469{_}Formal declaration of war against Servia was proclaimed by Austria on Tuesday, July 28.
10147-8{_}3470{_}The text of the official announcement was as follows:  "The Royal Government of Servia not having given a satisfactory reply to the note presented to it by the Austro-Hungarian Ministry in Belgrade on July 23, 1914, the Imperial and Royal Government of Austria-Hungary finds it necessary itself to safeguard its rights and interests and to have recourse for this purpose to the force of arms.
10147-8{_}3471{_}Austria-Hungary, therefore, considers itself from this moment in a state of war with Servia."
10147-8{_}3472{_}This declaration was signed by Count Berchtold, the Austrian minister for foreign affairs.
10147-8{_}3473{_}The events that immediately preceded the declaration of war, as summarized in a previous chapter, were as follows:  On June 28 a Slav student who thought he was a patriot killed the Archduke Francis Ferdinand, heir to the Austrian throne, at Serajevo, the capital of Bosnia, which had been lately made a province of Austria.
10147-8{_}3474{_}An inquiry was begun in which evidence was introduced to show that the assassin's work was part of a plot for the revolt of the Southern Slav provinces of Austria, and that it was instigated by Servians, if not by the Servian Government.
10147-8{_}3475{_}On July 23, however, before the investigation was completed, Austria sent an ultimatum to Servia demanding that it use every means in its power to punish the assassins and also to stop all further anti-Austrian propaganda.
10147-8{_}3476{_}Austria demanded that she be permitted to have representatives in the work of investigation in Servia.
10147-8{_}3477{_}The next day, July 24, Russia joined the little Slav country in asking for a delay.
10147-8{_}3478{_}Austria refused to grant this.
10147-8{_}3479{_}On July 25, ten minutes before 6 p.m., the hour at which the ultimatum expired, the Servian premier, M. Pashitch, gave his reply to the Austrian ambassador at Belgrade.
10147-8{_}3480{_}Servia agreed to all the conditions and apologies demanded by Austria, except the requirement that Austrian officials should be allowed to participate in the inquiry to be conducted in Servia into the assassination of the Archduke.
10147-8{_}3481{_}Even this was not definitely refused.
10147-8{_}3482{_}On July 27 the Austrian foreign office issued a statement in which appeared these words:  "The object of the Servian note is to create the false impression that the Servian Government is prepared in great measure to comply with our demands.
10147-8{_}3483{_}"As a matter of fact, however, Servians note is filled with the spirit of dishonesty, which clearly lets it be seen that the Servian Government is not seriously determined to put an end to the culpable tolerance it hitherto has extended to intrigues against the Austro-Hungarian monarchy."
10147-8{_}3484{_}Russia at once notified Austria that it could not permit Servian territory to be invaded.
10147-8{_}3485{_}It was then realized in Europe that the great Slav nation would support its little brother.
10147-8{_}3486{_}Germany let it be known that no other country must interfere with the Austro-Servian embroglio, which meant that Germany was prepared to back Austria.
10147-8{_}3487{_}An eleventh-hour proposal by the British foreign secretary, Sir Edward Grey, that mediation between Servia and Austria be undertaken by a conference of the Ambassadors in London, was accepted by France and Italy, but declined by Germany and Austria.
10147-8{_}3488{_}Then next day, July 28, came Austria's declaration of war, which soon made Europe the theater of the bloodiest struggle of all the ages.
10147-8{_}3489{_}SERVIA AND ITS ASPIRATIONS  Servians reply to the declaration of war was to concentrate a strong division of its forces in the Sanjak of Novi-Bazar, from which they would be in a position to threaten Bosnia and Herzegovina, the two Balkan provinces that Austria had lately annexed.
10147-8{_}3490{_}It was also reported that Servia intended to invade Bosnia with the object of enlisting further support from the Bosnian Serbs, who were said to be on the point of rising against Austria-Hungary.
10147-8{_}3491{_}The country of the Servians being well suited for defense, they were never completely overrun by the Turks, as other Balkan states were, and as a consequence they still retain, like the Greeks, a native aristocracy of culture.
10147-8{_}3492{_}Physically, they are fairer than most of the Balkan Slavs and more refined in appearance.
10147-8{_}3493{_}By temperament they are light-hearted, joyous, frivolous, and charming to deal with.
10147-8{_}3494{_}In Servia itself, including territory acquired in recent wars, there are about 4,500,000 Serbs.
10147-8{_}3495{_}In Austria there are about 3,500,000 Serbs, including Croats who belong to the Servian race.
10147-8{_}3496{_}The Servians have long dreamed and talked and written of a greater Servia, that should take in all the Servian race.
10147-8{_}3497{_}They look back to the time of King Stephen Dushan, in the fourteenth century, when Servia was supreme in the Balkans and was nearly as advanced in civilization as the most advanced nations of Europe.
10147-8{_}3498{_}The re-establishment of this ancient kingdom had become a passion with the Serbs--not only with those in Servia, but with many in Hungary as well.
10147-8{_}3499{_}Hence, their animus against Austria and Austrian rule, while Austria's fight was, primarily, for the preservation and solidification of her heterogeneous dominions; secondarily, for revenge for the Archduke's death.
10147-8{_}3500{_}Incidentally, it may be mentioned that the Archduke Francis Ferdinand was a close personal friend of the German Kaiser.
10147-8{_}3501{_}THE SERVIAN ARMY  The Servian forces under General Radumil Putnik, consist of ten divisions, divided into four army corps, with a peace footing of 160, and a war strength of over 380,000.
10147-8{_}3502{_}Most of the men called to arms against Austria were veterans of the two recent Balkan wars, and hence probably the most seasoned troops in Europe.
10147-8{_}3503{_}The rifle of the Servian army is the Mauser, model of 1899, with a caliber of 7 millimeters, but it is doubtful if Servia possessed enough of them to arm the reserves.
10147-8{_}3504{_}The Servian field piece is a quick-firing gun of the French Schneider-Canet system.
10147-8{_}3505{_}The army has some 350 modern guns.
10147-8{_}3506{_}At the outbreak of the war Servia had ten of the most modern aircraft, but she had not developed their efficiency to a degree at which they would be of much material benefit to her in the struggle.
10147-8{_}3507{_}The extremely mountainous nature of Servia and of the adjacent territory of Bosnia make military movements somewhat slow and difficult, especially for troops unaccustomed to mountain warfare.
10147-8{_}3508{_}Compared with this mountainous region, the district of Agram, where one Austrian army corps had its headquarters, is easy country to operate in, while the plain of Hungary on the opposite side of the Danube made the task of concentrating troops an easy one for the Austrians.
10147-8{_}3509{_}Another Austrian army corps had its base at Serajevo in Bosnia.
10147-8{_}3510{_}A railway to the northeast from this Bosnian capital touches the Servian border at Mokragora.
10147-8{_}3511{_}To the north of this point lies Kragujevac, the new capital of Servia, to which King Peter, his court and the Government repaired from Belgrade just before the declaration of war.
10147-8{_}3512{_}Southeast of the new capital is the important Servian city of Nish.
10147-8{_}3513{_}The western frontier of Servia follows the windings of the Biver Drina, a tributary of the Danube.
10147-8{_}3514{_}The Danube itself forms part of the northern boundary and the former capital.
10147-8{_}3515{_}Belgrade, is picturesquely situated on the south bank of the Danube at its junction with a tributary.
10147-8{_}3516{_}Two Austrian fortresses command the city from across the Danube.
10147-8{_}3517{_}On the plain of Hungary to the north is Temesvar, an important point at which another Austrian army corps was located.
10147-8{_}3518{_}CHANCES AGAINST SERVIA  At the outset the chances of war were heavily against Servia.
10147-8{_}3519{_}Such artificial defenses as she possessed were on the Bulgarian frontier.
10147-8{_}3520{_}Many of her troops were engaged in endeavoring to establish Servian rule among the neighboring peoples in her new Albanian possessions.
10147-8{_}3521{_}Austria was prepared to bring against her immediately the three army corps from Temesvar, Serajevo and Agram, and four more corps, from Hermanstadt, Budapest, Graz, and Kaschau, within a fortnight.
10147-8{_}3522{_}Servians one hope appeared to be the difficulty of the country, otherwise she could not oppose for a moment the advance of 250,000 troops supported by pieces of artillery.
10147-8{_}3523{_}Then, too, Austria had warships on the Danube and it was partly through this fact that it was decided by the Servian Government to evacuate Belgrade and to retire to Kragujevac, sixty miles southeast.
10147-8{_}3524{_}In spite, however, of the seeming futility of opposition, Servia, encouraged by Russian support, prepared for a strenuous campaign against the Austrian forces, and the first two months of the war ended without any decisive advantage to Austria.
10147-8{_}3525{_}The Servians, on the other hand, claimed numerous successes.
10147-8{_}3526{_}Their task was lightened by the Russian invasion of Austrian territory and the determined advance of the Czar's host, which demanded the fullest strength of the Austrian forces to resist.
10147-8{_}3527{_}As the Russians hammered their enemy in Galicia the spirits of the Servians rose and their seasoned soldiers gave a good account of themselves in every encounter with Austrian troops.
10147-8{_}3528{_}They crossed the Drina and carried the war into Bosnia, putting up a stiff fight wherever they encountered the enemy, and while they sustained severe losses in killed and wounded during August and September, the losses they inflicted upon the Austrians were still heavier.
10147-8{_}3529{_}AUSTRIANS BOMBARD BELGRADE  The Austrian troops on the banks of the Danube became active soon after war was declared.
10147-8{_}3530{_}In the first few days they seized two Servian steamers and a number of river boats.
10147-8{_}3531{_}Belgrade was bombarded from across the river and many of its public buildings, churches and private residences suffered damage.
10147-8{_}3532{_}The hostile armies came into contact for the first time on the River Drina, between Bosnia and Servia, and Vienna was compelled to admit defeat in this preliminary engagement of the war.
10147-8{_}3533{_}The Servians forced a passage through the Austrian ranks, but only at the cost of many killed and wounded.
10147-8{_}3534{_}When Crown Prince Alexander of Servia began the invasion of Bosnia in earnest, in the middle of August, Austria found herself at a disadvantage because of the necessity of massing most of her forces against the Russians.
10147-8{_}3535{_}Roumania and Montenegro were then preparing to join the Servians in the field against Austria.
10147-8{_}3536{_}Later in August the Servians captured several of the enemy's strongholds in Bosnia.
10147-8{_}3537{_}After a four-day battle on the banks of the Drina the Austrians were defeated with heavy loss, a large number of guns and prisoners being captured by the Servians.
10147-8{_}3538{_}The Montenegrin troops repulsed an Austrian invading force and took several hundred prisoners in an all-day battle on the frontier.
10147-8{_}3539{_}Early in September a heavy engagement was fought by the Servian and Austrian armies near Jadar, resulting in Servian victory.
10147-8{_}3540{_}It was claimed that the Austrians left 10,000 dead on the field of battle.
10147-8{_}3541{_}The Servians also successfully defended Belgrade, which had been bombarded on several occasions.
10147-8{_}3542{_}Fifteen or twenty miles west of Belgrade on the Save River, an Austrian force was decisively defeated by the Servians, who then seemed to be duplicating the successes of the Russian army against Austria.
10147-8{_}3543{_}The attitude of Turkey was being closely watched at this time, Greece and Bulgaria being prepared to enter the war against the Ottoman Empire if the latter decided on belligerency, but on September 5 Turkey again declared her intention to remain neutral.
10147-8{_}3544{_}SERVIANS CAPTURE SEMLIN  Crossing the Save River into Hungary, the Servians scored a brilliant stroke in the capture of Semlin, an important Austrian city.
10147-8{_}3545{_}They also reported continued successes in Bosnia.
10147-8{_}3546{_}Reports of wholesale desertions of Slavs from the Austrian army were received daily and probably had considerable foundation in fact.
10147-8{_}3547{_}It was said that the Servians were being received enthusiastically by the people of Hungary.
10147-8{_}3548{_}These Servian triumphs led to the reorganization of the Balkan League, including Servia, Montenegro, Bulgaria and Greece.
10147-8{_}3549{_}On September 20 the Servian Government announced that an Austrian attacking army which attempted to cross the frontier near the Sabatz Mountains had been routed with a loss of 15,000 killed and wounded.
10147-8{_}3550{_}The Servian losses in this and other engagements were claimed to have been small in comparison with those of the enemy.
10147-8{_}3551{_}Continuing their forward movement into Hungary, the Servians inflicted further losses on the Austrians near Noviapazow, while the Montenegrins reported a victory in the mountain slopes over their border.
10147-8{_}3552{_}On October 1 it was reported that the Servians had again repulsed an Austrian attempt at invasion and had driven the Austrians back across the Drina with loss.
10147-8{_}3553{_}They had also checked another Austrian attempt to take Belgrade.
10147-8{_}3554{_}The Servian war office claimed that the combined Servian-Montenegrin armies had made material progress in their invasion of Bosnia-Herzegovina, and that they were within striking distance of Serajevo, which they expected to capture.
10147-8{_}3555{_}This, however, was denied by the Vienna ministry of war, which claimed that the Servian situation was entirely satisfactory to Austria.
10147-8{_}3556{_}On October 5 Servian troops were reported to have begun a northeast advance from Semlin, to effect a junction with two Russian columns advancing southward in Hungary.
10147-8{_}3557{_}One of these columns was then assaulting a fortress in Northwest Hungary, sixty-six miles southeast of Olmutz, while the other was descending the valley of the Nagyan against Huszt in the province of Marmaros.
10147-8{_}3558{_}This latter province or county, which the Russians invaded through the Carpathian passes, lies in the northeast of Hungary, bordering on Galicia, Bukowina and Transylvania.
10147-8{_}3559{_}There was a legend that the eastern Carpathians are impregnable, but this legend was destroyed by the Russian invasion.
10147-8{_}3560{_}Before attaining Uzsok pass, in the Carpathians, the Russians successively captured by a wide flanking movement three well-masked positions which were strongly defended by guns.
10147-8{_}3561{_}Each time the Russians charged the enemy fled and the Russians followed up the Austrian retreat with shrapnel and quick fire, inflicting heavy losses.
10147-8{_}3562{_}German troops joined the Austrian forces in Hungary and at some points succeeded in repulsing the invaders, though their general advance was not decisively checked and they continued the endeavor to effect a junction with the Servians to the south.
10147-8{_}3563{_}Advices from Budapest, October 6, declared that the Russians had captured Marmaros-Sziget, capital of the county of Marmaros, necessitating the removal of the government of that department to Huszt, twenty-eight miles west-northwest of Sziget.
10147-8{_}3564{_}A second Russian column was reported to be threatening Huszt and Austro-German reinforcements were being hurried up to check the Russian advance.
10147-8{_}3565{_}[Illustration: "BY ALLAH, I MAY HAVE TO INTERFERE IN THE NAME OF HUMANITY" --Kessler in the New York _Evening Sun_.]
10147-8{_}3566{_}CHAPTER XIV  STORIES FROM THE BATTLEFIELD    _Thrilling Incidents of the Great War Told by Actual Combatants   --Personal Experiences from the Lips of Survivors   of the World's Bloodiest Battles--Tales of   Prisoners of War, Wounded Soldiers and Refugees   Rendered Homeless in Blighted Arena of Conflict_.
10147-8{_}3567{_}HAND-TO-HAND FIGHTING  Cavalry fighting on the banks of the River Marne in the year 1914 was almost identical with the charge in the days when Hannibal's Numidian horse charged at Romans at Lake Trasimene, or when Charles Martel and the chivalry of France worsted the Moors and saved Europe on the plains of Tours.
10147-8{_}3568{_}A good description of a cavalry charge was given by Private Capel of the Third British Hussars, a veteran of the Boer war, who took part in the fighting beginning at Mons and was separated from his regiment in a charge at Coulommiers, in the battle of the Marne, when his horse fell.
10147-8{_}3569{_}"You hear," said he, "the enemy's bugles sounding the charge.
10147-8{_}3570{_}Half a mile away you see the Germans coming and it seems that in an instant they will be on you.
10147-8{_}3571{_}You watch fascinated and cold with a terror that makes you unable to lift an arm or do anything but wait and tremble.
10147-8{_}3572{_}"They come closer and still you are horrorstruck.
10147-8{_}3573{_}Then you feel your horse fretting and suddenly you start from your daze, and fear changes suddenly to hate.
10147-8{_}3574{_}Your hand goes to the saber hilt, your teeth clinch and you realize that you must strike hard before the enemy, who is now very close, can strike.
10147-8{_}3575{_}Every muscle tightens with the waiting.
10147-8{_}3576{_}"Before your own bugles have sounded two notes of the charge you find yourself leaning forward over the neck of your galloping horse.
10147-8{_}3577{_}All the rest is a mad gallop, yells of the enemy and your own answer, a terrible shock in which you are almost dismounted, and then you find yourself face to face with a single opponent who, standing up in the stirrups, is about to split your head.
10147-8{_}3578{_}You notice that you are striking like a fiend with the saber.
10147-8{_}3579{_}"After that madness passes it seems almost like a complex maneuver and soon you find yourself riding for dear life--perhaps to escape, perhaps after the Germans.
10147-8{_}3580{_}You then realize that you have been whipped and that the charge has failed, or you see the backs of the fleeing enemy, feel your horse straining in pursuit and know that you have gained a victory."
10147-8{_}3581{_}FRIGHTFUL MORTALITY AMONG OFFICERS  The official reports of the loss of life in the battles in France tell of the large number of officers killed.
10147-8{_}3582{_}Sharp-shooters on both sides have had instructions to aim at officers.
10147-8{_}3583{_}These sharpshooters are often concealed far in advance of their troops.
10147-8{_}3584{_}Their small number and their smokeless powder make their discovery most difficult.
10147-8{_}3585{_}This lesson was learned at great cost to the British during the Boer war.
10147-8{_}3586{_}Dispatches from Bordeaux stated that letters found on dead and captured German officers prove the truth of reports regarding the terrible mortality in the German ranks, especially among officers.
10147-8{_}3587{_}In the Tenth and Imperial Guard Corps of the German army it is said that only a few high ranking officers escaped being shot, and many have been killed.
10147-8{_}3588{_}The German officers have distinguished themselves by their courage, according to the stories of both British and French who fought them.
10147-8{_}3589{_}An officer of an Imperial Guard regiment, who was taken prisoner after being wounded, said:  "My regiment left for the front with sixty officers; it counts today only five.
10147-8{_}3590{_}"We underwent terrible trials."
10147-8{_}3591{_}A German artillery officer wrote:  "Modern war is the greatest of follies.
10147-8{_}3592{_}Companies of 250 men in the Tenth Army Corps have been reduced to seventy men, and there are companies of the guard commanded by volunteers of a year, all the officers having disappeared."
10147-8{_}3593{_}SAYS GEBMANS FOUGHT EVERY DAY  The following is from a letter, written during the prolonged battle of the Aisne by a lieutenant of the Twenty-sixth German Artillery:  "The Tenth Corps has been constantly in action since the opening of the campaign.
10147-8{_}3594{_}Nearly all our horses have fallen.
10147-8{_}3595{_}We fight every day from 5 in the morning till 8 at night, without eating or drinking.
10147-8{_}3596{_}The artillery fire of the French is frightful.
10147-8{_}3597{_}We get so tired that we cannot ride a horse, even at a walk.
10147-8{_}3598{_}Toward noon our battery was literally under a rain of shrapnel shells and that lasted for three days.
10147-8{_}3599{_}We hope for a decisive battle to end the situation, for our troops cannot rest.
10147-8{_}3600{_}A French aviator last night threw four bombs, killing four men and wounding eight, and killing twenty horses and wounding ten more.
10147-8{_}3601{_}We do not receive any more mail, for the postal automobiles of the Tenth Corps have been destroyed."
10147-8{_}3602{_}HOW IT FEELS TO BE WOUNDED  Many men in the trenches have proved themselves heroes in the war.
10147-8{_}3603{_}A wounded British private told this story:  "We lay in the trench, my friend and I, and when the order to fire came we shot, and shot till our rifles burned up.
10147-8{_}3604{_}Still the Germans swarmed on toward us, and then my friend received a bad wound.
10147-8{_}3605{_}I turned to my work again, continuing to shoot slowly.
10147-8{_}3606{_}Then I rose a little too high on my shoulder.
10147-8{_}3607{_}"Do you know what it is like to be wounded?
10147-8{_}3608{_}A little sting pierced my arm like a hot wire; too sharp almost to be sore, and my rifle fell from me.
10147-8{_}3609{_}I looked at my friend then and he was dead."
10147-8{_}3610{_}In one casualty list made public by the British war office in September, sixteen officers were reported killed, thirty-eight wounded and ten missing.
10147-8{_}3611{_}The famous Coldstream Guards and the Black Watch regiments were among the sufferers.
10147-8{_}3612{_}HOW GENEBAL FINDLEY DIED  A correspondent in France described the death of General Neil Douglas Findley of the British Royal Artillery as follows:  "When at dawn the British advance continued toward Soissons the enemy was fighting an exceptionally fierce rearguard action.
10147-8{_}3613{_}A terrible shell fire was directed against our artillery under General Findley, temporarily situated in a valley by the village of Prise.
10147-8{_}3614{_}It seemed a matter of moments when we should have to spike our guns and General Findley saw the urgency for action.
10147-8{_}3615{_}"'Boys,' his voice echoed down the line, 'we are going to get every gun into position,' Then deliberately the general approached a regimental chaplain kneeling beside a gunner.
10147-8{_}3616{_}'Here are some of my personal belongings, chaplain.
10147-8{_}3617{_}See that they don't go astray,'  "One by one our guns began to blaze away and the general had a word of encouragement and advice for every man.
10147-8{_}3618{_}In vain his staff tried to persuade him to leave the danger zone.
10147-8{_}3619{_}"Our range was perfect, the German fire slackened and died away and with a yell our men prepared to advance.
10147-8{_}3620{_}The outburst came too soon, one parting shell exploding in a contact with Findley's horse, shattering man and beast."
10147-8{_}3621{_}KILLED FOE IN REVOLVER DUEL  While their men battled on a road near Antwerp, it is said that a Belgian cavalry sergeant and an officer of German Uhlans fought a revolver duel which ended when the Belgian killed his foe, sending a bullet into his neck at close range.
10147-8{_}3622{_}The daring Uhlans had approached close to the Antwerp fortifications on a reconnoitering expedition.
10147-8{_}3623{_}They were seen by a small Belgian force, which immediately went out on the road to give battle.
10147-8{_}3624{_}As they neared each other, the German commander shouted a jibe at the Belgian sergeant.
10147-8{_}3625{_}There was no answer, but the sergeant rode at a gallop straight for the Uhlan.
10147-8{_}3626{_}Miraculously escaping the shots aimed at him, he drew up alongside the officer and informed him that his life was to be forfeited for the insulting words he had uttered.
10147-8{_}3627{_}Both began firing with their revolvers, while at the same time their men clashed.
10147-8{_}3628{_}Only a few of the soldiers witnessed the thrilling duel, for they themselves were fighting desperately.
10147-8{_}3629{_}After their officer's death the Uhlans withdrew, leaving a number of dead.
10147-8{_}3630{_}Someone carried word of the duel to King Albert, who had just arrived in Antwerp, and he called before him and personally congratulated the sergeant, Henri Pyppes.
10147-8{_}3631{_}The latter was wounded in the arm by one of the Uhlan's bullets, but he refused to be taken to the hospital and remained on duty in the field.
10147-8{_}3632{_}LITTLE STORIES FROM FRANCE  Count Guerry de Beauregard, a French veteran of the war of 1870, thus announced the death of a son at the front: "One son already has met the death of the brave beyond the frontier at the head of a squadron of the Seventh Hussars.
10147-8{_}3633{_}Others will avenge him.
10147-8{_}3634{_}Another of my sons, an artilleryman, is with the general staff.
10147-8{_}3635{_}My eldest son is with the Twenty-first Chasseurs.
10147-8{_}3636{_}Long live France!"
10147-8{_}3637{_}A wounded French soldier who was taken to Marseilles verified a remarkable story of his escape from death while fighting in German Lorraine.
10147-8{_}3638{_}The soldier owes his life to a small bust of Emperor William, which he picked up in a village school and placed in his haversack.
10147-8{_}3639{_}A German bullet struck the bust and, thus deflected, inflicted only a slight wound on the soldier.
10147-8{_}3640{_}Twenty German prisoners taken during the melee near Crecy, were herded together in a clearing, their rifles being stacked nearby.
10147-8{_}3641{_}In a rash moment they thought that they were loosely guarded and made a combined rush for the rifles.
10147-8{_}3642{_}"They will never make another," was the laconic report of the guard.
10147-8{_}3643{_}SAYS DEAD FILLED THE MEUSE  Edouard Helsey of the Paris newspaper, Le Journal, reported to be serving with the colors, wrote under date of August 29:  "It would be difficult to estimate the number of Germans killed last week.
10147-8{_}3644{_}Whole regiments were annihilated at some points.
10147-8{_}3645{_}They came out of the woods section by section.
10147-8{_}3646{_}One section, one shell--and everything was wiped out.
10147-8{_}3647{_}"At two or three places which I am forbidden to name corpses filled the Meuse until the river overflowed.
10147-8{_}3648{_}This is no figure of speech.
10147-8{_}3649{_}The river bed literally was choked by the mass of dead Germans.
10147-8{_}3650{_}The effect of our artillery surpasses even our dreams."
10147-8{_}3651{_}DETROIT ARTIST'S NARROW ESCAPE  Lawrence Stern Stevens, an artist of Detroit, narrowly escaped death near Aix-la-Chapelle at the hands of a crazed German lieutenant, by whom he was suspected of being a spy.
10147-8{_}3652{_}Stevens left Brussels on Aug. 24 in an automobile.
10147-8{_}3653{_}He was accompanied by a photographer and a Belgian newspaper correspondent, and his intention had been to make sketches on the battlefield.
10147-8{_}3654{_}His arrest at Laneffe thwarted this plan.
10147-8{_}3655{_}He underwent a terrifying ordeal at the hands of his demented captor, although he was not actually injured.
10147-8{_}3656{_}On the evening of Aug. 24 he was court-martialed and sentenced to death and held in close confinement over night.
10147-8{_}3657{_}Early on the morning of Aug. 25 he was led out, as he supposed, to be shot, but the plans had been changed and instead he was taken before Gen. von Arnim.
10147-8{_}3658{_}After being forced to march with German troops for two days, Stevens fell in with a party of American correspondents at Beaumont, from which point he traveled to Aix-la-Chapelle on a prison train, and eventually reached Rotterdam and safety.
10147-8{_}3659{_}SAD PLIGHT OF FRENCH FUGITIVES  M. Brieux, the noted French dramatist, who witnessed the arrival at Chartres of a train full of fugitives who had fled from their homes before the German advance, described his experience for the Figaro.
10147-8{_}3660{_}The fleeing people gathered round him and told him stories and he wrote his impressions as follows:  "Children weep or gaze wide-eyed, wondering what is the matter.
10147-8{_}3661{_}Old folks sit in gloomy silence.
10147-8{_}3662{_}Women with haggard cheeks and disheveled hair seem to belong to another age.
10147-8{_}3663{_}"They tell of invaders who scattered powder around or threw petroleum into their houses and then set them afire.
10147-8{_}3664{_}"And when did this happen?
10147-8{_}3665{_}Yesterday!
10147-8{_}3666{_}It is not a matter of centuries ago in distant climes, but yesterday, and quite near to us.
10147-8{_}3667{_}Yet one cannot believe it was really yesterday that these things were done."
10147-8{_}3668{_}One of the fugitives explained to M. Brieux why after the first hour of their flight she had to carry her elder child as well as her baby.
10147-8{_}3669{_}She showed him a pair of boots.
10147-8{_}3670{_}"I felt the inside with my fingers," says Brieux.
10147-8{_}3671{_}"Nails had come through the soles.
10147-8{_}3672{_}I looked at the child's feet.
10147-8{_}3673{_}They were dirty with red brown clots.
10147-8{_}3674{_}It was blood."
10147-8{_}3675{_}CHAUNCEY DEPEW ON A RUNNING-BOARD  Chauncey M. Depew, former United States Senator for New York, was in Geneva when the trouble began.
10147-8{_}3676{_}He said on his return: "After crossing the border into France we picked up men joining the colors on the way to Paris, until our train could hold no more.
10147-8{_}3677{_}"Whenever I stuck my head into a corridor the soldiers would set up a cheer on seeing my side whiskers.
10147-8{_}3678{_}They mistook me for an Englishman and cried: 'Long live the _entente cordiale!_'"  IN THE "VALLEY OF DEATH"  The fiercest fighting of all that preceded the Russian victory at Lublin was in a gorge near the village of Mikolaiff, which the Russian soldiers reverently named the "Valley of Death."
10147-8{_}3679{_}The gorge was full of dead men, lying in heaps, according to an officer who participated in the battle.
